pwclmm-title.lmm-statement: The content of this manual is a direct extract from the Pratt & Whitney Canada PW617F-E Engine Maintenance Manual Part No. 3072162 and contains all Ramp and Line Maintenance Tasks and information. Heavy Maintenance Tasks and information can be found in the PW617F-E Engine Maintenance Manual Part No. 3072162.
Maintenance Manual Part No. 3072162 will be made available to operators and/or shops that can demonstrate the ability to perform the necessary work.

mfmatr.title: SERVICE BULLETIN LIST
mfmatr.para: The Service Bulletins given in this list are applicable to the PW617F-E series engine family. This list contains four columns which are:
- The P&WC SB No. The SB are given in sequence of P&WC SB number
- The ATA SB No. The ATA bulletin prefix PW617F-E is not given into the list.
- The Rev. No. which is the revision number of the SB.

- The Incorporation Status. The term INCORPORATED in this column shows that the SB is incorporated in the manual. The term NO EFFECT in this column shows that no change to the manual was necessary for that SB number. The term NOT USED in this column shows that there is no SB document available at the time the manual SB list was revised.

prcitem.title: General
prcitem.para: This maintenance manual contains the recommended procedures for maintaining PW617F-E engines manufactured by Pratt & Whitney Canada. Personnel involved with engine maintenance should acquaint themselves with the contents of the following introductory paragraphs for full comprehension of the information contained in this manual.

Procedures in this manual may be accomplished with the engine installed or removed from the airframe. This manual will be revised as necessary to incorporate any changes as they arise and also incorporate latest approved procedures and data. This manual is not customized to any particular airframe installation. Configurational variations that may arise as a result of installation or peculiar requirement will be dealt with in the text as they occur.

prcitem.title: Customer Service
prcitem.para: Customer Service representatives maintain contact with operators and service activities and are available for investigation of any specific difficulty or problem. Request for assistance should be directed to:
Request for AOG support should also be directed to:

prcitem.title: Customer Feedback
prcitem.para: Any discrepancies, problems or suggestions regarding this publication should be forwarded in writing, using the Pratt & Whitney Canada Customer Feedback Sheet (RSVP), and directed to:

Customer Feedback Sheets are enclosed with new manuals and each subsequent revision. Additional forms may be obtained by contacting: The Supervisor, Publications Customer Services, at the above address. An on-line RSVP form is also available via the P&WC website above.

prcitem.title: Engine Accessory Repair
prcitem.para: Send all engine accessory components for repair/repair-by-replacement to:

prcitem.title: Maintenance Concept
prcitem.para: There are three maintenance levels for the PW617F-E engine: Ramp Maintenance, Line Maintenance and Heavy Maintenance. Repairs beyond the levels detailed in this manual are not recommended and should be done by an approved overhaul facility.

numlitem.para: Ramp Maintenance consists of the tasks required to verify engine condition and which can be accomplished without the use of special tools.
Line Maintenance is the removal and installation of external components and engine accessories.

Heavy Maintenance details Hot Section Inspection (HSI), repair and removals considered beyond the normal capabilities of the average line maintenance shop. The scope includes the removal and installation of engine internal components and limited repair to the hot section area.

prcitem.para: Instructions are given with the understanding that Standard Practices, Chapter 70, has been read, entirely understood and will be followed.
Refer to Table for a complete list of Maintenance Tasks.

prcitem.title: How to Use this Manual
prcitem.para: Subject matter in this manual is separated into specific Chapters, Sections and Subjects in accordance with ATA Specification No. 2200. Each Chapter is divided into sections and each section is divided into subjects. Each subject is divided into pageblocks and each pageblock is divided into tasks.

prcitem.title: Chapter/Section/Subject Numbering
prcitem.para: Subject matter in this manual is separated into specific Chapters, Sections and Subjects in accordance with ATA Specification No. 2200. Each Chapter is divided into sections and each section is divided into subjects. These three elements are shown in large bold numbers at the lower right hand corner of each page, where applicable. Chapters contained in this manuals are listed below. Refer to the section "LIST OF CH/SE/SU", for a complete breakdown of all the Chapter/Section/Subjects used in this manual.

prcitem.title: Pageblock Numbering
prcitem.para: Page number blocks are used to further subdivide subjects into maintenance categories and are listed below:

prcitem.title: Task Numbering System
prcitem.para: The structure of this manual is controlled by the Air Transport Association (ATA) Specification No. 2200. It uses the Jet Engine Maintenance Task Oriented Support System (JEMTOSS) which has task and subtask numbers for text, illustrations and tables. The system permits this manual to be adapted to the different electronic or manual systems of the users.

The task numbering system permits selection of data or cross-references because each task or subtask number is unique. The task numbers give an accurate point of reference that will not change with revisions to pages or paragraph numbers.

Each operation specified in this manual has a task number which is controlled by ATA Specification No. 2200 numbering system and the function of the data. The task number contains five elements. The first three of these elements are the ATA number and they give the Chapter/Section/Subject number.

The fourth element identifies the function (inspection, repair, test, etc.). Refer to Table for specific fourth element function identification. The fifth element gives a different identification for each task/subtask in the function. Task identifiers, given in sequence, are from 801 thru 999 and subtask identifiers are from 001 thru 800.

entry.para: Remove Engine Test Equipment and Instrumentation
Install Engine Test Equipment and Instrumentation

prcitem.title: Supplementary Publications
prcitem.para: Personnel concerned with the maintenance of the PW617F-E engine should familiarize themselves with the content of the Illustrated Parts Catalog, P&WC Manual P/N 3072164, which lists and describes the saleable parts of the engine and illustrates their inter-relationship.
Refer to the P&WC Consumable Materials List Manual, P/N 3043340 for information about consumable materials referred to in this manual.

prcitem.title: Component Maintenance Manuals
prcitem.para: Table 2 lists the Component Maintenance Manuals (CMM) for the PW617F-E engine. Refer to Illustrated Parts Catalog, P&WC Manual P/N 3072164, for component part numbers and supplier codes.

prcitem.title: Service Bulletins
prcitem.para: Service Bulletins will be issued as required to provide information or instructions for modifying engines or parts to the latest configuration.

prcitem.title: Special Tool Service Bulletins
prcitem.para: Special Tool Service Bulletins provide instructions for modifying special tools to a later configuration.

prcitem.title: Safety
prcitem.para: This manual describes processes that may require the use of chemicals, solvents, paints or other commercially available materials.

Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) containing information about Trade Name, Safety Hazards, Health Hazards, Reactivity, Spill or Leak Procedures, Special Protection Information, Special Precautions and Transportation and Labelling are available from the manufacturer. Read prior to using consumable materials.

prcitem.title: Directional References
prcitem.para: The terms right or left, clockwise or counterclockwise, upper or lower, and similar directional referenced, will apply to the engine as viewed from the rear with the engine in a horizontal position.

prcitem.title: Build Specification (BS)
prcitem.para: Build Specifications BS1209, BS1277 and BS1278 are applicable throughout this manual unless otherwise specified.

prcitem.title: Special Tools
prcitem.para: Special tools required to maintain the engine are listed in Table. Refer to 'Supplementary Tool Information' for recommendations on safe use, handling and maintenance of Pratt & Whitney Canada special tools.
The maintenance tasks for the PW617F-E engines detailed in this manual are in four categories specific to P&WC, Table gives equivalent categories based on ATA 104 and A/C AMM definitions.
You can get tools from the following suppliers:

l1item.para: The Airworthiness Limitations section is contained in the PW617F-E Airworthiness Limitations Manual P/N 3072699.

The Airworthiness Limitations Manual P/N 3072699 contains mandatory rotor component cyclic life limits which are a condition of engine type certification. These limits are approved by Transport Canada.
The Operating Limits and Leading Particulars section (Ref. Task 05-10-00-990-801) contains limits approved by Transport Canada.

The Scheduled Inspection/Maintenance Intervals section (Ref. Task 05-20-00-210-801) consists of periodic inspections, maintenance tasks, frequencies and overhaul life limits which have been accepted by Transport Canada.

The Unscheduled Maintenance Inspections section (Ref. Task 05-50-00-210-801) consists of inspections and actions required when an engine exceeds the operating limitations (Ref. Task 05-10-00-990-801) or is subjected to unusual stress or operating conditions or gives unsatisfactory performance.
This section lists engine operating limits, overspeed limits, overtemperature limits and leading particulars for PW617F-E engines.
Engine operating limits are found in Table.
Engine leading particulars are detailed in Table.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: Maximum (MAX) is an Automatic Thrust Reserve intended to be used for a period of not more than ten minutes after a failure of one engine on a twin engine aircraft.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: TO/GA (Takeoff/Go Around) is the thrust normally set for Takeoff during everyday operations. The total time during which Takeoff thrust may be used is limited to five minutes per flight. The five minute limit commences when the power lever is advanced to the Take off detent.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: Maximum Continuous (MCT/CLIMB) is the maximum thrust approved for operation without time constraints. However, normal operation is intended to be a combination of Takeoff, Climb and Cruise settings. Maximum Continuous is not intended for regular, normal operation.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: Idle is the minimum thrust available. Ground idle N2 speed is a minimum of 54% N2. Flight Idle N2 speed is a minimum of 59% N2. Idle speed is determined by the control system as a function of ambient temperature and pressure.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: Oil Pressure. See Figure

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: After completing a start under cold conditions or with cold fuel (below 0C) and achieving a stabilized Idle, remain at Ground Idle for the time required for the oil to reach the minimum operating temperature of 14C. During this time the Transient oil pressure limit applies. Run the engine for an additional three minutes to make sure that no ice particles are present in the fuel supplied to the engine.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: N1 denotes fan speed. N2 denotes HP compressor speed.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: Under certain cold start conditions oil pressure may reach 275 psig.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: A minimum N2 must be maintained to ensure engine operation in icing conditions. The FADEC Power Management controls Ground and Flight Idle N2 above the minimum speed demonstrated for AWM 533.68 Induction System Icing.

l1item.para: This section contains the minimum Pratt & Whitney Canada approved engine maintenance inspection checks (based on flight hours as defined in the airworthiness limitations section of this manual (Ref. Task 00-00-00-860-801), or calendar times whichever occurs first) and are intended to coincide with airframe inspection intervals (not to exceed the listed frequencies). Detailed procedures are provided, where applicable, in the relevant INSPECTION/CHECK sections of subject chapters in this manual. A list of the explanation of terms is given in Task 72-00-00-290-801.
The rotor component life limitations outlined in the airworthiness limitations section of this manual (Ref. Task 00-00-00-860-801), override all other scheduled activities.

Operators may choose other maintenance programs, including a P&WC customized one. It is the operator's responsibility to obtain individual maintenance program approval from their local airworthiness authority.
The scheduled maintenance checks include the following:

l2item.para: Recommended Maintenance Tasks listed in Table.
Engine Hot Section Inspections.
Engine Overhauls.
Low Utilization Engine Inspections.

l1item.para: At intervals of 600 flight hours or one calender year (whichever comes first) the EEC must be interrogated for EEC faults (Ref. Task 72-00-02-810-801). Do the corrective actions on the detected faults as indicated by the fault codes.

note.para: TLD faults may be identified by viewing the Maintenance Computer display page (Refer to the AMM).

l1item.para: If Long Term Dispatch (LTD) faults are found before the end of 600 flight hours or one calender year interrogation interval, flight is allowed, however all of the faults must be cleared before the end of 600 flight hours or one calender year interrogation interval (Ref. PW617F-E Airworthiness Limitations Manual, P/N 3072699, Time Limited Dispatch).

note.para: LTD status is indicated in the Aircraft Central Maintenance Computer. If LTD is active, the Maintenance Message "LONG DISPATCH" will be displayed as a maintenance message.

l1item.para: At the time of the inspection, if it is noted that the LTD indication is set in the Aircraft Maintenance Computer, but there are no related faults latched, it is required to download the information from the Data Collection Unit (DCU) to check for intermittent TLD faults. All TLD faults data from the most recent 10 flights must be reviewed and rectified, unless the fault was induced by maintenance action.
After the inspection is completed, the LTD status should be cleared. (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-822), TLD Clear Procedure (Long Dispatch).
All faults indicated by the EEC must be cleared at this interval.
When any component, accessory or LRU is removed due to any TLD fault, the following information must be provided to Pratt & Whitney Canada:

unlitem.para: Fault code and corrective action taken

l1item.para: Send this information:

l2item.para: Directly to P&WC Engine Data Knowledge Management via e-mail to COPS.TRAC@PWC.CA or by fax to 450-647-6836.
Send a copy of the information with the component, accessory or LRU to help with the investigation.

l1item.para: Do the Scheduled Inspections of the PW617F-E engine in accordance with Table.
Task Type Definitions:

l2item.para: GVI - General Visual Inspection: A visual examination of an interior or exterior area, installation or assembly to detect obvious damage, failure or irregularity. This level of inspection is made from within touching distance, unless otherwise specified. A mirror may be necessary to enhance visual access to all exposed surfaces in the inspection area. This level is made under normally available lighting conditions such as daylight, hanger lighting, flashlight or drop light and may require removal or opening of access panels or doors. Stands, ladders or platforms may be required to gain proximity to the area being checked.

DET - Detailed Inspection: An intensive visual examination of a specific item, installation or assembly to detect damage, failure or irregularity. Available lighting is normally supplemented with a direct source of good lighting at an intensity deemed appropriate. Inspection aids such as mirrors, magnifying lenses etc. may be necessary. Surface cleaning and elaborated access procedures may be required.

SDI - Special Detailed Inspection: An intensive examination of a specific item, installation or assembly to detect damage, failure or irregularity. The examination is likely to make extensive use of special inspection techniques and/or equipment. Intricate cleaning and substantial access or disassembly procedure may be required.
DIS - Discard: The removal from service of an item at a specified life limit
OPC - Operational Check: An operational check is a task to determine that an item is fulfilling its intended purpose. The check does not require quantitative tolerances.
VCK - A visual check is a task to determine that an item is fulfilling its intended purpose. The check does not require quantitative tolerances.

l1item.para: The inspection procedure and criteria are described in the referenced chapter.

Do an Operational Check of the T6 Temperature Indicating System
Every 1800 flight hours or 36 months, whichever comes first.

Every 600 flight hours or 12 months, whichever comes first.
Every 600 flight hours or 12 months, whichever comes first.
Check the Exterior Surfaces of the Nacelle for Evidence of Oil Leaks
Daily/Pre-flight (see NOTE:) and every 600 flight hours or 12 months, whichever comes first.
Daily/Pre-flight (see NOTE:) and every 600 flight hours or 12 months, whichever comes first.
Check the Oil Filter Impending Bypass Indicator Popup Button
Inspect the Oil Filter Impending Bypass Indicator
Every 600 flight hours or 12 months, whichever comes first.
Do an Operational Check of the Chip Detector
Every 600 flight hours or 12 months, whichever comes first.

note.para: These actions are performed by the flight crew as part of the pre-flight "walk around" inspection. Refer to the Aircraft Flight Manual.

l1item.para: The initial HSI for the PW617F-E engine must be performed at 1750 flight hours. Subsequent HSIs must be done every 1750 flight hours. An additional 50 flight hours is available for scheduling purposes.
A different HSI interval may exist as part of a P&WC customized Maintenance Plan.
The TBO for the PW617F-E engines is 3500 flight hours. An additional 100 flight hours is available for scheduling purposes.
A different Overhaul interval may exist as part of a P&WC customized maintenance plan.

Further increases to the TBO interval are subject to the approval of the operator's local regulatory authority and it is the responsibility of individual operators to make applications for such increases.

Operators desiring P&WC support for its application for TBO extension should submit a formal request in writing, together with details of the sample engine condition with name and address of the overhaul facility to:

unlitem.para: Attention: Manager, Customer Support - Service Engineering, PW600 Engines.

l1item.para: A low utilization engine is defined as an engine that has not been subject to disassembly and inspection of both hot section and cold section at an approved overhaul facility by the end of the following service intervals, whichever comes first (Ref. Task 72-00-00-290-817).

unlitem.para: 12 years since entry into Service/Overhaul, or

l1item.para: For engines subject to low utilization, the initial on-wing Low Utilization Inspection (LUI) is to be done at the end of the following periods, whichever comes first:

unlitem.para: 12 years since entry into Service/Overhaul, or

l1item.para: At the end of either of the two LUI intervals, an additional 1 month or 10 flying hours, whichever comes first, is permitted for scheduling purposes.

Subsequent LUI's are to be performed at 24 month intervals, provided that visual inspections, borescope inspections and performance calibration runs are satisfactory. If the visual or borescope inspections or the calibration runs are not satisfactory, return the engine to an approved service facility for appropriate maintenance or repairs.
Unless otherwise stated, the tolerance for periodic or scheduled inspections is ten percent (10%), or up to a maximum of 100 flight hours, or 30 days calendar time, whichever is less.

note.para: The tolerance is established for maintenance scheduling convenience only and must be approved by the governing civil aviation authority.

l1item.para: The following engine accessories must be returned with the engine whenever the engine is routed to an overhaul facility for scheduled inspection/repair in accordance with the PW617F-E Engine Overhaul Manual. These accessories are to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Maintenance Manual instructions or their respective Component Maintenance Manuals:

numlitem.para: Fuel Metering Unit (FMU)
Engine Electronic Control (EEC)
Engine Electrical Wiring Harness
Engine Data Collection Unit (DCU)
T6 Thermocouple Harness Assembly
Bleed Valve Actuator (BVA)
Fuel-to-Oil Heat Exchanger (FOHE)
Air Cooled Oil Cooler (ACOC)
Ignition Exciter
Ignition Cables
Spark Igniters
Chip Detector
Fuel Filter Impending Bypass Switch
Fuel Filter Bypass Indicator (Pop Up)
Oil Filter Impending Bypass Indicator (Pop Up)

l1item.para: A regular wash is recommended for engines being operated in sandy, dusty, or in smog or salt laden environments (Ref. Table). For engine cleaning procedures, refer to Chapter 71-00-00, Cleaning/Painting.

Engine cleaning includes external washes, hand-wash of the fan as well as compressor desalination or performance recovery washes. An external wash is recommended when the engine is operated in an environment where atmospheric contamination exists.

Environmental conditions vary depending on engine operation and geographical location. Air pollution and salt-water exposure are examples of adverse environments. Chemical reactions with fuel and heat can produce severe corrosion, which can be significantly reduced through regular gas path washing.

Table provides wash schedules to reduce the rate of engine deterioration when the engine is operated in adverse environments. Periodic inspection of the engine externals, compressor inlet, and compressor gas path components for contamination can also be used as a basis for establishing external and internal wash requirements.

Engine wash schedule, compressor and external, are to be determined by the operator, with consideration of the specific aircraft operating and environmental condition. Wash frequency should be adjusted to suit the engines exposure to adverse environmental conditions. Exposure determination of continual, frequent or occasional operation should consider factors such as; time at altitude, home-base environment, destination, and storage in a sheltered, air-conditioned hangar.

entry.para: Continually operated in dusty, sandy, heavily polluted or salt-laden environment.
Frequently operated in dusty, sandy, heavily polluted or salt-laden environment.
Occasionally operated in dusty, sandy, heavily polluted or salt-laden environment.
As required to suit engine operating conditions as indicated by engine condition trend monitoring system.

note.para: * Washing frequency may be adjusted to suit operator experience and engine condition.

Air pollution: The process of polluting the atmosphere by the discharge of harmful substances, causing contamination with, for example, volcanic dust or corrosive chemicals such as those found in industrial smog.
Salt laden environment: The presence of salt haze, created by finely divided particles of sea salt in the air, usually derived from the evaporation of sea spray.
A motoring wash for light soil or multiple motoring washes for heavy soil contamination is recommended.
Multiple compressor washes should be performed to the extent permitted by starter operating limitations. Observe starter cooling period (Ref. Starter manufacturer's manual)

l1item.para: An unscheduled maintenance inspection must be done when the engine is subjected to unusual stress or operating conditions, exceeds operating limitations or gives unsatisfactory performance.

If, as the result of the inspection, engine removal is required, a written report, stating the cause of removal in detail (e.g. overspeed, overtemperature, etc.) must be sent with the engine to an overhaul/repair facility.
If an operational engine must be removed, a Power Assurance check (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-813) is recommended before engine removal to determine the extent of inspection/repair required.
In the event of a "NO DISPATCH " EICAS message, do the corrective actions on the detected faults indicated by the EEC fault codes (Ref. Task 72-00-02-810-801).

In the event of a "SHORT DISPATCH " EICAS message, do the corrective actions on the detected faults indicated by the EEC fault codes (Ref. Task 72-00-02-810-801). Faults must be rectified within 125 flight hours.
When any component, accessory or LRU is removed due to any TLD fault, the following information must be provided to Pratt & Whitney Canada:

unlitem.para: Fault code and corrective action taken

l1item.para: Send this information:

l2item.para: Directly to P&WC Engine Data Knowledge Management via e-mail to COPS.TRAC@PWC.CA or by fax to 450-647-6836.
Send a copy of this information with the component, accessory or LRU to help with the investigation.

l1item.para: Do a functional check of the aircraft engine temperature indicating system, refer to the AMM. If serviceable, refer to Task 05-10-00-990-801 for the required maintenance actions. Refer to Task 77-20-02-710-801 for the operational check of the T6 thermocouple system (heat response check).
Make sure there are no N1 and N2 speed sensor maintenance messages or faults. If serviceable, refer to Task 05-10-00-990-801 for the required maintenance actions.
Investigate each instance of FOD to determine the cause and circumstance.
When evaluating damage to the LP compressor (rotor and stator) or inlet cone, the integrity of the complete engine should be considered.

Inspect the nose cone, fan blades, fan case and fan exit stators. If indications that a foreign object might have entered the HP compressor are present, do a borescope inspection of the HP compressor (Ref. Task 72-00-00-290-804).
Continue downstream borescope inspection if indication is found that the foreign object might have affected downstream components.

Remove the ACOC in accordance with Maintenance Manual Instructions (Ref. Task 79-20-07-000-801). If there are indications that foreign object debris is present, return the ACOC to the Supplier to be inspected/repaired according to the Component Maintenance Manual instructions. Install a serviceable ACOC according to the Maintenance Manual instructions (Ref. Task 79-20-07-400-801).

If the damage found is not acceptable for continuing in operation (Ref. Task 72-00-00-290-804), return the engine to an approved overhaul facility to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions.

If the components are serviceable, turn the LP rotor by hand and turn the HP rotor using a suitable socket installed in the AGB starter drive gearshaft, listen for unusual noises. If unusual noises are heard, return engine to an approved overhaul facility, to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions.

Inspect the chip detector (Ref. Task 79-30-01-210-801) and the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-210-801). If debris is found in the oil filter or the chip detector, refer to debris in oil system fault isolation (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831).
Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810), do a ground run and a vibration survey (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-818). Check that the engine operates normally.
Investigate each instance of bird strike to determine the cause and circumstance.
When evaluating damage to the LP compressor (rotor and stator) or inlet cone, the integrity of the complete engine should be considered.

Inspect the nose cone, fan blades, fan case and fan exit stators. If indications that a foreign object might have entered the HP compressor are present, do a borescope inspection of the HP compressor (Ref. Task 72-00-00-290-804).

Remove and inspect the ACOC for debris. If debris is noted replace unit. Install the ACOC and perform a leak check of the external tubes. Make sure the inside of the bypass duct is inspected for any evidence of leaks.
Continue downstream borescope inspection if indication is found that the foreign object might have affected downstream components.

If the damage found is not acceptable for continuing in operation (Ref. Task 72-00-00-290-804), return the engine to an approved overhaul facility to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions.

If the components are serviceable, turn the LP rotor by hand and turn the HP rotor using a suitable socket installed in the AGB starter drive gearshaft, listen for unusual noises. If unusual noises are heard, return engine to an approved overhaul facility, to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions.

Inspect the chip detector (Ref. Task 79-30-01-210-801) and the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-210-801). If debris is found in the oil filter or the chip detector, refer to debris in oil system fault isolation (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831).
Do a fan wash (Ref. Task 71-00-00-160-806) and a compressor wash (Ref. Task 71-00-00-160-808). Check that the bleed ports are clear of contamination.
Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810) and do a ground run, refer to the AMM. Check that the engine operates normally.

Visually check engine inlet for evidence of arcing, pitting or black scarring on the nose cone or low compressor rotor blades. If evident return the engine to an approved overhaul facility. Indicate lightning strike.
If a lightning strike is suspected but no evidence of arcing is visible, do the following steps.

Turn the low pressure rotor by hand and listen for unusual noises coming from the fan and turbine bearings. If unusual noises are heard, return the engine to an approved overhaul facility for lightning strike inspection.

Inspect the chip detector (Ref. Task 79-30-01-210-801) and the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-210-801). If debris is found in the oil filter or the chip detector, refer to Debris In Oil System fault isolation (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831).
If debris is not found, reinstall the oil filter and the chip detector.
Visually inspect all of the electrical wiring harnesses and bonding straps. Check for EEC fault codes (Ref. Task 72-00-02-810-801).
Inspect the starter. Refer to the AMM.
Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810) and ground run up to takeoff power, Refer to the AMM. Check that the engine operating parameters are normal.

Inspect the chip detector (Ref. Task 79-30-01-210-801) and the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-210-801). If metallic/magnetic debris is found, return the engine to an approved overhaul facility for lightning strike inspection.
Return the engine to service if no lightning strike damage is found.

If a chip detector indication occurs within 65 flight hours of the lightning strike event, do the fault isolation chart for Debris In Oil System (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831) and send the debris for analysis.

Inspect the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-210-801) at 65 5 flight hours. If debris is found, refer to Debris In Oil System fault isolation (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831). If debris is not found, the engine may continue in service with subsequent inspections done as defined by the relevant maintenance program.
Return engine to an approved overhaul facility for an inspection of dropped engines, to be carried out in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions.

The engine is designed to withstand landing loads of 6g. If the 6g load limit was exceeded during a heavy landing incident, the engine must be returned to an approved overhaul facility for inspection and repair in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions. If a 6g load was imposed during a heavy landing incident, do the checks listed below.
If any of the following defects are evident, replace the engine:

unlitem.para: Cracks or distortion of engine mounts.
Damage to engine air intake/fan case.
Cracks or distortion of firewalls and bulkheads.
Damage or insecurity of engine/airframe exhaust duct.

l1item.para: Turn the HP rotor using a suitable socket, installed in the AGB starter drive gearshaft. Listen for unusual noises which can indicate problems in the accessory gears, bearings, seals and rotors. If unusual noises occur, remove engine for investigation.
Check the following airframe/engine connections for security:

unlitem.para: Cable Connectors at the EEC. Refer to the AMM.

l1item.para: Check all engine-mounted accessories for security. Rectify if required.
Check for EEC Fault Codes (Ref. Task 72-00-02-810-801).
Do an Engine Power Assurance Check (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-813).

If a chip detector indication occurs within 65 flight hours of the hard landing event, do the fault isolation chart for Debris In Oil System (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831) and send the debris for analysis.

taskproc.title: Engine Windmilling for Less than 15 Minutes

l1item.para: No inspection required.

taskproc.title: Engine Windmilling for More than 15 Minutes with Positive Oil Pressure

l1item.para: If there was positive pressure indication during windmilling do an oil level check before returning the engine to service. If the oil level is low, some oil could be in the accessory gearbox, therefore, a motoring run might be required before servicing.

taskproc.title: Engine Windmilling for More than 15 Minutes with No Positive Oil Pressure

l1item.para: If there was no positive oil pressure indication, do the following steps.
Turn the low pressure (LP) rotor by hand and listen for unusual noises coming from the fan and turbine bearings.
Turn the high pressure (HP) rotor using a suitable socket, installed on the AGB starter drive gearshaft. Listen for unusual noises coming from bearings and gears.
If unusual noises are heard, return the engine to an approved overhaul facility, to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions.

Inspect chip detector and oil filter. If debris is found, do the fault isolation chart for Debris In Oil System (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831). Replace the oil filter, clean and reinstall the chip detector.
Check the oil level (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-803).
Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810) and ground run up to take off power, refer to the AMM. Check that engine parameters are normal.

Repeat the chip detector and oil filter inspection. If metallic debris is found, return the engine to an approved overhaul facility, to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions.
Repeat the oil level check and replenish the oil system if required (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-804).

In addition, continue to inspect the chip detector every 10 flight hours until 65 flight hours is exceeded. If debris is found, do the fault isolation chart for Debris In Oil System (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831).
Check the engine oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-210-801) at 65 5 flight hours. If debris is found, do the fault isolation chart for Debris In Oil System (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831).
If no debris is found, the engine may continue in service with subsequent inspections carried out as defined per the relevant maintenance program.
Return engine to an approved overhaul facility for an inspection after immersion in water to be carried out in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions.

task.title: Engine Exposed to Fire Extinguishing Agent

l1item.para: Foam, powder or other chemical extinguishers: If only engine externals are exposed, then wash immediately (Ref. Task 71-00-00-160-805) and monitor for corrosion. Otherwise, return engine to an approved overhaul facility to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual instructions.
Halon: No engine maintenance required.

task.title: Aircraft Flown Through a Cloud of Volcanic Ash

l1item.para: Do a compressor wash (Ref. Task 71-00-00-160-808).
Drain the oil (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-806).
Refill the oil system with new oil Task 72-00-00-640-805).
Remove the engine oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801).
Replace the engine oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-400-801).
Do a borescope inspection of the compressor (Ref. Task 72-00-00-290-804).
Do a borescope inspection of the HP turbine (Ref. Task 72-00-00-290-804 and check for glass-like deposits on the turbine blades. If found, do a hot section inspection (Ref. Task 72-00-00-290-802).
Do a Power Assurance Test (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-813).

If defects are found or the results of the Power Assurance Test are unsatisfactory, return the engine to an approved overhaul facility to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual.
If no defects are found and the results of the Power Assurance Test are unsatisfactory, return the engine to service.
Drain and refill the oil system with new oil (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-806 and Task 72-00-00-640-805), 50 10 flight.
Refer to Task 05-10-00-990-801 for the oil temperature limits.
Drain and discard the engine oil (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-806).
Remove oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801). Inspect the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-210-801).
Remove and inspect the chip detector and strainer (Ref. Task 79-30-01-000-801 and Task 79-30-01-210-801).
Repair the cause of the high oil temperature (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-825.
Install the chip detector, strainer and oil filter (Ref. Task 79-30-01-400-801 and Task 79-20-01-400-801).
Fill the oil system with new oil (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-805).
Do a power assurance check (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-813).

Monitor the oil temperature and chip detector indications in the cockpit. Repeat the checks for oil temperature and chip detector indications during the subsequent 65 flight hours. If the operating oil temperature is satisfactory and there is no indication of metal chips, the engine can continue in service with subsequent inspections as specified in the applicable maintenance program (Ref. Task 05-20-00-210-801)

task.title: Use of Unapproved Engine Oil Brands

l1item.para: Drain the engine oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-806).
Flush the engine oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-807).
Fill the engine oil system with original brand of approved engine oil (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-805).

caution.para: IF DEBRIS IS FOUND IN THE OIL, THE LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF THE DEBRIS MUST BE KNOWN BEFORE CONTINUING ENGINE OPERATION.

l1item.para: Refer to Task 05-10-00-990-801 for the oil pressure limits. The engine FADEC will indicate a CAS message for low oil pressure and shows all oil pressure exceedances on the engine exceedance synoptic page.
Do the fault isolation chart for low or high oil pressure as applicable (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-827), to find and repair the root cause.
If there is debris in the oil, send it to an approved laboratory for analysis (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801), the results must be known before continuing engine operation.
If you suspect that the fuel filter is contaminated (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-816), Fuel Filter Bypass Indication (Pop-Up).
Allow the engine to cool. Visually inspect the inlet and exhaust duct for oil.
Check the oil level (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-803).
Remove and inspect the chip detector and strainer (Ref. Task 79-30-01-000-801 and Task 79-30-01-210-801).
Remove and inspect the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801 and Task 79-20-01-210-801).
Check the N1 rotor by manually turning the fan in the correct direction. Check for free movement and listen for unusual scraping or binding.

Check the N2 rotor by manually turning the AGB starter gearshaft with a suitable socket and torque wrench. Check that the maximum torque needed is 15 lb.ft. (20.3 Nm) and listen for unusual scraping or binding.
Do an engine calibration check (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-812) and attach the data to the engine logbook with a description of the event.
Do an engine DCU data download.
Contact P&WC with the results of the above maintenance checks and the DCU data, so that P&WC can make a decision if the engine can continue in operation.

Engine(s) that are taken out of service and were not preserved as specified in the maintenance manual (Ref. Task 72-00-00-620-801) could have corrosion damage. Send the engine to an overhaul facility to inspect for corrosion.
Flush the oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-807).
Flush the oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-807).

Check the N1 rotor by manually turning the fan in the correct direction. Check for free movement and listen for unusual scraping or binding. If unusual noises are heard, send the engine to an overhaul facility.

Check the N2 rotor by manually turning the AGB starter gearshaft with a suitable socket and torque wrench. Check that the maximum torque needed is 15 lb.ft. (20.3 Nm) and listen for unusual scraping or binding. If unusual noises are heard, send the engine to an overhaul facility.

If the maximum torque of 15 lb.ft. (20.3 Nm) is reached before AGB starter gearshaft turns, examine and/or remove the FMU. If the AGB starter gearshaft still does not turn before the maximum torque of 15 lb.ft. (20.3 Nm) is reached, return the engine to an approved overhaul facility to be inspected/repaired in accordance with the Engine Overhaul Manual.

Remove and inspect the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801 and Task 79-20-01-210-801) if debris is found, do the fault isolation chart for debris in oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831). If no debris is found replace the oil filter.
Start the engine and ground run up to take off power, refer to the AMM. Check that engine parameters are normal.

Check for chip detector indication. Remove and inspect the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801 and Task 79-20-01-210-801) if metallic debris is found, send the engine to an overhaul facility. If no debris is found, the engine can continue in service.

At 50 +/- 5 flight hours remove and inspect the oil filter (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801 and Task 79-20-01-210-801) if debris is found, do the fault isolation chart for debris in oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-831). If no debris is found, the engine can continue in service with subsequent inspections as specified in the applicable maintenance program (Ref. Task 05-20-00-210-801)

taskproc.title: Skydrol Hydraulic Fluid in the Oil System

l1item.para: If the engine was not motored or started:

l2item.para: Flush the oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-807).
Replace all accessible preformed packings located below the max oil level mark on the sight glass.

l1item.para: If the engine was motored or started:

l2item.para: Send the engine to an overhaul facility, to do an inspection for ingestion of Skydrol hydraulic fluid.

taskproc.title: MIL-H-5606 Hydraulic Fluid in the Oil System

l1item.para: Flush the oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-807).

The operating limits section gives the takeoff power limits (Ref. Task 05-10-00-990-801). There is no CAS message in the cockpit for any exceedance of these limits. The operator is required to make sure that the engine does not exceed the takeoff power time limit by manually pulling the TLA back. If an exceedance occurs, do the following:

l2item.para: Record the occurrence in the engine logbook.
Do a power assurance test (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-813) and attach the data to the engine logbook.
The results of the power assurance test should be used to schedule an engine performance recovery wash (Ref. Task 71-00-00-160-808) or other maintenance (such as HSI, etc.).

l1item.para: If engine(s) flameout because of ingestion of deicing fluid, do a compressor wash before returning the aircraft to service (Ref. Task 71-00-00-160-807).

If engine vibration occurs during the flight and the starter/generator is found to be damaged; the vibrations caused by the damage may have also caused damage to the accessories mounted on the engine and the fuel/oil tubes found in the starter/generator area. Do the following checks:

l2item.para: Do a visual inspection of all the accessories, fuel/oil tubes for leaks, cracks, oil weeping, correct installation of attaching parts and damage.
Inspect the starter/generator mounting pad on the AGB for any damage.
Remove and replace the spline adapter (vespel).
Rotate the AGB gearshafts manually and listen for any unusual noise.
Replace the starter/generator magnetic seal.
Inspect the oil filter and chip collector/detector for unwanted material. If any unwanted material is found, send an oil sample and oil filter for analysis. Do a flush of the engine oil system.
Operate the engine at 80% N1 for 10 minutes.
Do a visual inspection for external oil or fuel leaks.

If unwanted material was found before, do an inspection of the oil filter and chip collector/detector again for unwanted material. If any unwanted material is found, contact your Pratt and Whitney Canada technical representative.

l1item.para: If the engine is operated with fuel temperature above the maximum operating temperature, as measured by the engine EEC, the following action is required:

l2item.para: Remove the FMU (Ref. Task 73-20-00-000-801) and install a replacement FMU (Ref. Task 73-20-00-400-801). The removed FMU should be returned to the manufacturer with a description of the event, including the peak and duration of the fuel temperature exceedance.

Record the peak and duration of the exceedance in the engine log book. Do a borescope inspection of the engine fuel nozzles (Ref. Task 72-00-00-290-808) within 600 flight hours of the exceedance event.

l1item.para: To ensure proper reinstallation, observe the location of each part during removal. Tag and mark all parts, clips, and brackets as to their location.
During removal of engine components, such as tubes, look for indications of scoring, burning or other indications of damage. Tag unserviceable parts and units for investigation and possible repair.

caution.para: DUST CAPS USED TO PROTECT OPEN TUBES AGAINST CONTAMINATION SHALL ALWAYS BE INSTALLED OVER AND NOT INSIDE THE TUBE ENDS . FLOW THROUGH THE LINES MAY BE BLOCKED OFF IF LINES ARE INADVERTENTLY INSTALLED WITH DUST CAPS IN THE TUBE ENDS.

l1item.para: Extreme care shall be taken to prevent dust, dirt, safety cable, lockwire, nuts, washers or other foreign matter from entering the engine. It cannot be overemphasized that this precaution applies whenever work is done on the engine either on the wing or off the wing. Suitable plugs, caps, and other covering shall be used to protect all openings as they are exposed.
If at any time items are dropped into the engine, the dropped articles must be located and retrieved immediately.
Before assembling or installing any part, be sure it is thoroughly clean.

Safety cable, lockwire, lockwashers, tablocks, tabwashers, or cotterpins must never be reused. All safety cable, lockwire and cotterpins must fit snugly in holes drilled in studs and bolts for locking purposes. Install a cotterpin so that the head fits into the castellation of the nut, and unless otherwise specified, bend one end of the pin back over the stud or bolt and the other end down flat against the nut. Only safety cable, lockwire, and cotterpins made of corrosion resistant steel are to be used. Bushing plugs shall be safety cabled or lockwired to the assembly boss or case. Do not safety cable or lockwire the plug to the bushing.
Replace all gaskets, packings, and rubber parts at reassembly. Make sure that new nonmetallic parts to be installed (such as an oil seal) show no sign of having deteriorated in storage.
Make sure that the shelf life is not expired for parts with a shelf life. Check the expiry date shown on the part packaging or associated paperwork.
To protect critical areas of engine parts (such as compressor and turbine disks) against scratches and nicks, tool surfaces contacting these areas must be covered with protective material.

During replacement of components, note condition of any removed preformed packings. Pieces accidentally torn or cut from packings must be retrieved, regardless of size, even if this entails a systematic disassembly and cleaning of the system. Ensure that new packings are free of cuts, flashings and deformities which may be sheared off at installation.
When installing engine parts that require the use of a hammer to facilitate assembly or installation, use only a plastic or rawhide hammer.

Whenever adhesive tape has been applied to any part, the tape must be removed and the part thoroughly cleaned of all tape residue with (PWC11-027)petroleum solvent before installing into engine. Test results indicate that all tapes are capable of causing surface attack and/or reduction in tensile ductility as temperature increases.
If any part has been coated with corrosion preventive compounds, all traces of this compound and accumulated foreign matter must be removed prior to installation.

Reference numbers on Fits and Clearances, for applicable chapters, indicate the location of fits, clearances, and parts for which torque and spring pressures are specified. A description of, and limits for, these fits, clearances, torque and spring pressures is located by referring to a reference number, given in the text, to the same number given in the appropriate Fits and Clearances. In locations where no specific torque limit is given in Fits and Clearances the general torque recommendations are specified.
The terms and symbols used in Fits and Clearances are explained as follows:

l2item.para: REF. DIMENSIONS Column - This column indicates the minimum and maximum manufacturing dimensions of two mating parts. These dimensions are provided for information only.

LIMITS Column - This column indicates the desired minimum and maximum fits and clearances between new parts, and also the allowable limit to which these parts may wear before replacement is necessary (Ref. NOTES ).
The symbol T indicates a tight fit. The symbol L, or no letter after a fit denotes a loose fit.
Unless otherwise specified, all fits are diametrical.
The figures in the MINIMUM, MAXIMUM and REPLACE columns shall be interpreted as follows:

l3item.para: Imperial: Torque in pound-inches, spring pressures in pounds, and all other limits in inches.
Metric: Torque in Newton-meters, spring pressures in newtons, and all other limits in millimeters.

numlitem.para: Where the replace column is left blank, the minimum or maximum limit applies, as required.
Where minimum and maximum figures are given for torque loads, they represent the intended tightening range.

l1item.para: Torque limits given in the following chapters are to be interpreted as follows:

numlitem.para: Torque values in pound-inches at room temperature.
Angles of turn in degrees.

l1item.para: Thread lubricant is (PWC03-001) engine oil unless otherwise specified.
Parts heated or cooled before assembly must be at room temperature when the final torque is applied.
Flange bolts must be torqued in diametrically opposed sequence.
Torque should be applied slowly and evenly for consistency and the best possible accuracy.
Torque check for reuse of self-locking fasteners as follows:

l2item.para: Check for adequate torque of self-locking fasteners before reuse. Discard fastener if locking capability is impaired. Do not repair self-locking fasteners.
Torque Limits

l3item.para: Self-locking nuts, self-locking bolts, and self-locking helical coil inserts must be capable of meeting torque requirements in Table .

table.title: Torque Check for Reuse of Self-Locking Nuts, Bolts and Helical Coil Inserts (Pound-inches at Room Temperature and Lubricated With Engine Oil)

entry.para: Fine Thread Mating Bolt Thread Size
Course Thread Mating Bolt Thread Size
NOTE: ** Use the listed bolt sizes for torque testing cadmium plated nuts, carbon steel nuts, alloy steel nuts, and aluminum nuts.

l4item.para: For torque testing stainless steel, corrosion and heat resistant steel, nickel alloy, and AMS6304 nuts, major, minor and pitch diameters of bolts should be reduced 0.003 inch below dimensions specified in Table .

Unplated stainless steel, corrosion resistant steel, nickel alloy, and AMS6304 steel nuts that have thread overcut for plating at assembly, shall be silver plated 0.0003 to 0.0006 inch thick for test purposes, and checked for requirements as given in Table for threaded, unplated bolts.

note.para: Where a non-standard torque value is specified, refer to fits and clearances in applicable chapter.

l3item.para: The expression FIT TO is used when an operation may be required at assembly to obtain the required fit.
An asterisk (*) in the replace column indicates that parts should be replaced if any looseness is found.
The number symbol (#) indicates that parts should be replaced when scuffing, pitting, galling or excessive wear has taken place.
Spline fits are calculated from chordal dimensions; unless otherwise specified, all other fits are diametrical.

For torque testing stainless steel, corrosion and heat resistant steel, nickel alloy, and AMS6304 nuts, major, minor and pitch diameters of bolts should be reduced 0.003 inch below dimensions specified for listed 0.190-32 UNF-3A, 0.190-24 UNC-3A and larger bolt sizes (Ref. Table .

l2item.para: Unplated Nuts

l3item.para: Unplated stainless steel, corrosion resistant steel, nickel alloy, and AMS6304 steel nuts that have threads overcut for plating at assembly, shall be silver plated 0.0003 to 0.0006 inch thick for test purposes, and checked for requirements as given in Table for threaded unplated bolts.

note.para: Where a non-standard torque value is specified, refer to fits and clearances in applicable chapter.

l1item.para: Check torque indicating devices before using, and calibrate by means of weights and a measured lever arm to make sure that there are no inaccuracies. Checking one torque wrench against another is not sufficient. Some wrenches are quite sensitive to the way they are supported during a tightening operation, and every effort must be made to adhere to the instructions furnished by the respective manufacturers.
When using a special extension, or adapter wrench together with a standard torque wrench (Ref. Fig. . In order to arrive at the resultant required torque limits, the following formula must be used:

unlitem.para: T - Desired torque on the part.
E - Effective length of special extension or adapter.
L - Effective length of torque wrench.
A - Distance through which force is applied to part.
R - Reading on scale or dial of torque wrench.

para.equ:
R =
LT
A
=
LT
L + E

unlitem.para: A torque of 1440 lb.in. (162.7 Nm) is desired on a part, using special extension having a length of three inches (76.2 mm) from center to center of its holes, and a torque wrench measuring 15 inches (381 mm) from center of handle or handle swivel pin to center of its square adapter. Then:

With the axis of the extension or adapter and the torque wrench in a straight line, tightening to a wrench reading of 1200 lb.in. (135.6 Nm) will provide the desired torque of 1440 lb.in. (162.7 Nm) on the part.

l1item.para: All nut, bolt and screw torques should be obtained using a thread lubricant. The lubricant should be engine oil, unless otherwise specified. Torque requirements for interference fit application, such as studs and pipe plugs, may be obtained with or without lubrication, unless otherwise specified.

caution.para: ENSURE THAT ANTISEIZE AND ANTIGALLING COMPOUNDS ARE APPLIED IN A THIN EVEN COAT, AND THAT EXCESS COMPOUND IS COMPLETELY REMOVED TO AVOID CONTAMINATION OF ADJACENT PARTS, PASSAGES OR SURFACES WHERE THE COMPOUND MAY CAUSE MALFUNCTIONING, OR EVEN FAILURE, OF ENGINE.

l1item.para: (PWC06-001)Lubricating compound should be applied to all loose-fit spline drives which are external to the engine and have no other means of lubrication. For certain assembly procedures molybdenum disulfide in either paste form (Type G) (PWC06-004)anti-seize compound or powdered form (Type Z) (PWC06-004A) anti-seize compound mixed with (PWC03-001)engine oil or ( PWC04-001)grease may be used. Particular applications of molybdenum disulfide are indicated in the individual text portions of this manual, as applicable.
Bolts and nuts on flanges with metal tabular gaskets must be initially torqued to the required torque and then retorqued until torque values given in relevant assembly instruction remain constant.

The torque values given within text apply to nuts where the height of the nut is approximately equal to the major diameter of the thread. For jam nuts, refer to REMOVAL/INSTALLATION. Values do not apply to hollow bolts and screws.
Where self-locking nuts and helical coil inserts are used, the following procedure applies:

l2item.para: The locking torque for self-locking nuts and helical coil inserts must be checked at assembly. The locking torque must not be less than the values shown in Table unless otherwise specified.
When checking self-locking torque, care must be taken to ensure the fastener is not seated. This ensures that only the torque necessary to overcome the friction holding the thread is measured.

table.title: Locking Torque for Self-locking Nuts and Helical Coil Inserts

l1item.para: When tightening a castellated nut, alignment of slot must be obtained without exceeding the maximum torque. If this is not possible, replace nut with another one. After tightening nut to recommended torque, nut must not be loosened to permit insertion of safetywire or cotterpin. If slot in nut or safetywire hole in bolt or screw is not correctly aligned at the minimum torque value given, the nut, screw or bolt should be further tightened to next alignment position, but maximum torque value given must not be exceeded. Should alignment still be impossible without exceeding maximum torque, back off nut, screw or bolt one-half turn and retorque.

Effective locking of slotted, steel locknuts on bolts or studs requires full engagement of all locknut threads. The chamfered section of the locknut ID does not exert force on the bolt or stud; therefore, it is not necessary that the bolt or stud be flush with, or protrude from, the outer face of the locknut.
When the torque required to drive a stud to the correct protrusion does not reach the minimum value given, or exceeds the maximum value given, a new stud must be selected.
If leakage occurs at a coupling, do not attempt to correct by overtorquing. Disassemble fitting and check for nicks, burrs and/or foreign matter. Use new parts to rectify.

caution.para: KEYWASHERS ARE TO BE USED ONLY ONCE. NEW KEYWASHER(S) MUST BE INSTALLED AT EACH ASSEMBLY.
DO NOT USE SHARP EDGED TOOLS TO BEND OR SET KEYWASHER TABS. TAB DETACHMENT MAY OCCUR WITH SUBSEQUENT DAMAGE TO ENGINE.

l1item.para: Pre-Assembly Requirements for Cupwashers:

l2item.para: Visually inspect cupwasher for freedom from deep drawing score marks (especially in undercut adjacent to tangs) and for freedom from prior assembly/handling damage, i.e. bent tangs or prior stake marks.
Visually inspect contact surfaces for excessive roughness, burrs, or scores that may cause the washer to bend on the nut.
Visually inspect the nut for burrs, nicks or scratches on face which abuts the cupwasher that could cause the nut to pick up on the washer.

l1item.para: Assembly Requirements for Cupwashers:

l2item.para: The cupwasher must be lubricated on the nut side only, the opposite face must be clean and dry.
With cupwasher placed against shaft slots opposite to direction of nut tightening, screw nut fingertight.
With a silver pencil, make an alignment mark on cupwasher outside diameter and the component immediately adjacent to cupwasher.
Torque the nut in the normal manner.
If alignment mark has moved, remove and discard cupwasher.
Repeat procedure with new cupwasher.
Stake cupwasher.

caution.para: THOROUGHLY INSPECT ALL RETAINING RINGS, INCLUDING SPIROLOX, FOR CONDITION. DISTORTED RINGS ARE NOT ACCEPTABLE AND MUST BE REPLACED.

l1item.para: Retaining rings must be installed using approved retaining ring pliers. Internal type rings must not be compressed beyond the point where the ends of the ring meet. External type rings must be expanded just enough to allow installation without becoming bent. After installation, ensure that each ring is completely seated, without looseness or distortion in its groove.
General

l2item.para: Safety cable is installed through two or more parts in such a way that as the fastener loosens the safety cable will tighten. By tightening, the safety cable will not permit the fastener to loosen or turn. The safety cable system is made up of two components: the ( PWC05-344)safety cable/ferrule kit and a (PWC90025)crimping tool (Ref. Fig. .

The safety cable is available in one size, 0.32 inch (0.81 mm), and is made of stainless steel material. One end of the cable will have a cable end fitting swaged to it. The cable end fitting is made of stainless steel material. The strands of the cable on the opposite end of the cable are fused together to prevent the cable from fraying.

The ferrules are made of stainless steel material and are purchased in a spring-loaded, disposable cartridge. When the safety cable is installed the ferrule will be crimped on the open end of the cable.

The hand-operated crimping tool comes in two different lengths. The crimping pressure of the tool is set by the manufacturer. The primary parts of the crimping tool are the nose assembly and the tool body. This tool is used to crimp the ferrule on the end of the safety cable. The crimping tool will cut the safety cable even with the ferrule at the same time the ferrule is crimped.

l1item.para: Safety Cable Substitution: Where safety cable is specified, it may be replaced with safety wire. Use safety wire as specified in Table .

entry.para: NOTE: Safety wire AS3214 may be used in engine external applications only.

l1item.para: Basic Installation Rules:

l2item.para: It is not permissible to re-use safety cable or a ferrule. The safety cable and ferrule must be new for every application.

Unless specified differently in assembly procedure, safety cable should be installed in double- or triple-bolt patterns. The double-bolt pattern is preferred when you apply safety cable to an even number of fasteners (Ref. Fig. .
The maximum allowable span of safety cable between two end points is 6 inches (152.4 mm), unless otherwise specified.
Any defects (such as fray, nicks, kink or any damage to the safety cable) to any portion of the safety cable prior to, during or after installation is not permitted.

caution.para: DO NOT USE SAFETY CABLE IF THE HOLES ARE MORE THAN 0.100 INCH (2.54 mm) DIAMETER. THE FERRULES ON THE END OF THE CABLE ARE 0.106 - 0.108 INCH (2.69 - 2.74 mm) DIAMETER AND WILL FALL THROUGH HOLES LARGER THAN THIS.

l2item.para: Always install safety cable through the safety cable holes provided on the fastener.
Do not decrease or increase the torque on the parts to correctly align the holes for the cable.
Install safety cable so that any tendency for a fastener to loosen is counteracted by more tension on the cable.
It is recommended that there be no sharp turns more than 90 when the cable is passed through a fastener. Installation of safety cable should be with either a positive or neutral pull.
Cable flex limits are specified in Figure These values are the maximum flex limits between the end points when light finger pressure of approximately 2 pound (8.9 N) is applied at midspan.
Excess Cable:

l3item.para: Cut off excess cable from crimped ferrule after installation of safety cable.
Maximum length of cable beyond crimped ferrule is 0.031 inch (0.787 mm).

l2item.para: Safety Cable Seal:

l3item.para: Where specified, apply and crimp an aluminum seal to the load bearing portion of the safety cable.
After installing the seal, make sure that it is snug on the cable and that it can not be moved without showing evidence of tampering.
After installing the seal, an inspection stamp or other means of identification shall be applied to the seal.

l1item.para: Installation (Ref. Fig.

l2item.para: Install ferrule cartridge into (PWC90025) crimper tool body.
Do a visual inspection of the holes to be used to find all damage. If the hole is damaged, replace the part or, if possible, use another hole to install safety cable.

note.para: Keep the safety cable as straight as possible when you locking the fasteners or parts together.

l2item.para: Insert the free end of the (PWC05-344) safety cable into the hole of the part. Pull the cable through the hole until the cable end fitting is against the part.

note.para: On a double-bolt pattern, do not safety cable in a negative pull direction. Make sure the safety cable has a positive or neutral pull.

l2item.para: Insert the end of the cable through the second part. Choose the hole in the part that permits the cable to be as straight as possible. Pull the cable through the second part. If three parts must be safety cabled, do the same procedure for the third part.

The nose can be changed to four different positions at 90 increments. To select the position, push the nose in towards the tool, rotate to the desired position, and release the nose. If the nose does not lock into the indexed position, turn it slightly until it does (Ref. Fig. .
Insert the free end of the (PWC05-344) safety cable through a ferrule . Use the safety cable to pull the ferrule out of the ferrule cartridge.

Put the end of the safety cable through the crimping head of the crimping tool. Make sure the large hole in the crimping head is on the same side as the ferrule. Move the crimping tool along the safety cable until the crimping head is against the part. Make sure the ferrule goes inside the hole in the crimping head.

Insert the free end of the cable into the cable entrance. Continue to push the cable into the cavity. When the free end of the cable appears at the bottom of the tool, grab the cable and pull the slack from the cable until resistance is felt.

note.para: Grip the cable as close to the free end as possible during insertion to prevent buckling of the cable.

l2item.para: When all slack is removed from the cable, make sure the tool is snugly against the fastener by using several short strokes of the handle. Release the handle to the full open position and fully close the handle to affect crimping and cutting.

caution.para: IT IS IMPORTANT ON THIS FINAL STROKE TO HOLD THE TOOL AS STEADY AND PERPENDICULAR TO THE CABLE AS POSSIBLE WHILE ENSURING THAT A FULL STROKE IS USED TO MAINTAIN A CONSISTENT TENSIONING OF THE CABLE.

l2item.para: After crimping and cutting, release the tool handle and slide the tool off the crimped ferrule. Pull the excess cable from the tool.
Remove and discard unused safety cable from the bottom of the crimping tool.

l1item.para: Verification (Ref. Fig.

l2item.para: Push against the safety cable with light finger pressure halfway between the locked parts. If the cable feels loose, do a dimensional check to make sure the safety cable is serviceable as follows:

l3item.para: Measure the distance between the locked parts. Write this measurement down as Dimension A. If three parts are locked together, measure the distance between each of the parts and add the two measurements together to get Dimension A.
Push against the safety cable with light finger pressure halfway between the two locked parts. Measure the distance the safety cable moves laterally. Writes this measurement down as Dimension C.
Compare the dimensions written down to the limits given.

caution.para: DO NOT TRY TO BREAK THE SAFETY CABLE. IF THE SAFETY CABLE MUST BE REMOVED, CUT THE SAFETY CABLE TO AVOID DAMAGE TO THE HOLES OF THE PART.

l2item.para: If the safety cable is not within limits, cut the safety cable with wire cutters and remove the safety cable. Install new safety cable.
Check that cable was installed through bolts correctly (Ref. Para. 6.C. step (6)).
Verify that cable was cut flush at the end of the ferrule with no strand extending more than 1/32 inch from the end of the ferrule.
Visually inspect safety cable for kinks, frayed wires, or improper crimps. Remove and replace safety cable if problem exists.

l1item.para: Indenter Adjustment (Ref. Fig.

l2item.para: Remove the nose assembly by removing the two socket head cap screws.

caution.para: DO NOT ADJUST THE PUSHROD MORE THAN A QUARTER OF A TURN AT A TIME. SEVERE ADJUSTMENTS MAY DAMAGE THE TOOL.

l2item.para: Adjust the pushrod adjustment screw using a 0.25 inch (6.4 mm) straight edge screw driver. Turn the pushrod adjustment screw clockwise to loosen the crimp (enlarge the gaging dimension). Turn the adjustment screw counter-clockwise to tighten the crimp (reduce gaging dimension).
Replace the nose assembly and the two socket head cap screws. Turn each screw a small amount until tight to prevent binding.

caution.para: TIGHTENING THE CRIMP INCREASES REQUIRED HAND FORCES DURING APPLICATION AND INCREASES CABLE ASSEMBLY TENSILE VALUES. LOOSENING THE CRIMP DECREASES REQUIRED HAND FORCES DURING APPLICATION AND DECREASES CABLE ASSEMBLY TENSILE VALUES

l2item.para: Check calibration as described in (Ref. Para. 6.C. step (7)).

l1item.para: Indenter Calibration (Ref. Fig.

note.para: Indenter calibration should be checked periodically and must be checked after the nose assembly has been removed or interchanged.
Do a pull-off load test as often as necessary to make sure the crimp done by the crimping tool meets the necessary requirements.

l2item.para: Set up (PWC90026)test block.

Thread the cable into the 12 point screw and through the swivel, holding the lever in the home position. If the lever is not kept in the home position the results may be adversely affected. Cut the cable by making sure to close the handles completely.

Apply approximately 2 lbs. force to the cable with your finger at the line marked test area. If the cable touches either the side or bottom surface of the test area then remove the cable from the test block and use another cable as described in Para. 6.C. step (7)(b).

Place a 3/8 inch drive torque wrench into the square drive hole, orientating the test block and torque wrench on a flat surface. Apply the proper pull-off load as shown in Table . Release torque when minimum pull-off load is achieved.

note.para: Do not apply additional tension to safety cable than that is required to achieve minimum pull-off load.

l2item.para: If the cable did not break or pull out of the ferrule after applying proper torque, remove the torque wrench and apply approximately 2 lbs. force to the cable with your finger at the line marked test area.

If the cable breaks, touches either the side or bottom surface of the test area or pulls out of the ferrule, then the crimp is unacceptable and the tool indenter should be adjusted (Ref. Para. 6.C. step (6)).

table.title: Safety Cable Minimum Crimp Requirements (Pull-off Load)

l1item.para: Maintenance of Crimp Cavity:

l2item.para: Debris can accumulate in the crimp cavity during use. This debris must be removed and the cavity oiled periodically depending upon use and environment.

note.para: Ferrule sticking can occur if this procedure is not followed.

l2item.para: Remove debris by gently scraping or brushing the crimp cavity.
Blow any remaining debris from the cavity with air.
Coat the cavity with a light film of any lightweight synthetic or petroleum based oil after the cavity has been thoroughly cleaned.

l1item.para: Except where otherwise specified, the wire is heat and corrosion resistant steel wire of 0.025 inch diameter (PWC05-089)lockwire.
Basic Rules

l2item.para: Lockwire must be tight after installation to prevent failure due to rubbing or vibration.
Lockwire must be installed in a manner that tends to tighten and keep a part locked in place thus counteracting the natural tendency of the part to loosen.
Lockwire must never be overstressed. It will break under vibrations if twisted too tightly. The lockwire shall be pulled taut when being twisted, but shall have minimum tension, if any when secured.
Lockwire ends must be bent toward the engine, or part, to avoid sharp or projecting ends which might present a safety hazard or vibrate in the air stream.
Internal wiring must not cross over or obstruct a flow passage when an alternate method can be used.

l1item.para: Lockwire Hole Alignment

l2item.para: Check the units to be lockwired to make sure they have been correctly torqued and that the wiring holes are properly positioned in relation to each other. When there are two or more units, it is desirable that the holes in the units be in the same relationship to each other. Never overtorque or loosen units to obtain proper alignment of the holes. It should be possible to align the wiring holes when the units are torqued within the specified limits. However, if it is impossible to obtain a proper alignment of the holes without either over or under torquing, select another unit which will permit proper alignment within the specified torque limits.

l1item.para: Lockwire Twisting

l2item.para: To prevent mutilations of the twisted section of the wire when using pliers, grasp the wire at the ends or at a point that will not be twisted. lockwire must not be nicked, kinked, or mutilated. Never twist the wire ends off with the pliers and when cutting off ends, leave at least three complete turns after the loop, exercising extreme care to prevent the wire ends from falling into the engine. The strength of the lockwire holes is marginal; never twist the wire off with pliers. Cut the lockwire close to the hole, exercising extreme care.

l1item.para: Lockwire Illustrations

l2item.para: Figure illustrates a typical lockwiring procedure. Although there are numerous lockwiring operations performed on these engines, practically all are derived from the basic examples shown in Figure .

task.title: Identification of Hardware Material, Particularly Nuts and Bolts

l1item.para: A permanent type of material code designation has been adopted for use in these engines. Correct engine reassembly procedures require that particular attention be paid to the material requirements for nuts and bolts used in the hot section of the engine. In these areas, where parts must be of material which is resistant to high operating temperatures, special heat resistant alloys are employed. It is imperative that at reassembly of the engine or its components the properly coded part be reassembled in its original location, if serviceable.

The code system employs the use of a letter C for corrosion resistant steel for normal application and H for heat resistant alloys in hot section application. The stamped or embossed letter will be followed by a number of one or more digits, such as C1, C8, H3, and H12. Bolt code identification will usually appear on the top of the head and nut identification on one side of the hex (Ref. Fig. . When the application is an AN or MS six digit part number, the code identification C or H will be preceded by the letter E as in EC3 or EH10.

note.para: All AN or MS six digit part numbers, when manufactured of material in the common temperature range (such as cadmium plated, low alloy steel parts), are also coded E to indicate, in part, close material quality control.

l1item.para: The adoption of this program will make it possible for service activities to avoid the assembly of parts, with similar physical appearance, in locations which require high heat resistant parts. In this regard, it is required, at time of disassembly (removal), that all similarly coded parts be segregated so that two, or more, physically similar parts with different code numbers will not be scrambled; and so that, at subsequent reassembly (installation), the properly coded parts are replaced in their proper locations.

caution.para: NEVER ASSEMBLE A MATERIAL CODED PART WITH A C IDENTIFICATION IN A LOCATION WHICH REQUIRES AN H CODED PART AND VICE-VERSA. NEVER USE CADMIUM PLATED NUTS, BOLTS OR ANY OTHER CADMIUM PLATED PART IN THE HOT SECTION OF THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: Parts from several engines should not be scrambled at disassembly (removal) and cleaning, because, at the time of engine manufacture, production requirements may necessitate one or more material substitutions in a block of engines. Subsequent engine reassembly with indiscriminate scrambling of hardware, may result in unnecessary confusion in sorting these parts for proper reassembly.

caution.para: IT IS IMPORTANT THAT J THREADED HARDWARE BE CAREFULLY SEGREGATED AND MARKED AT DISASSEMBLY (REMOVAL) TO PREVENT MIXING OF J THREADED PARTS WITH NON J THREADED PARTS.

l1item.para: Unified Controlled Radius Root J Threaded Bolts feature full root radius for external threads with increased minor internal threaded diameter. J threads ensure greater fatigue life, improved stress relaxation characteristics and show improvement in tensile strength over previous designs. This thread form is used extensively throughout engines. Engine bolts having J threads appear just like items threaded with conventional threads.

task.title: Stainless Steel Bolts with Reduced Pitch Diameters

l1item.para: At engine manufacture, it is the practice to provide bolts with reduced pitch diameter for use in the hot sections of engines. This will minimize the possibility of bolt and nut seizure and is standard practice for locations where the parts are subjected to elevated temperatures (Ref. Fig. .
Submit particle to an approved P&WC laboratory for analysis.

Marking of engine parts, assemblies, or weldments shall be applied so as to ensure maximum legibility and durability of mark but in a manner that will not affect function or serviceability of part. Only applicable Pratt & Whitney Canada marking methods shall be used.
Except where otherwise specified, reidentification of parts shall be accomplished adjacent to, or in a location similar to that of, original marking.

All marking characters, unless otherwise specified, shall be 0.060 to 1.160 inch (1.52 - 4.06 mm) high. In special cases, when marking area is governed by size or configuration of part, characters not less than 0.016 (0.041mm) inch nor more than 0.250 inch (6.35mm) in height are permitted.

Electric-arc scribing, particularly hand arc scribing, whereby characters are produced by action of an electric arc between surface and an electrode (scriber), has been found unsuitable for jet engine parts and must not be used.
Acid etching, whereby characters are formed by action of an acid on surface of part, is not recommended because of its possible corrosive effect.
Do not use Soapstone to mark engine parts.
General

l2item.para: Marking should be done as close to original marking as possible. Permanent methods of marking are those in which marking is legible during entire service life of part.
Permanent markings shall not extend onto any radius, chamfer, sharp edge, or fillet adjoining designated marking surface.

l1item.para: Applied Marking Methods

caution.para: DO NOT ELECTROLYTICALLY ETCH ANODIZED SURFACES.

l2item.para: Electrolytic Etch - Characters are produced by electrolysis confined to area of characters by a stencil. This technique is sometimes used as a temporary method. Do not confuse it with electric-arc scribing.
Vibration Peening - Characters are produced by a vibrating, radius-tipped, conical tool.
