Normal TO-4%,
Normal TO-2%
Normal TO

l1item.para: Do the engine shutdown procedure after the ground calibration run has been completed (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-811).
Convert observed N1, N2 and ITT data to corrected data as follows (Ref. Table):

note.para: The values in Table are conversion factors created for convenient computation of corrected ITT.

l2item.para: Example:
Sample calculation:

l1item.para: Record the corrected N1, N2 and ITT values on the Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet (Ref. Fig.).
Plot the corrected data as follows using the values recorded on the Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet (Ref. Fig.):

l2item.para: Refer to the copies of the Engine Calibration and Performance Check Curve charts (Ref. Fig. and Fig.).
Plot the corrected N1 vs corrected N2 values on the MAXIMUM CORRECTED N2 CHART, (Ref. Fig.).
Plot the corrected N1 vs corrected ITT values on the MAXIMUM CORRECTED ITT chart (Ref.Fig.).

note.para: If it is not possible to plot the final N1 conditions on the plot axes provided due to high or low ambient temperatures, use the remaining usable conditions only.

l1item.para: If excessive scatter is apparent after the data has been plotted, check conversion calculations. If no errors, repeat the ground run at the applicable engine power setting(s).

Performance points plotted on Figure and Figure are for comparison purposes with data from the same engine taken at different flight hour times. Review of the data over a period of time can allow determination of deterioration or unresolved issues with the installation. Contact the P&WC Customer Support Help Desk for further assistance (Ref. INTRODUCTION).

table.title: Ambient Temperature Correction Factors for Specified Temperatures

l1item.para: Keep the completed Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet and the plotted Engine Calibration and Performance Check Curves with the engine logbook for future reference.
Do the Power Assurance Check, if required (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-813).
This task gives the procedure for doing the engine Power Assurance Check.

A performance check is to be done after completion of work on gas path components as required by Major Component Repair/Replacement (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-804), or the engine performance deterioration fault isolation procedure. Record the required, observed and calculated parameters on the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, (Ref. Fig.).

note.para: The power assurance test will determine if an engine will develop take-off power within N2 and ITT limits up to the maximum Tamb and altitude for which the engine is certified. Operators should use this information to schedule engine maintenance activity.
To make sure the engine can supply the necessary power, margins must not have negative values.

caution.para: DO NOT PERFORM THE POWER ASSURANCE TEST IN HIGH WIND OR MODERATE TO HEAVY RAIN, SNOW OR FOG CONDITIONS.

note.para: Engine performance is greatly affected by local atmospheric conditions.

l1item.para: Make a copy of the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, Figure to use during the ground run.
Make sure the instrumentation is functioning correctly and has been accurately calibrated per the applicable AMM.
Position the aircraft into the wind and away from the influence of buildings or other obstacles and ensure the wind speed is less than 25 knots with N1 fluctuation remaining below 0.5%.
Do the engine prestart procedure (Task 71-00-00-760-809).
Obtain the local ambient temperature (Tamb) in C from the airport tower.
Obtain the local pressure altitude in feet from the aircraft cockpit instruments (Refer to the AMM) or from the airport tower.
Record the local tamb and pressure altitude values on the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, Figure.
Record the ITT trim and N1 trim values stamped on the engine trim data plate (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-802) onto the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, Figure.

Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-812 Check No. 4 - Engine Calibration (Five Point Calibration) Figure, Power Assurance Test Chart - N1 vs Ambient Temperature to obtain the target N1% at TO power with all bleeds off for the tamb and pressure altitude recorded during the Power Assurance Check. Record the target N1 value on the Power Assurance Test Data Sheet, Figure.
Do the engine start procedure (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810).

note.para: Do not open any of the bleeds.

l1item.para: Check for EEC fault indications (Refer to the AMM). Record fault codes on a copy of EEC Fault Code Data Sheet, Figure). To review the EEC Fault Codes (Ref. Task 72-00-02-810-801).
Make sure all accessory loads are OFF.

caution.para: DO NOT EXCEED MAXIMUM VALUES OF N2 AND ITT. IF EITHER MAXIMUM VALUE IS EXCEEDED, (REF. Task 72-00-01-810-801) FOR CORRECTIVE ACTION. FOLLOWING RECTIFICATION, REPEAT THE POWER ASSURANCE CHECK.

l1item.para: Advance the thrust lever to the TO detent. Allow the engine rpm to stabilize for a recommended minimum of three minutes. Check that the engine N1 value is within 0.5% of previously recorded target N1 value.
Record the following operating parameter values:

numlitem.para: N1
N2
ITT
Tamb
PA

note.para: The Tamb and Pamb values recorded during the Job Setup may have changed.

l2item.para: Plot the recorded ITT value on the Power Assurance Test Chart - ITT vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig.) at the recorded Tamb and PA values.
Plot the recorded N2 value on the Power Assurance Test Chart - N2 vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig. ) at the recorded Tamb and PA values.
Check and record the ITT and N2 margins, i.e. the difference between the maximum N2 and ITT for the values at the recorded Tamb, PA , N2 and ITT values.

note.para: Interpolation might be required to determine maximum N2 and ITT if the airport altitude is between the lines on the power assurance charts.

l1item.para: If desired, do the engine shutdown procedure (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-811).
If the recorded N2 and/or ITT values are close to or at the limits Engine Performance Deterioration (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-801).

graphic.title: Power Assurance Test Chart - N2 vs Ambient Temperature
Power Assurance Test Chart - ITT vs Ambient Temperature

l1item.para: Determine target N1:

l2item.para: Enter Power Assurance Test Chart - N1 vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig. ) at Tamb of 21C, and PA of 500 ft.
Target N1 is 91.8%.

l1item.para: Sample engine recorded parameters at T/O power with all bleeds OFF:

l2item.para: At Tamb 21C and PA 500 ft.
N1 is 91.5% which is within 0.5% of target N1 (91.8%).
Recorded ITT is 775C.
Recorded N2 is 98.2%.

l1item.para: Calculate the difference () between maximum N2 and ITT, and recorded N2 and ITT:

l2item.para: Enter Power Assurance Test Chart - N2 vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig.) at Tamb 21C and PA 500 ft.
Max. N2 is 99.2%.
The difference (N2) is maximum N2 minus recorded N2 99.2% - 98.2% = 1%

note.para: The 1% value is the available N2 margin to the engine limit.

l2item.para: Enter Power Assurance Test Chart - ITT vs Ambient Temperature (Ref. Fig.) at Tamb 21C and PA 500 ft.
Max. ITT is 787C.
The difference (ITT) = (maximum ITT) - (recorded ITT) 787C - 775C = 12C.

note.para: The 12C value is the available ITT margin to the engine limit.

l1item.para: Keep the completed Engine Calibration Run Data Sheet and the plotted Engine Calibration and Performance Check Curves with the engine logbook for future reference.
This task gives the procedure for checking the engine main oil pressure (MOP).
Not applicable.
Do the prestart checks (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-809).
Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810).
Position the aircraft into the wind.
Operate the engine at GROUND IDLE speed for two minutes minimum and allow engine oil temperature to stabilize.
Advance the power lever to achieve target TAKEOFF power. Record MOP and MOT when stabilized. Do not exceed three minutes at TAKEOFF power.
Move the power lever to achieve GROUND IDLE speed and allow the engine to stabilize for two minutes.
Shut the engine down (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-811).
The recorded MOP value must be within the limits shown on Figure :

l2item.para: If recorded MOP is within Figure limits, no further action is required.
If recorded MOP is not within Figure limits, the cold start valve can be adjusted per engine main oil pressure (MOP) adjustment (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-815.

graphic.title: Engine Main Oil Pressure Setting Graph

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for adjusting the engine main oil pressure.
Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

caution.para: DO NOT ADJUST OIL PRESSURE TO COMPENSATE FOR UNRESOLVED OIL SYSTEM PROBLEMS (REF. Task 72-00-01-810-801). THIS COULD CAUSE MOP TO BE OUT OF SPECIFIED LIMITS AND CAUSE DAMAGE TO OIL SYSTEM COMPONENTS.

l1item.para: Loosen the two bolts (1) so that the flange (3) can be lifted off the cover (4).

note.para: It is not necessary to remove the flange (3) to do the MOP adjustment.

l1item.para: Turn the hexagonal nut on the cover (4) clockwise CW to increase the engine oil pressure or counter-clockwise CCW to decrease the engine oil pressure.

note.para: The cover (4) has 24 tangs (2), partially visible through the slots in the flange (3). A rotation of one tang changes the engine oil pressure by approximately 3.6 psi.

l1item.para: If a new cold start valve was installed, make sure that the nominal setting procedure was done (Ref. Task 79-20-05-400-801.
Engage the slots in the flange (3) with the tangs (2) of the cover (4) at the desired MOP setting.
Torque the two bolts (1) to 36 to 40 lb.in. to secure the flange to the oil pump.
Do the Engine MOP Check to confirm that MOP is within the limits shown on Figure (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-814).

task.title: Engine N1 and ITT Trim Adjustment

l1item.para: This task is used to adjust engine N1 and ITT trims, utilization information and engine serial number.

caution.para: REPLACING BOTH THE EEC AND THE DCU AT THE SAME TIME FOR ANY REASON, WILL REQUIRE A SPECIAL INITIALIZATION PROCEDURE TO BE PERFORMED. PRIOR TO PERFORMING THIS TASK, CONTACT P&WC TO PERFORM THE PROCEDURE.

REPLACING THE EEC OR THE DCU WILL RESULT IN AN AUTOMATIC SYNCHRONIZATION OF ENGINE TRIMS. EXCHANGING A DCU FROM ONE ENGINE TO ANOTHER WILL CAUSE THE INCORRECT TRIMS TO BE LOADED ON THE ENGINE. IF THIS OCCURS, INITIALIZE AS DESCRIBED IN THIS TASK.

l1item.para: This procedure may be used:

l2item.para: If the DCU is replaced with a new DCU.
After a shop visit (new, unscheduled or overhaul) to update the usage information.
When the engine is installed on the aircraft.

numlitem.para: When an EEC is replaced, the EEC will automatically update its own trims and operational data from the DCU.
When the DCU is replaced with a new unit, the EEC will automatically initialize the DCU.

l1item.para: If replacing both the EEC and the DCU at the same time, a special procedure is required prior to performing this procedure. Contact P&WC to perform the procedure.
There are two methods available to complete this procedure:

l2item.para: Method 1, using a (PWC40549) DCU Cable with External Power. This method may be used when the DCU is on a bench, or the if the engine is on a build stand. The power supply for the DCU is built into the ( PWC40549)DCU Cable with External Power .

Method 2, using (3074497) DPHM Kit . This method may be used when the DCU is installed on an engine, and the engine is installed on an aircraft. The power supply for the DCU comes from the aircraft via the FADEC and engine harness when using the (3074497) DPHM Kit .

l1item.para: Install a new DCU. Refer to Task 77-40-01-400-801.
Make sure the aircraft system and engine EEC are powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Make sure the aircraft has ON GROUND status.
Make sure the engine has been shut down and is not operating.

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

caution.para: MAKE SURE THAT BOTH ENGINES HAVE BEEN SHUT DOWN AND ARE NOT OPERATING.

l1item.para: METHOD 1 (Using (PWC40549) cable:

l2item.para: Remove the DCU from the engine. Refer to Task 77-40-01-000-801.
Connect (PWC40549)cable to the DCU, to a commercial AC wall outlet and to a laptop.
Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181), from the Windows desktop.
Select engine model PW617.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select TRIM/UPLOAD.
Enter the data from the source indicated, into the column marked New Val as shown in Tables and .
After the values are entered, click the WRITE button to send the data to the DCU. Confirm that the Current Val. column now shows the correct data.
Disconnect (PWC40549)cable from the DCU, the commercial AC wall outlet and from the laptop.
Install the DCU on the engine. Refer to Task 77-40-01-400-801.
Do an Engine Trim Verification Check. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-817.

l1item.para: METHOD 2 (Using (3074497) DPHM Kit :

l2item.para: Loosen and remove the engine wiring harness P36 connector from the DCU using the (PWC90012)pliers.
Connect the (3074497)DPHM Kit cable to the DCU, to engine wiring harness P36 connector and to a laptop computer per instructions provided with the kit.
Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.
Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181), from the Windows desktop.
Select engine model PW617.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select TRIM/UPLOAD.
Enter the data from the source indicated, into the column marked New Val as shown in Tables and .
After the values are entered, click the WRITE button to send the data to the DCU. Confirm that the Current Val. column now shows the correct data.
De-energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.
Disconnect the (3074497)DPHM Kit cable from the DCU, from the engine wiring harness P36 connector and from the laptop computer.
Connect the engine wiring harness P36 connector to the DCU electrical connector. Refer to Task 73-20-02-400-801 or to Task 73-20-02-400-803.
Do an Engine Trim Verification Check. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-817.

entry.para: NOTE: The engine serial number should be entered using CAPITAL LETTERS. If capital letters are not entered, the engine will not issue a fault, but the aircraft data system will not correctly save the engine data to it's flash card system.

note.para: The FADEC calculates these values automatically. If these records disagree with the Engine Logbook, the Logbook shall take precedence.

l1item.para: This task is to verify the N1 and ITT engine trims after engine replacement, EEC replacement and/or DCU replacement.
There are two methods available:

l2item.para: Verify trims using the engine maintenance page on the aircraft primary flight display, (Refer to the AMM). No tools are required.
Verify trims using PWC ground based software (Ref. Introduction).

l1item.para: Aircraft must be "ON GROUND" status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

l1item.para: METHOD 1: Do the Engine Trim Verification using the aircraft avionics. Refer to the AMM for procedure.

note.para: Engine trims are available on the Aircraft Avionics ENGINE MAINTENANCE PAGE.

l1item.para: METHOD 2: Do the Engine Trim Verification using the Ground Based Software (part of DPHM Kit P/N 3074497).
This task describes how to download the engine DCU data which can be used for remote analysis by maintenance personnel, advanced diagnostics or to download ECTM data as a backup to the primary.
To download the engine DCU data, get access to the engine compartment and connection directly to the DCU.
If the DCU is unserviceable and cannot be interrogated, then the EEC may be interrogated (Ref Task 71-00-00-760-819).
Aircraft must be "ON GROUND" status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostic, and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

note.para: Do this task if setting up the Ground Based Software (GBSLite) for the first time or if setting up on a new laptop computer.
It is recommended, but not mandatory, to have a dedicated laptop for the engine maintenance.

l1item.para: Administration rights are required for the installation.
For Post-SB66034R1, DPHM 2.0.4 (GBSLite version 4.02) or higher is required.
Install DPHM Suite, as follows:

l2item.para: Put the CD in the laptop. If the DPHM Suite Installer screen opens, continue to step (d). If the screen does not automatically open to install the software, continue to step (b).
Double-click on the CD drive in My Computer. If the DPHM Suite Installer screen opens, continue to step (d). If the screen does not automatically open to install the software, continue to step (c).
Double-click on DPHMInstaller.exe from the CD contents. Continue to step (d).
Make sure that the components that are required to be installed are selected.
Select the Install button.
Follow the on-screen instructions.

l1item.para: If the DPHM kit includes (PWC73009) adapter, install the drivers. Refer to the GBSLite help manual. The help manual is available by opening GBSLite and selecting the Help button. The instructions for installation are in section USB-Serial Port Adapter Setup Instructions.

note.para: The USB connector must always be plugged to the same USB port on the laptop where it was originally installed. It is advisable to label the USB port on the laptop.

l1item.para: It is recommended, but not mandatory, that the computers anti-virus and wireless network adapter be disabled when using GBS software.

taskproc.title: Engine DCU Download via Aircraft GSE Connector (Pre-SB66034 Only)

l1item.para: Connect download (PWC69810) cable adapter to the maintenance connector.
Connect (PWC62174)extension cable to download (PWC69810) cable adapter.

Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to (PWC62174)extension cable. Connect the (PWC73009)connector labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN A" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled RS422 TO USB CHAN B" disconnected.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to USB end of the cable to laptop.

note.para: USB drivers provided with USB adapter must be previously installed. The USB connector must be plugged to the same USB port on the laptop where it was originally installed. It is advisable to label the USB port on the laptop.

l1item.para: Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the Windows desktop.
Select engine model PW617F.
Perform Engine Real Time Display task (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-820) and confirm LOOP is equal to 26.

If LOOP is not equal to 26, return to the GBSLite menu, connect the connector labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN B" into the Uport 1250 and disconnect the connector labeled RS422 TO USB CHAN A". Perform Engine Real Time Display task (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-820) and confirm LOOP is equal to 26.
Under the option of GSE CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD.

note.para: The help symbol ? within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes. It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l1item.para: Click OK to establish communication.
To trigger the download process; move TLA to the TO/GA and switch cockpit ignition switch from AUTO to OFF for more than 2 seconds.
If the download does not work, perform the Verify GSE Download Conditions in the Engine Real Time Display task (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-820).

note.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes. It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l1item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Make sure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: METHOD 1: Connection directly to the Engine DCU using ( PWC40549)Cable with External Power .

l2item.para: Remove the DCU from the engine.
Connect (PWC40549)cable to the DCU, to a commercial AC wall outlet and to a laptop via a serial port.
Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the Windows desktop.
Select engine model PW617.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD DCU.

numlitem.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes. It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l2item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Ensure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: METHOD 2: Connection directly to the Engine DCU cable with Aircraft Power DPHM Kit P/N 3074497 (Ref Fig. 513).

l2item.para: Remove P36 connector using (PWC90021) pliers.
Using DPHM Kit P/N 3074497 Ref. (Fig. :

l3item.para: Connect DCU (PWC40712)adapter cable to the DCU.
Connect P36 to DCU (PWC40712) adapter cable.
Connect DCU (PWC40712)adapter cable to (PWC62174) extension cable.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter (PWC62174) extension cable.
Connect the USB end of the RS422-USB (PWC73009)dual channel adapter to a laptop.

note.para: USB drivers provided with USB adapter must be previously installed. The USB connector must be plugged to the same USB port on the laptop where it was originally installed. It is advisable to label the USB port on the laptop.

l2item.para: Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.
Start GBSLite from the main menu.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD DCU.

numlitem.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes. It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l2item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Ensure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: METHOD 3: Connection directly to the Engine DCU cable with DCU (PWC67792)T-harness Cable .

l2item.para: Remove P36 connector using (PWC90021) pliers.
Using DCU T-Harness Cable, connect (PWC67792) cable to the DCU at P36 and to a laptop via the serial port.
Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.
Start GBSLite from the main menu.
Under the option of DCU CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD DCU.

numlitem.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
The download process may take up to 30 minutes.

l2item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Ensure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: This task describes how to download the engine DCU data which can be used for remote analysis by maintenance personnel, advanced diagnostics or to download ECTM data as a backup to the primary.
This task should only be used if the engine DCU data is not accessible because of an unserviceable DCU.
To obtain the complete EEC Data Download, it is necessary to download both EEC channel A and EEC channel B per engine.
Aircraft must be "ON GROUND" status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

l1item.para: Make sure that the Ground Based Software (GBS) and RS422 adapter USB drivers are installed as per section D of Task 71-00-00-760-818.
Connect (PWC69810)download cable adapter to the maintenance connector.
Connect (PWC62174)extension cable to download cable adapter.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to extension cable.
For EEC channel A download, connect the (PWC73009)dual channel adapter labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN A" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled RS422 TO USB CHAN B" disconnected.
For EEC channel B download, connect the connector labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN B" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled RS422 TO USB CHAN A" disconnected.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to laptop and connect the other end to the aircraft ground support equipment connector within the aircraft (Ref. Fig. 513) Refer to the AMM.

note.para: USB drivers provided with USB adapter must be previously installed. The USB connector must be plugged to the same USB port on the laptop where it was originally installed. It is advisable to label the USB port on the laptop.

l1item.para: Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the Windows desktop.
Under the option of GSE CONNECTION, select DOWNLOAD.

note.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.
If the ignition switch is already OFF, set it back to AUTO, and then start the procedure.

l1item.para: Move the TLA to the MAX detent and set the cockpit ignition switch from AUTO to OFF. Make sure the switch remains in the OFF position.

note.para: It is normal for the block numbers to appear to stop during the download process.

l1item.para: Once all blocks have been downloaded, another window will open and prompt you to save the recording to a file on your laptop computer. Ensure that the correct engine serial number, engine position and aircraft serial number are entered. The DCU data contains data from both EEC channels; therefore, it only has to be downloaded once per engine.

note.para: Special attention should be given to the location and filename of where the data is saved.

l1item.para: Cycle EEC power and repeat for the other channel.
Once both channels are downloaded, contact P&WC personnel to indicate that a DCU download was not possible.

numlitem.para: If the download does not work, do the Verify GSE Download Conditions in the Engine Real Time Display (Task 71-00-00-760-820).
TLA positions are as follows:

l1item.para: This task describes how to view both channels of EEC real-time data, at the same time, on the same engine.
This task may be used for the following reasons:

unlitem.para: To diagnose problems with the engine control system.
To check/verify engine EEC data vs. aircraft data.
To record information to be used for advanced remote analysis.

l1item.para: Aircraft must be "ON GROUND" status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

l1item.para: Ensure that the Ground Based Software (GBS) and RS422 adapter USB drivers are installed as per section D of task 71-00-00-760-818.
Connect download (PWC69810) cable adapter to the maintenance connector.
Connect (PWC62174)extension cable to download (PWC69810) cable adapter.
Connect RS422-USB (PWC73009) dual channel adapter to (PWC62174)extension cable.
For EEC channel A download, connect the (PWC73009)dual channel adapter labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN A" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled RS422 TO USB CHAN B" disconnected.
For EEC channel B download, connect the connector labeled "RS422 TO USB CHAN B" into the Uport 1250. Leave the connector labeled RS422 TO USB CHAN A" disconnected.

Connect the USB end of the RS422-USB (PWC73009)dual channel adapter to the laptop and connect the other end to the aircraft ground support equipment connector in the aircraft. (Ref. Fig. 513) (Refer to the AMM).
Launch GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the Windows desktop.
Under the option of GSE CONNECTION, select REAL TIME DISPLAY.

note.para: The help symbol "?" within the GBSLite software may be selected at any time for a more detailed instruction on the procedure.

l1item.para: Follow the on-screen menu to view parameters as supplied by the engine EEC.

To perform the Verify GSE Download Conditions function, select CLICK TO START VERIFY and follow the on-screen instructions. To end the Verify GSE Download Conditions function, select CLICK TO STOP VERIFY.
To perform a Real-Time Display recording, select the START RECORDING button. To end the recording, select the STOP RECORDING button. Follow the on-screen instructions.
This task describes how to review and analyze data that was previously downloaded from the engine or data from a recorded Real Time Display (RTD).
This task may be used to analyze/diagnose unscheduled maintenance events. It is intended for use by P&WC personnel or other experienced personnel.
There are four sources of data that may be used for data analysis:

unlitem.para: Engine data from the engine DCU.
Engine data from the engine EEC.
Engine data from the aircraft Avionics Flash Card.
Engine data from the aircraft Data Link Management System.

l1item.para: Not applicable.

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

taskproc.title: Engine Data Analysis from DCU and/or EEC

l1item.para: Start GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the main menu.
Select the engine program from the drop down menu (PW617F).
Select "Data Analysis".
Select the folder where the data is.
Proceed with analysis of the data.

To view the trend data, select Fault Event/Show Trend Data from View dropdown menu. If the trend data from the latest flights are not available in GBSLite, perform the DCU Pointer Block Recovery function Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-826 in GBS software.
In the Fault/Event panel (top panel), the data is sorted by data and time, the latest recording can be found at the bottom.
Click on Fault/Event Code; the name of the event code will appear at the top in red.
If the IETM, P/N 3072162 is installed, clicking on the Fault/Event Code will link to the appropriate maintenance action in fault isolation charts.
Click on the associated Snapshot and Trace for further analysis of the Fault/Event, which can be viewed in the lower panel.
The file can be sent to the Designated Analysis Center (DAC) for data analysis or can be uploaded to the WebECTM Services.
This task gives the TLD clearing procedure.
This task should be done at the scheduled TLD inspection interval (Ref. Task 05-20-00-210-801), after all the faults have been rectified.

note.para: The EEC is designed to latch a "ENG 1 LONG DISPATCH", or "ENG 2 LONG DISPATCH" TLD status, if at any time during operation, a TLD fault occurs. The status is displayed on the "Engine Maintenance Page" on the aircraft avionics. Refer to the AMM.

l1item.para: Aircraft system and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Aircraft must be "On ground" status.
Get access to the Aircraft Maintenance Computer. Refer to the AMM.
Move the TLA to the TOGA detent.
Activate the exceedance/TLD clearance function on the Engine Maintenance Page, for the appropriate engine. Refer to the AMM.

note.para: "CLEAR E1" for engine No. 1, and "CLEAR E2" for engine No. 2.

l1item.para: Check the engine maintenance page and make sure that LONG DISPATCH status is not active. Refer to the AMM.

note.para: The EEC must receive the command for at least two seconds to register the clear command. Therefore, it may take up to four seconds to display the updated LONG DISPATCH status on the engine maintenance page.

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for doing on-aircraft engine vibration survey and fan trim balancing. Refer to Figure.

Resonant vibration is the major contributor to aircraft cabin noise. Engine vibration causes resonant vibration in aircraft structures, exciting resonance and noise in the cabin. The maintenance philosophy for providing the following procedures is to aid in the reduction of aircraft cabin noise through the reduction of engine vibration.

Using the recommended vibration analysis equipment, engine vibration levels are measured while the engine is installed during a series of engine ground runs. Engine vibration is measured and potentially reduced by adjusting the trim balance weight configuration on the LP compressor (fan) front balance rim. A typical operation includes an initial ground run where a vibration survey is performed and a trim weight solution determined; a second ground run to measure the new vibration signature; and one or more engine runs to verify that engine vibration levels are optimized.

If excessive or undesirable cabin noise is present in the aircraft, it is recommended that cabin acoustic readings be taken using microphones according to an approved method, before performing on-wing engine vibration survey and trim balance. The cabin acoustic survey will help determine the source of the excessive noise. If it is suspected that the engine is the cause of excessive vibration and subsequent excessive cabin noise, only the fan may be trim-balanced while the engine is on the aircraft.

Current engine balancing procedures, carried out during engine test, include a requirement to trim balance the complete LP compressor assembly by the installation of counterweights to specific positions in the inlet cone assembly.

The operator must be familiar with the TEC Viper Model Collector/Analyzer before performing these operations. Do a vibration survey and fan trim balance operation using the following procedures and the TEC 'Viper' Model Operator's Manual.
P&WC recommends an engine fan trim balancing operation following repair of the fan.

Required equipment, including an optional laptop computer running TEC Avtrend software and connecting cables listed in Equipment and Materials list for this task has been approved for use in determining position and mass of trim balance counterweight. Other equipment may be approved on a case-by-case basis.
Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Disconnect the aircraft wiring harness connector from the engine main wiring harness connector at the aircraft firewall. Refer to the AMM.
Check the ACES analyzer battery charge:

l2item.para: Switch electrical power to the 10-100-4040CETEC Viper collector/analyzer to ON and check the battery's charge. If the battery charge indication is less than 60%, charge the battery before doing any procedures.
Switch electrical power to the 10-100-4040CETEC Viper collector/analyzer to OFF.

l1item.para: Install the latest version of the maintenance level Transient Vibration Survey/Fan Balance Setup File in the 10-100-4040CE ACES Viper collector/analyzer. The setup files may be downloaded from ACES Systems website: www.acessystems.com.
Switch electrical power to the analyzer to OFF.
Refer to the Illustrated Parts Catalog, 72-30-01, for trim balance counterweight information.

note.para: The equipment below is part of (PWC68604) High Speed Trim Balancing Kit.

entry.para: Cable, Breakout Extension N1 and N2

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

graphic.title: Typical Engine Vibration Survey and Fan Trim Balancing Operation Using TEC Model Equipment
Installation of Collector/Analyzer Equipment - Fan Trim Balancing

entry.para: Trim Balance Counterweights - Inlet Cone Hole Numbers
Trim Balance Counterweights - Engine Data Plate Hole Numbers

l1item.para: If the fan was repaired:

l2item.para: Remove the inlet cone (Ref. Task 72-30-01-000-801).
Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-802 for engine data plate descriptions. Check the engine trim data plate and record the locations of any LP compressor trim balance counterweights on a copy of Table.

note.para: Trim balance counterweight hole locations are numbered clockwise (CW) on the rear face of the inlet cone balancing rim (Ref. Fig.).

l2item.para: Record the location of any existing counterweights on the inlet cone balance rim on a copy of Table.

note.para: A maximum of nine counterweight screws are permitted on the inlet cone balance rim.

l2item.para: Remove all existing counterweights from the inlet cone balance rim.
Install the inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-400-805.

l1item.para: Install TEC Viper Model Analyzer equipment (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Remove the three nuts (4), the three bolts (3), the angle bracket (2) and engine front lifting bracket (1).
Install the (PWC69161)accelerometer mounting bracket (7), the three nuts (4), the three bolts (3) and the angle bracket (2). Torque the bolts 36 to 40 lb.in (4.1-4.5 Nm).

note.para: The bracket plate should face forward.

l2item.para: Install the 69-100-0016accelerometer (5) on the (PWC69161)accelerometer mounting bracket (7) with the three cap screws (6). Torque the cap screws 13 to 15 lb.in. (1.5-1.7 Nm.).

caution.para: MAKE SURE YOU ATTACH THE CABLES AND THE CHARGE CONVERTER BOX SECURELY TO PREVENT LOOSENING DURING THE GROUND RUN.

l2item.para: Connect the 10-320-0008high temperature cable to the 69-100-0016accelerometer and to the 10-100-0574 charge converter box.
Connect the 10-100-0574charge converter box to the 10-100-4040CETEC Viper collector/analyzer Channel A port with 10-320-0158sensor cable (25 ft) or 10-320-0159sensor cable (50 ft).
Disconnect the engine wiring harness P9 connector from the aircraft fire wall connector. Refer to the AMM.
Connect the 10-320-0333firewall breakout cable to the aircraft harness firewall connector. Refer to the AMM.
Connect the 10-320-0333firewall breakout cable to the engine rear main wiring harness P9 connector.
Connect the 10-320-0333firewall breakout cable to the 10-100-0498dual channel tach filter with the 10-320-0336N1/N2 breakout extension cable .

l1item.para: Switch electrical power to the ViperCollector/Analyzer ON.

note.para: With the ViperCollector/Analyzer powered on, make sure the Fan/Turbine Balance application is installed.
With the ViperCollector/Analyzer powered on, make sure the battery charge battery charge indication is more than 60%. If not, charge the battery before doing any procedures.

l1item.para: At the "Main" menu, select Fan/Turbine Balance using the upper/lower curser keys then press ENTER.
Select "Start Job" using the upper/lower curser keys and press ENTER.
At the "Set-up List", select PW617F using the upper/lower curser keys then press ENTER.

note.para: Analyzer will display "Loading...Please wait.", then, "Initializing for data acquisition, please wait".

l1item.para: At the "Job identification" menu, type in the name of the customer and the aircraft serial number (e.g. John Smith Aviation ZZ-XXX) using the keypad.

note.para: The "F1" key can be used to select Names which have been already entered in the analyzer.

l1item.para: In the "A/C Registration" field, enter the aircraft registration number using the keypad.
Input the A/C Total Time using the keypad keys and press ENTER.
At the "Engine Information" menu, enter the engine position using the left and right arrow keys, then use the upper/lower curser keys to move to "ENGINE".
Press the UP and DOWN arrow keys to move the cursor to the next field. Enter additional/optional information.
Press the ENTER key to move to the next menu.
At the "Fan/Turbine Balance Speeds" menu, press the F1 survey key.

note.para: The screen will display [Prime ]Initializing for Data Aquisition....Please Wait".

l1item.para: At the "Start Aircraft" menu, the Collector/Analyzer (Viper) screen will display "Survey for determining baln RPMs perform FOD check, start engine(s) per flight manual, and set engine(s) to idle".
Start the engine. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-810.
Let the engine stabilize and oil temperature reach 125F (51C) minimum. Press ENTER.

note.para: If required, run the engine at a higher idle speed to warm the engine oil, then return the power lever to idle.

l1item.para: Press ENTER to start acquiring data, then gradually increase engine speed to maximum N1 rpm. When this is done, press enter to stop acquisition.
Return the engine to ground idle N1 speed. There is no need to shut the engine down.
At the Shut down engines field, press F5 to continue.
At the Fan/turbine balance speeds screen, press enter to accept the peak N1 speed recorded during the survey and proceed to next screen.

note.para: The Analyzer will display "Initializing for data aquisition, please wait.".

l1item.para: The Analyzer will prompt "Fan/Turb Balance Equipment Setup" as a reminder to verify unit connections. Press ENTER to continue.
Record engine vibration levels at five N1 speeds as follows:

l2item.para: The Analyzer will display CURRENT RPM VALUE. Press ENTER.

caution.para: DO NOT EXCEED ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS WHEN TRIM BALANCING (REF. 05-10-00, OPERATING LIMITS, TASK 05-10-00-990-801). MAINTENANCE MANUAL ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS SUPERSEDE ANY INSTRUCTIONS IN THE ANALYZER PROCEDURE.

l2item.para: At the "Set Engine Speed" prompt, the Analyzer will display the peak vibration N1 speed. Bring the engine to this speed and press ENTER. At the next display, allow 10 to 15 seconds for the phase and amplitude to stabilize, then press ENTER to accept the measuring point.
The ViperCollector/Analyzer will display the next speed (Peak N1 minus 250 rpm). Repeat the procedure for the remaining N1 rpm settings:

note.para: At each speed, make sure that the engine rpm agrees with the speed requested by the ViperCollector/Analyzer and that the phase measurement indicated is fairly stable. If the engine speed changes by 50 rpm, press F1 (Reset) to start a new average.

l2item.para: Return the engine to ground idle N1 speed.

note.para: Do not press any key now: the Analyzer will display: "Please wait...Optimizing solution".

l2item.para: At the "Review Prior Run(s) Data" menu, review data taken and press ENTER.

note.para: Use F1 or F5 key to retake one or all speed settings.

l2item.para: Do the engine shutdown procedure. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-811.
Press F5 to continue.

l1item.para: Wait for the analyzer to produce counterweight optimization result at "Fan/Turb suggested/installed wts" prompt.
Record the position and class of the counterweight hole(s) defined by the Collector/Analyzer (Viper) on the Fan Trim Balancing Data Worksheet (Ref. Fig..
Remove the engine inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-000-801.

note.para: Unbalance is corrected using a maximum of nine counterweight screws.

l1item.para: At the "Fan/Turbine Suggested/Installed Weights" menu, press ENTER. If the trial counterweight is installed in the positions defined by the Viper Collector/Analyzer, press F1, "Inst=Sugg".

If the trim counterweight is installed in a hole other than the defined hole, change the class and location on the ViperCollector/Analyzer using the left/right and up/down curser keys. Record this information.

Install the counterweight screw(s) ( (2), Fig.) on the inlet cone balancing flange location closest to trial solution defined by Viper Collector/Analyzer. Tighten the counterweight screw (2) so that the screw head is flush with or below inlet cone (1) balancing Flange E.
Install the inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-400-805.
After the trial counterweight and the inlet cone have been installed, press ENTER to continue to proceed with the trial five-point ground run.

caution.para: DO NOT EXCEED ANY ENGINE OPERATING LIMIT (REF. 05-10-00, OPERATING LIMITS, TASK 05-10-00-990-801). IF ANY N1 SETTING WILL CAUSE THE ENGINE TO EXCEED AN OPERATING LIMIT, OMIT THAT POINT OR POINTS.

l1item.para: Start the engine. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-810.
Let the engine stabilize and the engine oil temperature reach 125F (51C) minimum.
Record engine vibration levels at five N1 speeds as follows:

l2item.para: The Analyzer will display CURRENT RPM VALUE. Press ENTER.

caution.para: DO NOT EXCEED ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS (REF. 05-10-00, OPERATING LIMITS, TASK 05-10-00-990-991). MAINTENANCE MANUAL ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS SUPERSEDE ANY INSTRUCTIONS IN THE ANALYZER PROCEDURE.

l2item.para: At the "Set Engine Speed" prompt, the Analyzer will display the peak vibration N1 speed. Bring the engine to this speed and press ENTER. At the next display, allow 10 to 15 seconds for the phase and amplitude to stabilize, then press ENTER to accept the measuring point.
The ViperCollector/Analyzer will display the next speed (Peak N1 minus 250 rpm). Repeat the procedure for the remaining N1 rpm settings:

note.para: At each speed, make sure that the engine rpm agrees with the speed requested by the ViperCollector/Analyzer and that the phase measurement indicated is fairly stable. If the engine speed changes by 50 rpm, press F1 (Reset) to start a new average.

l2item.para: Return the engine to ground idle N1 speed.

note.para: Do not press any key now: the Analyzer will display: "Please wait...Optimising solution".

l2item.para: At the "Review Prior Run(s) Data" menu, review data taken and press ENTER.

note.para: Use F1 or F5 key to retake one or all speed settings.

l2item.para: Do the engine shutdown procedure. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-811.
Press F5 to continue.

l1item.para: Wait for the analyzer to produce counterweight optimization result at "Fan/Turb suggested/installed wts" panel.
If the vibration level is within acceptable limits, end the balance procedure. Record trim counterweight class and screw hole location(s) in the engine log book.
If vibration level is not acceptable, observe and record the new counterweight weight and hole location calculated by ViperCollector/Analyzer, then do the following steps:

note.para: The ViperCollector/Analyzer calculates final or successive solutions based on previous trial counterweights having been removed.

l2item.para: Remove the engine inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-000-801.
Remove the affected trial counterweight screw(s) from the inlet cone. Note the balance hole location number of the removed counterweight (Ref. Fig.).
At the "Fan/Turbine Suggested/Installed Weights" menu, press ENTER. If the trial counterweight is installed in the positions defined by the ViperCollector/Analyzer, press F1, "Inst=Sugg".

If the trim counterweight is installed in a hole other than the defined hole, change the class and location on the Viper Collector/Analyzer using the left/right and up/down curser keys. Record this information.

Install the counterweight screw(s) ( (2),Fig.) on the inlet cone balancing flange location closest to trial solution defined by Viper Collector/Analyzer. Tighten the counterweight screw (2) so that the screw head is flush with or below inlet cone (1) balancing Flange E.
Install the inlet cone. Refer to Task 72-30-01-400-805.
After the trial counterweight and the inlet cone have been installed, press ENTER to continue.
Do further trial weight trim balance runs as required.
When engine vibration is within acceptable limits, end the balance procedure. Record trim counterweight class and screw hole location(s) in the engine log book.

l1item.para: Switch power to the Aces Viper analyzer to OFF.
Remove the cables connecting the Aces Viper analyzer equipment to the engine interfaces. Separate the cables and equipment and put them in the protective case.
Connect the engine wiring harness P9 connector to the aircraft fire wall connector. Refer to the AMM.
Remove the three cap screws (6) and the 69-100-0016 accelerometer (5) from the (PWC69161)accelerometer mounting bracket (7).
Remove the three bolts (3), three nuts (4), the angle bracket (2) and the (PWC69161) accelerometer mounting bracket (7) from the engine.
Lubricate the bolt (3) threads with (PWC03-001)engine oil .
Install the engine front lifting bracket (1) using the three nuts (4), the three bolts (3), the angle bracket (2). Torque the bolts 36 to 40 lb.in (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedure for doing an on-wing engine transient vibration survey.
Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Check the ACES analyzer battery charge:

l2item.para: Switch electrical power to the 10-100-4040CEACES Viper collector/analyzer to ON and check the battery's charge. If the battery charge indication is less than 60%, charge the battery before doing any procedures.
Switch electrical power to the TEC Viper ModelCollector/Analyzer to OFF.

l1item.para: Install the latest version of the maintenance level Transient Vibration Survey/Fan Balance Setup File in the 10-100-4040CE ACES Viper collector/analyzer. The setup files may be downloaded from ACES Systems website: www.acessystems.com.
Switch electrical power to the analyzer to OFF.

note.para: The equipment below is part of (PWC68604) High Speed Trim Balancing Kit.

entry.para: CEC Adapter Cable, Sensor Cable-to-Velocity Sensor
Cable, Breakout Extension N1 and N2

graphic.title: Typical Engine Vibration Survey and Fan Trim Balancing Operation Using TEC Model Equipment
Installation of Collector/Analyzer Equipment - Transient Vibration Survey

l1item.para: Install the 69-100-0078velocity transducer (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Get access to the engine bypass duct services fairing assembly at the six o'clock position on the bypass duct rear flange. Refer to the AMM.
Remove the bolt (11), the washer (10) and the plug (9) from the bypass duct service fairing. Discard the preformed packing (8).

caution.para: MAKE SURE YOU ATTACH THE CABLES AND THE CHARGE CONVERTER BOX SECURELY TO PREVENT LOOSENING DURING THE GROUND RUN.

l2item.para: Install the 69-100-0078velocity transducer on the velocity transducer mounting bracket installed on the exhaust case rear flange at the 6 o'clock position. Tighten the transducer using the (PWC68764)socket supplied with the (PWC68604)fan trim balancing kit to 32 to 36 lb.in..
Connect the 69-100-0078velocity transducer to the 10-320-0226CEC adapter cable.

Connect the 10-320-0226CEC adapter cable to the Channel B port on the 10-100-4040CEACES Viper collector/analyzer with the 10-320-0158sensor cable (25 ft) or the sensor cable 10-320-0159sensor cable (50 ft).

l1item.para: Install TEC Viper Model Analyzer equipment (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Remove the three nuts (4), the three bolts (3), the angle bracket (2) and engine front lifting bracket (1).
Install the (PWC69161)accelerometer mounting bracket (7), the three nuts (4), the three bolts (3) and the angle bracket (2). Torque the bolts 36 to 40 lb.in (4.1-4.5 Nm).

note.para: The bracket plate should face forward.

l2item.para: Install the 69-100-0016accelerometer (5) on the (PWC69161)accelerometer mounting bracket (7) with the three cap screws (6). Torque the cap screws 13 to 15 lb.in. (1.5-1.7 Nm.).

caution.para: MAKE SURE YOU ATTACH THE CABLES AND THE CHARGE CONVERTER BOX SECURELY TO PREVENT LOOSENING DURING THE GROUND RUN.

l2item.para: Connect the 10-320-0008high temperature cable to the 69-100-0016accelerometer and to the 10-100-0574 charge converter box.
Connect the 10-100-0574charge converter box to the 10-100-4040CEACES Viper collector/analyzer Channel A port with 10-320-0158sensor cable (25 ft) or the 10-320-0159sensor cable (50 ft).
Disconnect the engine wiring harness P9 connector from the aircraft fire wall connector. Refer to the AMM.
Connect the 10-320-0333firewall breakout cable to the aircraft harness firewall connector. Refer to the AMM.
Connect the 10-320-0333firewall breakout cable to the engine rear main wiring harness P9 connector.
Connect the 10-320-0333firewall breakout cable to the 10-100-0498dual channel tach filter with the 10-320-0336N1/N2 breakout extension cable .

l1item.para: Switch electrical power to the Collector/Analyzer (TEC Viper Model) to ON.
At the "Main" menu, select the Transient Vibration Survey option using the upper/lower curser keys then press ENTER.
At the "Transient Vibration Survey" menu, select "Start Job" using the upper/lower curser keys then press ENTER.
At the "Setup List" menu, select "PW617F O/W" using the upper/lower curser keys and press ENTER.

note.para: The screen will display "Initializing for Data Aquisition....Please Wait".

l1item.para: At the "Job Identification" menu, type in the name of the customer and the the aircraft serial number (e.g. John Smith Aviation ZZ-XXX) using the keypad.

note.para: The "F1" key can be used to select Names which have been already entered in the analyzer.

l1item.para: Press the DOWN arrow key to move the cursor to the next field.
In the "A/C Registration" field, enter the aircraft registration number using the keypad.
Press the DOWN arrow key to move the cursor to the next field.
In the "A/C Total Time" field, enter A/C total time in hours using the keypad.
Press the ENTER key to move to the next menu.
At the "Engine Information" menu, enter the engine position number using the left and right arrow keys.
Move the cursor past the 'Propeller' field by pressing the DOWN arrow key until the cursor is in the 'Engine' section.
Enter the engine serial number (e.g. LC-XXXX) or use the F1 key to enter a previously-entered engine S/N.
Press the DOWN arrow key to move the cursor to the "Type" field. Enter 'PW617F'.
Press the DOWN arrow key to move the cursor to the "TSO" field. Use the keypad to enter total-time-since-overhaul in hours.
Press the DOWN arrow key to move the cursor to the "TSN" field. Use the keypad to enter total-time-since-new.
Press ENTER.

note.para: The screen will display either "Initializing for Data Aquisition...Please Wait" or " Recovering Database Memory Before Display Initializes" and there will be a five-to-eight second pause.

l1item.para: The ViperCollector/Analyzer screen will display "Perform FOD check, start the engine and establish normal operating conditions".
Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810).
Let engine stabilize and the engine oil temperature reach a minimum of 125F (51C).

note.para: If required, run the engine at a higher idle speed to warm the engine oil, then return the power lever to idle.

l1item.para: At the Start Engine menu, press ENTER.

note.para: Please wait while the database is accessing.

l1item.para: From the "Select Condition" menu, use the DOWN arrow key to move the cursor to the "[ ] ACCEL" condition field. Press ENTER.

note.para: This step will appear if there are multiple conditions to choose from.
There will be a delay of approximately ten seconds while the analyzer prepares the database manager to recover database memory. When the real-time display starts, the analyzer will be recording data.

l1item.para: The ViperCollector/Analyzer will next display real time Plane 1, Plane 3, N1 and N2 engine data on the analyzer screen.

note.para: For on-wing fan vibration survey, Plane 3 data is not required.
Real-time data is sampled by the analyzer at a rate of five times/sec.
This field will display rotor rpm value in %.

caution.para: DO NOT EXCEED ANY ENGINE OPERATING LIMIT WHEN TRIM BALANCING (REF. 05-10-00, OPERATING LIMITS, TASK 05-10-00-990-801). MAINTENANCE MANUAL ENGINE OPERATING LIMITS SUPERSEDE ANY INSTRUCTIONS IN THE ANALYZER PROCEDURE.

l1item.para: Data aquistion step: accelerate engine from idle to N1 takeoff power at approximate rate of 0.5% N1 per second. When takeoff N1 power is achieved, press ENTER to stop real-time data acquisition.
The analyzer will display the message "Store the Data".
Press the F1 key to answer YES and store the data or press the F5 key to answer NO if the data is to be discarded.
Decelerate the engine to idle speed.
Press F1 again to "End Run" to complete the survey.

note.para: The ViperCollector/Analyzer screen will display "Shut Down Engine per Manual Instructions".

l1item.para: Do the engine shutdown procedure. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-811.
Press the F5 key to continue.
Go to the "Main" menu using the Backup key.
If the engine vibration levels are satisfactory:

l2item.para: Download the survey data to a computer if required. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-825.
Do the steps in Job Closeup Information.

l1item.para: Switch power to the 10-100-4040CEcollector/analyzer to OFF.
Refer to (Ref. Fig.. Remove the cables connecting the Aces Viper analyzer equipment to the engine interfaces. Separate the cables and equipment and put them in the protective case.
Connect the engine wiring harness P9 connector to the aircraft fire wall connector. Refer to the AMM.
Remove the three cap screws (6) and the 69-100-0016 accelerometer (5) from the (PWC69161)accelerometer mounting bracket (7).
Remove the three bolts (6), three nuts (4), the angle bracket (2) and the (PWC69161) accelerometer mounting bracket (7) from the engine.
Lubricate the bolt (3) threads with (PWC03-001)engine oil .
Install the engine front lifting bracket (1) using the three nuts (4), the three bolts (3), the angle bracket (2). Torque the bolts 36 to 40 lb.in (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Remove the 69-100-0078velocity transducer using the (PWC68764)socket .
Lubricate a new preformed packing (8) with (PWC03-001)engine oil .
Install the preformed packing (8) on the plug (9).
Install the plug (9), the washer (10) and the bolt (11) on the bypass duct service fairing. Torque the bolt 36 to 40 lb.in (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

task.title: Downloading Transient Vibration Survey and/or Fan Trim Balancing Data to Laptop

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for downloading fan trim balancing data to a laptop computer.
Not applicable.

note.para: The equipment below is part of (PWC68604) High Speed Trim Balancing Kit.

l1item.para: Switch power to the Aces Collector analyzer ON.
Connect the 10-320-0483analyzer-to-notebook USB data cable to the USB port on the side of the ViperCollector/Analyzer .
Connect the 10-320-0483analyzer-to-notebook USB data cable to a USB port on a computer operating 10-700-0103 TEC Avtrend software.
Open the 10-700-0103TEC Avtrend software software program on the computer.
Select Menu Option - File - Transfer - Retrieve Data. Wait for data to be transferred.

graphic.title: Downloading Transient Vibration Survey and/or Fan Trim Balancing Data to Laptop - Schematic

l1item.para: Disconnect the 10-320-0483analyzer-to-notebook USB data cable.
Turn power to the ViperCollector/Analyzer OFF.
Note the file name and path displayed in the Avtrend software program window in order to find the file for future use.

This task describes how to recover the pointer block 8 or 9 in the DCU when one of these blocks is absent or corrupt on an engine Post-SB66008. It is intended for use by P&WC personnel or other experienced personnel.
This task cannot be used if both blocks 8 and 9 are not healthy (both blocks are absent, or corrupt, or a combination).
This task is to be performed if data is missing from the DCU. A symptom of missing DCU data is if the trend data from the latest flights are not available in GBSLite.
Aircraft must be ON GROUND status.
Aircraft systems and engine EEC should be powered and communicating. Refer to the AMM.
Engine must be shutdown (not running).

entry.para: PW617F-E, Diagnostic, Prognostics and Health Management (DPHM) Kit

l1item.para: Connect to directly to the DCU as per one of the following methods:

l2item.para: METHOD 1: Connection directly to the Engine DCU using ( PWC40549)cable with external power .

l3item.para: Remove the DCU from the engine.
Connect (PWC40549)cable with external power to the DCU, to a commercial AC wall outlet and to a laptop via a serial port.

l2item.para: METHOD 2: Connection directly to the Engine DCU cable with DPHM Kit P/N 3074497. (Ref. Fig. 513)

l3item.para: Remove P36 connector using (PWC90021) pliers.
Using DPHM Kit P/N 3074497:

l4item.para: Connect DCU ( PWC40712)adapter cable to the DCU.
Connect P36 to Connect DCU (PWC40712)adapter cable.
Connect RS422-USB ( PWC73009)dual channel adapter to (PWC62174)extension cable .
Connect RS422-USB ( PWC73009)dual channel adapter to the laptop.

note.para: USB drivers provided with USB adapter must be previously installed.

l3item.para: Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.

l1item.para: METHOD 3: Connection directly to the Engine DCU cable with DCU T-Harness (PWC67792)cable :

l2item.para: Remove P36 connector using (PWC90021) pliers.
Using DCU T-Harness Cable, connect (PWC67792) cable to the DCU at P36 and to a laptop via serial port.
Energize the EEC. Refer to the AMM.

l1item.para: Start GBSLite (P/N 3070181) from the desktop.
Select the engine program from the drop down menu (PW617F).
Select the TRANSFER MODULE button.
Select DOWNLOAD/UPLOAD button.
In the toolbar, set the connection method to DIRECT.
Under the options menu, select Advanced Options.
When prompted, enter the password "pwc_pwr_user".
Select the "Detect and Recover Unhealthy DCU" button.
If you see one of the following messages, then the recovery was successful.

l2item.para: Block 8 successfully recreated.
Block 8 successfully repaired.
Block 9 successfully recreated.
Block 9 successfully repaired.

l1item.para: If you see one of the following messages contact your P&WC representative:

l2item.para: Program terminated. Invalid software identification.
Program terminated. Block 8 missing and Block 9 corrupted.
Program terminated. Block 9 missing and Block 8 corrupted.
Program terminated. Both Blocks 8 and 9 are missing.
Program terminated. Block 8 corrupted and Block 9 missing.
Program terminated. Block 9 corrupted and Block 8 missing.
Program terminated. Both Blocks 8 and 9 are corrupted.
Blocks 8 and 9 valid. No action taken.

l1item.para: Once a successful recovery is completed. Ensure that the DCU data is as per the logbook by performing Engine Trim Verification Check (Task 71-00-00-760-817).
-If after successfully completing the DCU Pointer Block Recovery, the symptoms are not resolved, contact your P&WC representative.

l1item.para: The Power Plant Cleaning section gives the procedures for engine external wash, fan hand wash, compressor washes (desalination or performance recovery) procedures. Compressor wash system information and water and cleaning solution information is also included.
Definition of Terms:

numlitem.para: Desalination Wash: A procedure that uses water only to remove salt from the engine air path.
Performance Recovery Wash: A procedure that uses the water solution mixed with a cleaning agent to clean the air path of contaminants to attempt to restore performance.
Rinsing: A procedure that uses a water solution to rinse the engine of cleaning solution.
Water Solution: A solution of water with or without isopropyl alcohol.

l1item.para: This task gives the set up information for the compressor wash system.
Not applicable.

entry.para: Compressor Wash Unit, Mobile (Alternate to PWC64444)
Compressor Wash Unit, Portable (Alternate to PWC32677-300)

note.para: Tubing for interconnection of components is to be 5/16 in. (8 mm) ID minimum.

l1item.para: Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.

task.title: Installation of the Compressor Wash Fixture (PWC69210)

l1item.para: Task Removed.

task.title: Removal of the Compressor Wash Fixture (PWC69210)

This task gives the procedures for preparing cleaning and rinse solutions for engine washing.
Not applicable.

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

note.para: Demineralized water is recommended for all types of washes. Drinking quality water may be used for engine external, fan and compressor washing (performance recovery).

l1item.para: Obtain a supply of demineralized water or drinking water complying with the requirements shown in Table:

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: The intake filter must not be coarser than 10-microns.

l1item.para: Prepare the water solution (Ref Table).
Performance recovery wash solutions:

l2item.para: B&B TC 100 (PWC11-003E)Detergent Cleaner is a ready-to-use solution. Do not further dilute by adding water and/or methanol

caution.para: DO NOT FURTHER DILUTE SOLUTION BY ADDING WATER AND/OR ANTI-FREEZE SOLUTIONS.

l2item.para: Turco T-5884 (PWC11-001G)Detergent Cleaner can be used but it is not a ready-to-use. Prepare this solution (Ref Table).

note.para: Add 150 ml of (PWC05-005)witconate emulsifying agent and mix solution thoroughly before use to prevent fuel separation.

caution.para: DO NOT FURTHER DILUTE SOLUTION BY ADDING WATER AND/OR ANTI-FREEZE SOLUTIONS.

l2item.para: The Biodegradable Performance Recovery Solutions, Ardrox 6345 ( PWC11-003)Detergent Cleaner or Ardrox 6367 (PWC11-003B)Detergent Cleaner (previously identified as Turboclean 2) can be used but they are not ready-to-use. Prepare this solution (Ref Table).

l1item.para: Table matches required cleaning solutions to the applicable engine cleaning task.
This task gives the procedures for external engine washing.
Not applicable.
The engine should never be left in a contaminated condition overnight, or longer.

caution.para: DO NOT USE GASOLINE OR SIMILAR TOXIC SUBSTANCES FOR EXTERNAL ENGINE CLEANING. DO NOT ATTEMPT TO WASH AN ENGINE THAT IS STILL HOT OR RUNNING. ALLOW ENGINE TO COOL FOR A MINIMUM PERIOD OF 40 MINUTES AFTER SHUTDOWN TO PREVENT PRECIPITATION FROM INADVERTENT USE OF HARD WATER.

l1item.para: External washing with fresh water is recommended when engine is contaminated with salt, volcanic dust or corrosive chemicals such as those found in industrial smog. Demineralized water is not necessary. (Ref. Task 71-00-00-160-804 for water quality requirements)
Mask all electrical connectors with plastic wrap to avoid moisture damage to connectors.
Wash the engine by hand using a clean sponge or soft cloth.

If a water wash is ineffective, a (PWC11-027) petroleum solvent /water emulsion may be used to remove oil, grime, or other materials/fluids (e.g. hydraulic fluids). Thoroughly rinse with water to remove all traces of cleaning fluid. Completely dry the engine using clean, dry compressed air.

note.para: External cleaning is very effective in tracing possible origin of external oil leakage.

l1item.para: Remove the plastic wrap from the electrical connectors.
Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedure for hand washing the fan.
Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

warning.para: PRIOR TO FAN WASHING MAKE SURE THE STARTER SWITCH AND IGNITION SYSTEM ARE IN THE OFF POSITION AND THE THRUST LEVER IS IN THE CUT OFF POSITION.
WHEN WASHING THE FAN BY HAND WEAR RUBBER GLOVES AND USE CAUTION AS THE LEADING EDGE OF FAN BLADES MAY BE VERY SHARP.

l1item.para: Fan blade washing is done by hand using a sponge or soft clean cloth.
Each blade must be washed individually on both pressure and suction side.
Wash the fan with desalination solution. Refer to Task 71-00-00-160-804.
Rinse with desalination solution.
Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedure for doing a compressor desalination wash.
Deleted.
Deleted.
Place suitable containers or a drip pan under the engine.

caution.para: FAILURE TO BLANK THE AGB BREATHER PORT (2) OR TO REMOVE THE AGB BREATHER TUBE (3) WILL RESULT IN CONTAMINATION OF THE AGB ENGINE OIL BY WASH FLUID.

l1item.para: Prepare the engine to prevent wash fluid from entering the AGB:

l2item.para: Install either a (PWC69812) blanking plug (1) or a PK3654-49 cap (1) or equivalent in the AGB breather port (2).
As an alternate to step (a), remove the AGB breather tube (3). (Ref. Task 72-60-02-000-801)
Make sure the engine control panel switch is set to the OFF position.
Make sure the engine thrust lever is in the IDLE position.
Shut off the aircraft cabin bleed air system. Refer to the AMM.
Make sure the engine ignition system is OFF.

entry.para: Compressor Wash Unit, Mobile (Alternate to PWC64444)
Compressor Wash Unit, Portable (Alternate to PWC32677-300)
Compressor Wash Unit, Mobile (Alternate to PWC64444)
Cap, AGB Breather Port (Alternate to PWC69812)

caution.para: MAKE SURE THAT THE ENGINE TEMPERATURE IS LESS THAN 150F (65C). IF THE TEMPERATURE IS HIGHER, HARD WATER CAN CAUSE MINERAL CONTAMINATION.
DO NOT EXCEED WASH OR RINSE FLUID INJECTION RATES.
THE (PWC69836)WASH WAND (5) MUST BE USED WITH FOUR (PWC66581) WEDGES (4) TO PREVENT FAN ROTATION DURING MOTORING CYCLES.
THE LP COMPRESSOR IS A TITANIUM PART. OPERATE THE WASH WAND WITH CARE.

l1item.para: Connect the (PWC69836)wash wand to the (PWC32677-300) mobile wash system or the (PWC64444)portable wash system or the (PWC89888)portable wash system or a locally manufactured wash system.
Install (PWC66581)wedges (4) as follows:

caution.para: MAKE SURE WEDGES ARE IN GOOD CONDITION.

l2item.para: Inspect wedges (4) for damage prior to installation to prevent damage to the abraidable material on the fan case. Replace any broken wedges.
Install four (PWC66581)wedges (4) between the tips of four equally-spaced fan blades and the fan case to prevent fan rotation. Make sure the wedges are secure.

caution.para: USE ONLY DEMINERALIZED WATER IN SOLUTIONS USED TO DO COMPRESSOR DESALINATION WASH FOR ENGINES EXPOSED TO CHEMICAL FIRE EXTINGUISHING AGENTS.

l1item.para: Fill the wash system with the required water solution:

l2item.para: Pressurize the wash system.
Adjust the wash system pressure to obtain a flow rate of 1.6 US gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Use water solution for a compressor desalination wash. Refer to Task 71-00-00-160-804.

caution.para: INSTALL THE WASH WAND GENTLY TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE FAN BLADES, FAN STATOR AND THE CORE INTAKE STRUTS.
MAKE SURE THAT THE WASH WAND DISK (6) IS SITTING ON THE TOP OF THE NOSE CONE AND AGAINST THE FAN BLADES.
MAKE SURE THAT THE NOZZLE OF THE WASH WAND IS POINTED INTO THE HP COMPRESSOR INTAKE.

l1item.para: Insert the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) by rotating the wand nozzle (7) through the fan blades, fan stator and the core intake struts into position in the HP compressor intake.
Make sure the four (PWC66581) wedges (4) prevent the fan from rotating.
Hold the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) during the engine motoring to make sure the disk (6) stays flat against the fan blades and sitting on the nose cone.

caution.para: DO NOT OPERATE THE WASH SYSTEM IF EITHER THE AGB BREATHER PORT (2) IS NOT CAPPED OR IF THE AGB BREATHER TUBE (3) WAS NOT REMOVED.
BEFORE MOTORING ENGINE, MAKE SURE THE ENGINE INTAKE IS CLEAR OF ALL LOOSE OBJECTS WHICH MAY BE INGESTED AND CAUSE ENGINE DAMAGE AND SUBSEQUENT FAILURE.
OBSERVE THE STARTER MANUFACTURER'S LIMITS DURING MOTORING (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).

l1item.para: Do two 20 second dry motoring runs using the engine starter. As N2 rotation passes 5%, start injection of 0.8 US gallons (3 liters) of the water solution into the engine core at a rate of 1.6 gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Stop motoring after 20 seconds. Turn the wash system off when N2 rotation is less than 5%.

caution.para: PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE FAN STATOR VANES AND FAN BLADES BY GENTLY ROTATING THE WAND (5) AS IT IS REMOVED.

l1item.para: Remove the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) from engine.
Remove the four (PWC66581) wedges (4).

caution.para: DELETED.
ALLOW STARTER TO COOL BETWEEN RUNS (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).

l1item.para: If isopropyl alcohol was used in the water solution, do a 20 second dry motoring run.

note.para: DELETED.

l1item.para: Disassemble wash system and (PWC69836) wash wand (3).
Deleted.
Deleted.
Deleted.

caution.para: MAKE SURE ALL CLEANING EQUIPMENT HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM THE ENGINE INLET.

l1item.para: Remove either the (PWC69812)blanking plug (1) or the cap PK3654-49 (1) from the AGB breather outlet port (2) if either were installed. Discard the cap.
Install the AGB breather tube (3) if it was removed. (Ref. Task 72-60-02-400-801)
Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.
Select CABIN BLEED OFF.
Do an engine start and operate the engine for one minute at 80% N1 to dry the engine.
Reduce power to IDLE. Operate the engine for five minutes at IDLE with CABIN BLEED ON.
Do the engine shutdown procedure. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-811.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedure for doing a compressor performance recovery wash.
Disconnect the two aircraft P3 air bleed tubes. Refer to the AMM.
Secure a plastic bag over the two exposed aircraft P3 ports. Leave the two engine P3 bleed ports open.
Place suitable containers or a drip pan under the engine.

caution.para: FAILURE TO BLANK THE AGB BREATHER PORT (2) OR TO REMOVE THE AGB BREATHER TUBE (3) WILL RESULT IN CONTAMINATION OF THE AGB ENGINE OIL BY WASH FLUID

l1item.para: Prepare the engine to prevent wash fluid from entering the AGB:

l2item.para: Install either a (PWC69812) blanking plug (1) or a PK3654-49 cap (1) or equivalent in the AGB breather port (2).
As an alternate to step (a), remove the AGB breather tube (3). (Ref. Task 72-60-02-000-801)
Make sure the engine control panel switch is set to the OFF position.
Make sure the engine thrust lever is in the IDLE position.
Shut off the aircraft cabin bleed air system. Refer to the AMM.
Make sure the engine ignition system is OFF.

DO NOT EXCEED WASH OR RINSE FLUID INJECTION RATES.
THE (PWC69836)WASH WAND (5) MUST BE USED WITH FOUR (PWC66581) WEDGES (4) TO PREVENT FAN ROTATION DURING MOTORING CYCLES.
