l1item.para: Connect the (PWC69836)wash wand to the (PWC32677-300) mobile wash system or (PWC64444) portable wash system or the (PWC89888)portable wash system or a locally manufactured wash system.
Install (PWC66581)wedges (4) as follows:

caution.para: MAKE SURE WEDGES ARE IN GOOD CONDITION.

l2item.para: Inspect wedges (4) for damage prior to installation to prevent damage to the abraidable material on the fan case. Replace any broken wedges.
Install four (PWC66581)wedges (4) between the tips of four equally-spaced fan blades and the fan case to prevent fan rotation. Make sure the wedges are secure.

caution.para: DO NOT DO A COMPRESSOR PERFORMANCE RECOVERY WASH OF ENGINES EXPOSED TO CHEMICAL FIRE EXTINGUISHING AGENTS.

l1item.para: Fill the wash system with the required compressor wash fluid:

l2item.para: Pressurize the wash system.
Adjust the wash system pressure to obtain a flow rate of 1.6 US gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Use (PWC11-001G)detergent cleaner, (PWC11-003)detergent cleaner, (PWC11-003B) detergent cleaner or (PWC11-003E) detergent cleaner for a performance recovery wash.

caution.para: INSTALL THE WASH WAND GENTLY TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE FAN BLADES, FAN STATOR AND THE CORE INTAKE STRUTS.
MAKE SURE THAT THE WASH WAND DISK (6) IS SITTING ON THE TOP OF THE NOSE CONE AND IS flat against THE FAN BLADES AFTER WAND INSTALLATION.
MAKE SURE THAT THE NOZZLE (7) OF THE WASH WAND (5) IS POINTED INTO THE HP COMPRESSOR INTAKE BEFORE APPLYING PRESSURE.

l1item.para: Insert the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) by rotating the wand nozzle (7) through the fan blades, fan stator and the core intake struts into position in the HP compressor intake.
Make sure the four (PWC66581) wedges (4) prevent the fan from rotating.
Hold the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) during the engine motoring to make sure the disk (6) stays flat against the fan blades and sitting on the nose cone.

caution.para: DO NOT OPERATE THE WASH SYSTEM IF EITHER THE AGB BREATHER PORT (2) IS NOT CAPPED OR IF THE AGB BREATHER TUBE (3) WAS NOT REMOVED.
BEFORE MOTORING ENGINE, MAKE SURE THE ENGINE INTAKE IS CLEAR OF ALL LOOSE OBJECTS WHICH MAY BE INGESTED AND CAUSE ENGINE DAMAGE AND SUBSEQUENT FAILURE.
OBSERVE THE STARTER MANUFACTURER'S LIMITS DURING MOTORING (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).

l1item.para: Start a 20 second dry motoring runs using the engine starter. As N2 rotation passes 5%, start injection of 0.8 US gallons (3 liters) of the cleaning solution into the engine HP compressor gas path at a rate of 1.6 gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Stop motoring after 20 seconds. Turn the wash system off when N2 rotation is less than 5%.
Allow cleaning solution to soak for 30 minutes.

Start a 20 second dry motoring run using the engine starter. As N2 rotation passes 5%, start injection of 0.8 US gallons (3 liters) of water solution into the engine core at a rate of 1.6 gal/minute (6 liters/minute).
Stop motoring after 20 seconds. Turn the wash system off when N2 rotation is less than 5%.
If evidence of cleaning solution is still present inside the engine, repeat steps (9) and (10).

caution.para: PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE FAN STATOR VANES AND FAN BLADES BY GENTLY ROTATING THE WAND (5) AS IT IS REMOVED.

l1item.para: Remove the (PWC69836)wash wand (5) from engine.
Remove the four (PWC66581) wedges (4).

caution.para: OBSERVE THE STARTER MANUFACTURER'S LIMITS DURING MOTORING (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).
ALLOW THE STARTER TO COOL BETWEEN RUNS (REF. STARTER MANUFACTURER'S MANUAL).

l1item.para: Do a 20 second dry motoring run.

note.para: If ambient temperatures required the use of isopropyl alcohol in the water solution, do an additional 20 second dry motoring run to purge the engine of remaining fumes.

l1item.para: If required, do another performance recovery wash after engine drying.
Dissassemble wash system and (PWC69836) wash wand (5).
Remove the plastic bags from the two aircraft P3 bleed ports.
Check the P3 air ports for moisture. Remove moisture.
Connect the two P3 air bleed lines. Refer to the AMM.

caution.para: MAKE SURE ALL CLEANING EQUIPMENT HAS BEEN REMOVED FROM THE ENGINE INLET.

l1item.para: Remove either the (PWC69812)blanking plug (1) or the cap PK3654-49 (1) from the AGB breather outlet port (2) if either were installed. Discard the cap.
Install the AGB breather tube (3) if it was removed. (Ref. Task 72-60-02-400-801)
Remove all tools, equipment and unnecessary items from the work area.
Select CABIN BLEED OFF.
Do an engine start and operate the engine for one minute at 80% N1 to dry the engine.
Reduce power to IDLE.
Select CABIN BLEED ON and operate the engine for five minutes at IDLE.
Do the engine shutdown procedure. Refer to Task 71-00-00-760-811.
If required, do another performance recovery wash after engine drying.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

title.xref: Biodegradable Performance Recovery Solutions Ardrox 6345 (PWC11-003) or Ardrox 6367 (PWC11-003B) (previously identified as Turboclean 2)

l1item.para: The PW617F-E engine is a two spool turbofan engine with a full length annular by-pass duct. A concentric shaft system supports the low pressure (LP) and high pressure (HP) rotors. The inner LP shaft supports the LP compressor (fan) which is driven by a single stage LP turbine. The outer HP shaft system is mechanically independent of the LP shaft and supports a single mixed flow stage and one centrifugal stage HP compressor driven by a single stage HP turbine. Thrust and roller anti-friction bearings provide support on each shaft.

Air enters the engine through the fan case and is accelerated rearwards by the fan. Concentric dividing ducts split the air into bypass and core flow streams. Fan bypass air flows into the bypass duct before exiting with the core air flow through a common exhaust mixer.

The core air flows into the HP compressor. A bleed valve is provided to prevent surge by discharging air into the bypass duct. A supply of core air is taken from the impeller for engine cooling and sealing purposes. Core air flow exits the HP compressor through diffuser pipes that convert velocity to static pressure. The diffused air then passes to the annulus surrounding the combustion chamber liner.
The combustion chamber liner is an annular, reverse flow weldment with varying sized perforations which allow entry of the compressed air to mix with the fuel and form a combustible air/fuel mixture.

Fuel is injected into the combustion chamber through a fuel manifold and nozzle assembly with air assisted fuel nozzles. During starting, the air/fuel mixture is ignited by two igniters which protrude into the combustion chamber liner. The resultant gases expand from the combustion chamber, reverse direction and pass through the HP turbine vane ring to a single stage HP turbine. The gases then pass through the LP turbine vane ring to a single-stage LP turbine. Air exits the LP turbine through the exhaust case and exhaust mixer to mix with the bypass air flow.

The engine is controlled by a twin channel Full Authority Digital Electronic Control (FADEC) system that regulates engine operation in response to inputs from the pilot, airframe and engine mounted sensors. An engine mounted Data Collection Unit (DCU) stores specific engine information such as engine trims, cumulative engine data (number of flight legs, flight time, number of starts etc.) trend monitoring data and engine identification.

graphic.title: PW617F-E Engine Air Flow, Flanges and Main Bearings
PW617F-E Engine Main Bearings and Shafts

l1item.para: Engine Specifications and Leading Particulars - Refer to Chapter 5-10-00.
Refer to Table for engine-driven accessories leading particulars.
All engine driven accessories are mounted on the accessory gearbox and driven by a tower shaft geared to the HP rotor.
All rpm values are relative to input speeds from the HP rotor and, for the N1 speed sensor, the LP rotor as follows:

l2item.para: HP rotor - 100.4 percent N2 40200 rpm.
LP rotor - 100 percent N1 19845 rpm.

l1item.para: The engine compressor section consists of the LP rotor balancing assembly, fan case and stator assemblies, compressor case assembly, LP shaft and the HP compressor.

The LP compressor consists of a single stage fan. The fan rotor is a titanium, integrally-bladed rotor (IBR). The rotor features 15 blades. Fan balancing is achieved with counterweights screwed into the nose cone rear face.

The compressor inlet cone is constructed of aluminum, and its conical shape is designed to shed ice in icing conditions. Trim balance counterweight hole locations are on the rear face of the inlet cone balancing rim.

The fan case is constructed from high strength steel with an epoxy resin abradable liner. The fan case has 33 aluminum vanes held in place by rubber grommets and a hose clamp. The stators direct airflow to the bypass duct and the HP compressor.

The LP compressor shaft is a one piece steel shaft supported by the No. 1 and No. 2 ball bearings at the front, and the No. 5 roller bearing at the rear. Holes in the shaft allow passage of P2.5 and P3 air for pressurizing of seals and nose cone anti-icing.

A phonic ring, for measuring N1 speed, is located between the No. 2 bearing and a shoulder on the LP shaft. The phonic ring has 12 teeth with one offset gap. The tip of the N1 speed sensor aligns with the phonic ring inside the No. 2 bearing compartment.
The fabricated bearing housing assembly houses the No. 1 and No. 2 bearings.

The HP compressor consists of a mixed flow rotor (MFR) followed by a centrifugal impeller. The MFR is a titanium IBR with 16 blades. The impeller is also constructed of titanium alloy with 15 vanes and 15 splitter vanes. The intermediate stator assembly is a two row arrangement with 43 vanes in each row and is constructed from stainless steel. The HP compressor casings are constructed of steel. The MFR shroud is integral with the compressor case, and the steel impeller shroud is bolted to the compressor case. The clearances are optimized for maximum fuel efficiency throughout the operating range.

A bleed valve is used to optimize air flow between the mixed flow and centrifugal stages. The bleed valve is incorporated is a full ring slot positioned upstream of the impeller to prevent surge, and to optimize starting and handling operability. The bleed valve is operated by a fuel-driven bleed valve actuator (BVA) controlled by the EEC.

An integrated compressor case assembly (or monocase) that includes the intermediate case and the gas generator case (GGC), is the main structural case of the engine. The monocase transfer the load from the five main engine bearings to the engine mounts, and provides the pressure vessel casing for the combustion module. The intermediate case is a fabricated stainless steel sheet metal assembly that includes the outer ring, the struts, inner hub and splitter assembly, and the shroud for the HP compressor MFR. The GGC is welded to the intermediate case splitter extension, and is also a fabricated stainless steel sheet metal assembly. The front mount pads are machined on the intermediate case outer ring.
The HP diffuser case assembly bolts into the compressor case. Each of the 21 diffuser exit ducts are attached to the diffuser using a single bolt.

The combustion chamber is an annular, reverse flow design. The combustion chamber liner is fully coated with a thermal barrier coating. The liner incorporates 14 floating fuel nozzle collars. The combustion chamber is bolted to the diffuser assembly and supported by two Igniter support tubes and a single combustor support tube.

Compressor discharge air is directed from the diffuser section and discharges into the combustion chamber through metered holes where it is mixed with fuel from the fuel nozzles and ignited. The expanding gases flow forward into the domed end where they are turned inwards through 180 degrees, then through the HP turbine vane ring to the HP turbine.

A series of perforations allow air to enter the liner in a manner designed to provide the best fuel/air ratios for engine starting and sustained combustion with minimum exhaust smoke. The perforations also ensure uniform temperature distribution at the HP compressor turbine inlet.
The HP turbine module has a single stage turbine with an uncooled HP turbine disk and blades and a cooled HP turbine vane ring.

The HP rotor assembly has a standard disk and 50 coated blades secured to the disk by rivets. The HP turbine rotor assembly is connected to the HP compressor by a spline/spigot and tie rod arrangement secured by a nut aft of the turbine disk.
The HP turbine vane is an integral ring consisting of 14 airfoils. The vane airfoils are cooled with compressor discharge air with trailing edge ejection and airfoil cooling holes.

The HP turbine support case turbine case holds 14 shroud segments. The shroud segments are cooled by compressor discharge air via a single row of holes in the turbine support case. The turbine support case extends rearward to follow the contour of the interturbine duct to the LP turbine and is bolted to the GGC portion of the monocase.
The LP turbine module has a single stage turbine with an uncooled LP turbine disk and blades, an uncooled LP turbine vane ring and an exhaust duct/forced mixer assembly.

The LP rotor assembly has a standard disk and 82 blades secured to the disk by rivets . The LP turbine rotor assembly is connected to the low rotor shaft by a spline arrangement and held in place by a bolt threaded into the LP shaft.

The LP turbine vane ring assembly consists of a cast ring and 50 airfoils mated to the interturbine duct. The interturbine baffle separates the HP turbine from the LP turbine below the gas path. The LP turbine rotor shroud has a honeycomb construction and sealing is achieved via labyrinth seals on the blade tips. The turbine exhaust case and HP turbine support case are bolted to the GGC portion of the monocase.

The turbine exhaust case assembly (TEC) consists of the exhaust casing, and a forced mixer. The TEC is a mixture corrosion and fire resistance materials. The mixer efficiently merges the bypass and core air flow streams. The exhaust case incorporates the No. 5 bearing support housing and the fuel shut-off mechanism. The No. 5 bearing oil jet incorporates a last chance filter. A removable end cone allows access for inspection of the fuel shut-off mechanism and the No. 5 bearing area

The AGB consists of a cast aluminum housing that incorporates an integral oil tank and a rear cover that incorporates the oil pump. It is attached to the compressor case assembly by two support plates mounted at either side of the gearbox housing.

The AGB gear train is driven by a towershaft assembly that passes through the bottom compressor case strut. The towershaft assembly is supported by a ball bearing at the top and a roller bearing at the bottom. The towershaft has a bevel gear at each end. The upper bevel gear meshes with the bevel gear on the HP rotor shaft and the lower bevel gear meshes with the bevel gear on the starter gearshaft in the accessory gearbox.

The starter gearshaft is supported by a roller bearing at the front and a ball bearing at the rear. A plain seal (garter type) is installed at the rear end of the gearshaft. A magnetic seal assembly is installed at the front end of the gearshaft.

The starter gearshaft also incorporates an air/oil separator. Breather air passes through the breather adapter and exits rearwards through a breather tube into the engine exhaust. A spur gear on the starter gearshaft assembly provides drives for the fuel control unit and the oil pump. Oil jets, supplied with pressure oil, provide lubrication for the gears and bearings.
The engine has a composite outer bypass duct through which bypass air is propelled and discharged past a forced exhaust mixer, to atmosphere.

The duct extends from the monocase aft flange to the rear mount plane interface and is both a pressure vessel, containing fan bypass air, and primary structure, carrying the aft engine mount. It incorporates the necessary penetration and sealing features to allow services, including air, oil, fuel, and igniters, access to the engine core. These services passing through the bypass duct are conveyed via aerodynamically shaped, hollow fairings, which are connected directly to the engine gas generator case.
Fuel System (Ref. Fig.

l2item.para: The PW617F-E engine fuel system provides fuel flow to the combustion system, as well as motive flow for aircraft fuel system energization. The main components of the PW617F-E fuel system are:

l3item.para: Fuel Metering Unit (FMU)
Fuel filter with bypass valve, bypass indicator and impending bypass switch
Fuel manifold and nozzle assembly
Fuel/Oil Heat Exchanger (FOHE)
Bleed Valve Actuator (BVA)
Fuel Shut-off Valve

l2item.para: Fuel is supplied to the FMU from the aircraft fuel tank. The airframe fuel tank is divided into a main wing tank and a smaller collector tank. The primary ejector pump, driven by high-pressure motive fuel flow from the engine, delivers fuel from the collector to the FMU inlet.

In the FMU the fuel is pressurized by the two-stage boost pump, driven by the AGB drive gear. The pressurized fuel is transferred to the AGB mounted FOHE. The FOHE transfers heat from the oil system to the fuel system. A fuel filter is included in this assembly in order to protect sensitive components from possible contaminants in the fuel. Should the fuel filter blockage become too great, a bypass valve on the unit opens to ensure the engine is never starved of fuel. Following heating and filtering, the fuel is returned to the FMU via an external tube.

On return to the FMU, a high-pressure gear pump, driven by the AGB drive gear, forwards the fuel to the metering section. The proportional module provides metered fuel to an externally mounted airframe flow meter and then returned to the flow divider section of the FMU.

The flow divider controls the division of metered fuel between the primary and secondary fuel manifolds. Two tubes from the FMU deliver the primary and secondary fuel to the fuel manifold mounted in the engine combustion chamber. The manifold is divided into two branches containing 14 integral hybrid fuel nozzles.
Surplus high-pressure fuel is used to provide the hydraulic effort for the BVA and motive flow for the airframe. The BVA is connected to the FMU via two tubes (supply and return).
In the unlikely event of an LP shaft shear event, fuel is cut-off from the engine by a Fuel Shut-off Valve (FSOV) mechanism built into the FMU.
Fuel Metering Unit

l3item.para: The FMU modulates engine fuel flow through electrical inputs from the EEC in response to changes in pilot demand and ambient operating conditions. The unit contains hydro-mechanical and electro-mechanical components for adequate engine flow modulation.
The FMU performs the following major functions:

l4item.para: Division of primary and secondary flow
Engine shutdown in normal, uncontrolled thrust and shaft shear circumstances
Supply of motive fuel flow for airframe usage
Prevention of discharge of fuel after engine shutdown

l2item.para: Fuel Filter

l3item.para: The fuel filter is a cartridge type, non-cleanable full-flow filter. The filter is a paper media type supported by an aluminum spring support core and end caps.
The filter element is contained in an aluminum filter housing which is an integral part of the FOHE.

Fuel from the first stage fuel pump passes through the FOHE and then enters the fuel filter assembly. It filtrates from the outside through the element to the centre core and then exits the assembly to feed the second stage fuel pump.

l2item.para: Fuel Filter Bypass Valve

l3item.para: The fuel filter bypass valve senses the differential pressure across the filter element and it allows fuel to bypass the filter if the pressure drop across the filter exceeds the cracking pressure setting of the valve.
The bypass valve consists of a poppet stem, a compression spring, a valve body and a spring pin. The pressure pushes the poppet against the spring to open the bypass valve.
The valve is configured to ensure that contaminant trapped by the filter element during previous operation is retained during bypass operation.

l2item.para: Fuel Filter Impending Bypass Switch

l3item.para: The fuel filter impending bypass switch signals the need to replace the fuel filter to avoid operating in bypass mode.

The fuel filter impending bypass switch is installed in the FOHE module by a two-bolt flange. The switch is a normally closed type, mounted parallel to the filter. The indicator contains two sections: the electrical switch assembly and the hydraulic actuation assembly.

Pressure is applied through the high and low pressure inlets to opposite sides of a diaphragm. When the pressure differential reaches between 6 - 10 psid the mechanism actuates its internal electrical contacts moving the switch to the open state.
When the differential pressure drops below 3 psid the mechanism reverses itself resulting in the micro-switch changing back to its normally closed state.

l2item.para: Fuel Filter Bypass Indicator

l3item.para: The fuel filter bypass indicator signals the need to flush the fuel system due to opening of the bypass valve.

The fuel filter bypass indicator is installed by a threaded interface into the fuel filter housing. The indicator is a mechanical indicator with a colored button that pops up for a visual indication that the filter needs to be replaced.

Contamination increases the pressure drop across the filter, and is detected by the bypass indicator. When a delta pressure of 16 2 psid is reached this will result in a large enough gap within the indicator to break the magnetic attraction to the upper cavity indicator. The indicator's spring will then pop-up the indicator. After actuation, the indicator has to be manually reset.

l2item.para: Bleed Valve Actuator (BVA)

l3item.para: The BVA controls the position of the compressor bleed valve according to signals from the EEC.
The BVA is a bi-directional fully modulated linear actuator used to position the engines compressor bleed valve via a lever mechanism and drive-rod, it is mounted, on a bracket, on the monocase.

The BVA operates on engine fuel pressure provided by the FMU. External tubes supply the fuel to the BVA and the return drains fuel back to the FMU. The BVA incorporates screen filters at the inlet and outlet tube ports, plus screens at the inlet to the servo valve nozzle jets.

The BVA torque motor servo valve provides differential fuel pressure across the piston as commanded by the EEC to position the compressor bleed valve to optimize overall engine performance and operability.
The BVA also has an overboard drain circuit that is utilized to capture and drain leakage past the primary seals. A back-up seal prevents external leakage.

l2item.para: Fuel Manifold and Nozzles

l3item.para: The FMU has two ports (primary and secondary) for fuel delivery to the fuel manifold. The fuel is delivered through two tubes to the bottom fairing in the bypass duct and interfaces with the inlet stem of the integral fuel manifold and nozzles assembly. Independent fuel passages in the manifold inlet stem, lead to the manifold ring.

The fuel manifold assembly is protected with last chance inlet screens at the primary and secondary inlets in the inlet stem and each fuel nozzle. The distribution of the nozzles maximizes starting performance and provides uniform radial temperature distribution for the engine combustor.

All nozzles have identical pressure atomizer nozzle tips with a single fuel passage and nozzle jet and two rows of holes in the air swirler to further assist in atomizing the fuel spray into small fuel droplets.
During start, the FMU will deliver fuel to the primary manifold to provide ignition and initial spool up of the engine.

l2item.para: Fuel Oil Heat Exchanger (FOHE)

l3item.para: The FOHE is used for fuel heating and oil cooling. Heat is transferred from one fluid to another in the heat transfer matrix. The FOHE is designed to maintain the fuel temperature above freezing temperature during steady state operation by transferring engine oil heat to the fuel.
The heat transfer matrix consists of alternating fuel and oil passages. Heat is conducted from one fluid to another through the walls of the passages separating the fluids.

The FOHE is mounted on the front of the AGB and the fuel is routed from and to the FMU through two external tubes. The fuel side of the FOHE is positioned in the fuel system between low and high pressure pumps, upstream of the fuel filter. The oil side of the FOHE is in the oil feed line of the lubrication system downstream of the oil filter.

l2item.para: Fuel Shut-off Valve

l3item.para: In the unlikely event of an LP shaft shear, the LP turbine moves rearward and trips a plunger mounted in the exhaust case. The plunger is connected by a cable to the FSOV in the FMU. When the plunger is tripped and the cable is pulled, it pushes on the mechanism and causes an FMU valve to move to the cut-off position. The valve is pressure loaded and will remain in the cut-off position until a manual reset is performed.

l1item.para: Engine Control System (Ref. Fig.

l2item.para: The PW617F-E engine control system controls the engine thrust in accordance with pilot demands, ambient conditions and engine operating limits.

The PW617F-E Full Authority Digital Engine Control (FADEC) system utilizes a state of the art dual channel Electronic Engine Control (EEC) to control the engine low rotor speed (N1) and thereby the engine thrust in accordance with the position of the pilot operated thrust lever angle (TLA) and the prevailing ambient conditions. This control is accomplished in accordance with the data received by the engine located sensors, with the engine trim and airframe inputs as selected via signals from the avionics. The take-off and maximum continuous detents will maintain a target N1, based on engine and airframe inputs from the engine.
The PW617F-E FADEC system, is comprised of the following main components:

l3item.para: Electronic Engine Control (EEC)
Engine Data Collection Unit (DCU)
FMU with integrated permanent magnetic alternator (PMA) and integral AGB-driven fuel pump
Bleed Valve Actuator (BVA)
Ignition system
Engine sensors

l2item.para: The EEC is an LRU that contains the system electronics containing both channels on two separate printed circuit boards. The EEC is electrically connected via engine and airframe harnesses to input signals from the engine sensors, as well as airframe discretes and the TLA signal. Using these inputs, the EEC modulates the fuel flow by means of a torque motor in the FMU and modulates the bleed valve position by means of a torque motor in the BVA.

Each EEC channel has two connectors, one for the interface with the engine and the second for the airframe. The two channels have several formats for digital communication. ARINC 429 is used for communication with the cockpit avionics. Two separate RS422 UART ports are provided for communication with the ground support equipment (GSE) and the engine DCU. Each channel has two CANbus cross communication links for the exchange of data between individual EEC channels and between EECs for the transmission of data between engines for synchronization and fault detection purposes.
The engine control system is designed with an electrically dual redundant architecture. This means:

l3item.para: Dual EEC with crosstalk communication between EEC channels
Dual control sensors for critical inputs
Dual wiring harnesses and synthesis are used where dual connectors are not available.
Dual coils on critical solenoids and torque motors
Dual redundant hardwired discrete inputs
Dual redundant parameters output to the aircraft

l2item.para: The engine control system detects input sensor faults and output effect or faults based on both power-on and continuous health checking during operation.

The control system, when necessary, reverts to alternate input or output sources to allow continued safe operation in the event of a detected fault. If an EEC fault cannot be accommodated within the primary channel, control will be passed automatically to the other EEC channel, which is always powered and functioning in a standby mode. The system also logs faults/exceedances in non-volatile memory and the DCU for later diagnosis and/or maintenance.
The EEC software is field loadable and reprogramming can be accomplished on wing, on the ground, with the engine not running, through an accessible connection.

An engine driven PMA integrated on the FMU provides electrical power the EEC in the event that aircraft supplied power is disrupted during flight. In all conditions, the FADEC system is capable of self sustained operation once the engine achieves an N2 idle speed.

The control system is designed for Time Limited Dispatch (TLD). This allows continued dispatch with electrical failures, provided system safety is maintained. The logic for this determination is part of EEC software and is annunciated to the cockpit via the ARINC bus. The time periods allowed are determined from component reliability.

l1item.para: Engine Data Collection Unit (DCU)

l2item.para: The DCU stores the following information:

l3item.para: Engine trim (N1 and ITT)
Engine/aircraft data (engine model number, S/N, engine position, aircraft S/N)
Cumulative engine data (number of flight legs, flight time, number of starts, etc.)
EEC data (EEC P/N, S/N, software version)
Fault/Event data
Trend data
Trace recording (recording of data versus time, before and after the event)

l1item.para: Engine Wiring Harness (Ref. Fig.

l2item.para: The integrated engine electrical wiring harness provides the electrical connection from the aircraft wiring harness to various engine components. The harness includes six multi-conductor connectors that attach to the airframe harness (P8 and P9), the BVA (P13), the DCU (P36), the FMU (P10 and P11). Each connector has a unique key and label to ensure correct installation to the end device. The connectors are stainless steel with high cycle pins and four tine socket contacts. The back shells are also stainless steel. The N1 and T1 sensors are integrated into the harness. Three different size terminal lugs connect to the T6 thermocouple harness. The wires are wrapped with inner braid in double and triple groups depending on the signal types and an outer braid. The complete harness is covered by a teflon overbraid.

l1item.para: The spark ignition system has been developed to provide the engine with an ignition system capable of quick light up over a wide temperature range. The ignition system consists of one exciter unit, two individual high tension cables and two spark igniters. The system is energized from the aircraft nominal 28 volt DC supply and operates in the 8.5 to 30 volt range. The operating output voltage range is 14 to 18kV.

The ignition exciter is mounted on brackets located on the compressor case at about the 1 o'clock position (pilot's view). The exciter is a sealed unit containing electronic components encased in an epoxy resin. The unit is energized during the engine starting sequence and when selected by the pilot.

Two individual ignition cable assemblies carry the electrical energy output from the ignition exciters to the spark igniters. Each lead assembly consists of an electrical lead contained in a flexible metal braiding. Coupling nuts at each end of the assembly connect to the ignition exciter and the spark igniters.

Two spark igniters, located at 4 and 8 o'clock positions, are installed through igniter support tubes on the gas generator case and locate in the floating washer igniter housings on the combustion chamber. The igniters are in the form of a threaded plug with a central positive electrode enclosed in an annular ceramic insulating material. The electrical potential developed by the ignition exciter is applied across the gap between the central conductor and the igniter shell (ground). As this potential increases, a small current passes across the air gap. This current increases until the air between the central conductor and the shell ionizes. When ionization occurs, high energy discharges across the surface of the ceramic insulator. The spark always occurs somewhere in the annular space between the central conductor and shell.
The PW617F-E engine air system is supplied from the following sources:

l2item.para: The HP compressor hub bleed cavity (P2.8)
The HP compressor impeller bleed (P2.9)
The HP compressor discharge (P3)

l1item.para: Pressurizing Air System

l2item.para: Air from the HP compressor impeller hub pressurizes the intershaft labyrinth seal and supplies cooling air to the front face of the LP turbine. Air also continues through a set of holes in the LP shaft. Air moving forward through the hollow LP shaft, provides nose cone anti-icing via a single hole in the nose cone tip, pressurization of the No. 1 bearing across a labyrinth seal and purging of the fan trailing edge hub. Air moving rearward travels the length of the LP shaft to provide pressurization of the No. 5 bearing cavity across a labyrinth seal.

l1item.para: Impeller Bleed Air System

l2item.para: Air is bled off the HP compressor impeller to pressurize the No. 4 bearing cavity and to cool the HP turbine disc. A small quantity of air moves aft across a carbon seal, mixing with P2.8 air from the impeller hub to cool the front face of the LP turbine.

l1item.para: P3 Air System

l2item.para: Air from the compressor discharge passes around the combustor to the region of the HP turbine shroud segments. Air to cool the HP turbine vane ring passes through holes in the turbine case and into the HP turbine vanes. The rest of the air goes through other holes in the turbine case to prevent hot gas path air from getting into the HP turbine shroud segments.

l1item.para: Compressor Bleed Valve

l2item.para: The compressor is equipped with a bleed valve and a bleed valve actuator (BVA) which is hydraulically operated and is controlled by the EEC.
The BVA operates on engine fuel pressure provided by the engine FMU. External tubes supply the fuel to the BVA and the return drains fuel back to the FMU.
The BVA is a bi-directional fully modulated linear actuator used to position the engine compressor bleed valve via a lever mechanism and drive-rod, it is mounted on a bracket on the monocase.

At high engine N2 speed, in steady state, the valve is held closed for maximum efficiency. At lower engine speeds the valve is modulated open for compressor surge control. At low airspeeds, the bleed valve is modulated to maximize compressor surge margin irrespective of core speed. The air discharged by the bleed valve is directed into the bypass duct.

l1item.para: Airframe Services

l2item.para: A bleed port provides air to the aircraft air management systems, for nacelle anti-icing and cabin ventilation/pressurization. The source of the bleed air is the HP compressor discharge (P3) flow.

An air-to-air cooler is fitted to the bleed port leading to the cabin ventilation system. The cooler reduces the temperature of engine-delivered bleed air to the specified requirements at all operating conditions and altitudes. The cooler is mounted in and cooled by the bypass stream.

l1item.para: The engine indicating system consists of the N1 speed sensor, the N2 indication, T1 and T6 temperature sensors. Exhaust gas temperature (T6), together with inlet total temperature (T1) and fan speed (N1) are used to calculate a value corresponding to interturbine temperature (ITT).
Temperature Sensors

l2item.para: T1 Sensor is an integral component of the main wiring harness measures the engine inlet temperature.

The T6 system consists of a braided wiring harness and six individual thermocouple probes connected in parallel. The thermocouple probes are installed on the exhaust case and protrude into the gas path. Each probe is connected to a twin-lead output which provides connection to the electrical wiring harness at a terminal junction box on the bypass duct. For ease of identification, leads are color coded with red for alumel and yellow for chromel. To prevent inadvertent cross-connection, the lugs and terminal bolts are of different diameters, alumel being larger in diameter and slightly magnetic.

l1item.para: Speed Sensors

l2item.para: Both N1 and N2 are primary engine indicators and are transmitted to the cockpit display from each EEC channel.

The N1 speed sensor is installed at the top of the compressor case and the tip of the N1 speed sensor aligns with the phonic ring inside the No. 2 bearing compartment. The N1 speed sensor measures the engine fan speed. Fan speed (N1) is the primary control loop in the EEC that is directly related to engine thrust. The N1 value is trimmed to ensure that all engines supply rated thrust at the same TLA position. This value is recorded on the engine trim dataplate.
The N2 signal is derived from the permanent magnetic alternator (PMA) integrated in the FMU. The EEC uses HP compressor speed (N2) to control engine transient operation and governing at idle speed.

l1item.para: The lubrication system is an unregulated oil system which provides oil flow to the main shaft bearings, accessory drive gears and bearings, and main shaft squeeze film dampers. The oil level is monitored by a sight glass mounted on the AGB. Airframe supplied main oil temperature (MOT) and main oil pressure (MOP) indicators. The primary components of the lubrication system are:

l2item.para: AGB with integral oil tank
Reversible (for left/right installation) filler neck and sight glass oil level indicator
Pressure and scavenge pumps
Fuel-Oil Heat Exchanger (FOHE)
Air-cooled Oil Cooler (ACOC)
Oil Filter
Impending bypass indicator
Pressure adjusting valve (PAV)
Cold start valve (CSV)
Chip detector
Air/oil separator (breather
All tubing to and from the bearing housings

l1item.para: Pressure Oil System:

l2item.para: Pressure oil is delivered from the tank in the AGB to the main oil filter by the main oil pump. A pressure adjusting valve (PAV) is used to set the main oil pressure to the oil nozzles and to bypass excess pressure oil from the pump outlet to the inlet. A cold start valve limits the system pressure if a downstream blockage or high oil viscosity occurs.

The oil filter has a bypass valve that opens when the filter pressure drops and an impending bypass switch, to provide an early warning of a contaminated oil filter. The indicator is locked out when the oil filter temperature is below 100F to prevent false indications of filter contamination during cold oil operation.
The filtered oil is then routed to the air-cooled oil cooler (ACOC) that provides supplementary oil cooling under hot oil conditions using bypass air flow as the heat sink.

From the ACOC the oil passes to the fuel-oil heat exchanger (FOHE) that acts as the primary heat sink for the oil system. The FOHE serves a dual purpose by preventing oil over-temperature and ice crystal formation in the fuel filter.

The oil system is monitored in the airframe via main oil temperature (MOT) and main oil pressure (MOP) indications. Both parameters are measured downstream of the FOHE on the main engine feed path. Pressurized oil is distributed to the various main shaft bearings, accessory components, and squeeze film dampers via non-restrictive transfer tubes and internal passageways. Each cavity feed line is fitted with a last chance strainer to protect the oil nozzles from contamination.

l1item.para: Scavenge Oil System

l2item.para: The oil scavenge system is designed to efficiently return the oil to the oil tank from the various cavities. Each bearing cavity is sealed by positive air flow through labyrinth or controlled gap carbon seals to prevent oil leakage into the secondary air system.

The No. 1, No. 2 and No. 3 bearing cavities are scavenged by a gravity drain and high pressure sealing air which blows down though the towershaft strut passage into the AGB. The No. 4 bearing cavity has a scavenge line which relies on the high pressure sealing air to drive the oil from the bearing compartment into the gearbox. The No. 5 bearing compartment uses a dedicated scavenge pump system. The accessory gearbox scavenge pump returns oil from the bottom of the gearbox to the oil tank. A large-mesh strainer captures large sized debris upstream of the scavenge pump.
All of the AGB scavenge oil passes through a magnetic chip detector and an air/oil separator, which vents the air into the engine exhaust in the rear bypass duct.

l1item.para: Breather System

l2item.para: The oil system breather is an air/oil separator located in the AGB. The breather is a centrifugal type and separates the air from the aerated scavenged oil. The pressure difference between the AGB cavity and ambient forces the air/oil mixture to enter the breather and the separated air exits through the central shaft. Since the oil droplets are heavier than air, they are centrifuged and oil is routed back in to the AGB. The separated air is vented into the BPD just upstream of the mixer via a breather tube.

l1item.para: The fuels specified in Table, 'Approved Fuels (Unrestricted Use)' are recommended by P&WC. Airworthiness authorities normally require operators to follow these recommendations unless alternative fuels have been agreed upon between the operator and P&WC and approval by the operators airworthiness authority.
The fuels recommended have been substantiated by P&WC specifications and are Transport Canada approved.

The fuel properties specified in Table, 'Fuel Properties' are the minimum requirements that are accepted for use. As these properties only meet minimum engine requirements, the list is not intended for use as a purchase specification for procurement of fuel for P&WC commercial engines. Rather, it is intended to allow operators to include minimum approved fuel requirements for P&WC engines in conjunction with other functional requirements when formulating their own procurement specification or judging the acceptability of fuels manufactured to other national specifications that exist throughout the world.
Technical requirement tests shall be performed, in accordance with the latest issue of the listed American Society for Testing and Materials (STEM) test methods.

entry.para: NOTE: 1. Mercaptan sulfur determination may be omitted provided Doctor test in accordance with ASTM D484 is conducted and results are negative.
NOTE: 2. Fuels will be acceptable provided they meet one of the following alternative requirements or combination of requirements:

numlitem.para: Smoke point of not less than 25 mm when determined in accordance with ASTM method D1322.

Smoke point of not less than 20 mm when determined in accordance with ASTM method D1322 provided fuel does not contain more than 3.0% by volume of naphthalene as determined in accordance with ASTM D1840. Due to occasional difficulties in meeting these requirements, a waiver is in current effect which authorizes the relaxation, as necessary, in the value of minimum smoke point down to 18 mm.

l1item.para: The high temperature stability property shall be measured in an ASTM - CRC fuel coker after 5 hours of operation at conditions of 300F (149C) preheater temperatures, 400F (205C) filter temperature, and six pounds (2.72 kg) per hour fuel flow rate. Maximum pressure change shall be 3 inches (76.2 mm) Hg, and preheater deposit shall be less than Code 3 in accordance with ASTM D1660.
The Jet Fuel Thermal Oxidation Tester (JFTOT) ASTM D3241, may be used as an alternate test method to ASTM D1660.

Testing shall be conducted at 500F (260C), maximum heater tube temperature fuel system pressure: 500 psig (3447.4 kPa); fuel flow rate: 2.85 US gal/hr (3 ml/Min.): test time 150 minutes. Maximum pressure change shall be 1.0 inch (25.4 mm) Hg and preheater deposit shall be less than Code 3 in accordance with ASTM D1660.

If JFTOT test at control temperature of 500F (260C) should fail to meet specification requirements of preceding step 3, then test shall be conducted at a temperature of 473F (245C) or, tested as in preceding step 1.
The results from both the 500F and 473F (260C and 245C) Control - temperature tests must be reported by the refiner on all fuel analysis reports.

Fuel shall consist solely of hydrocarbon compounds, except as otherwise specified herein. It shall be clear and free of undissolved water, sediment, and suspended matter, and shall be suitable for use in aircraft turbine engines.
The odor of the fuel shall not be nauseating or irritating. No substances of known dangerous toxicity, under usual conditions of handling and use, shall be used.

Oxidation Inhibitors: one or a combination of the following oxidation inhibitors may be added to the basic fuel in total concentration not greater than 25 milligrams per liter (0.025 g/L) to prevent formation of gum. Refer to the following list of approved Oxidation Inhibitors:

numlitem.para: 2, 4 - Dimethyl - 6 - Tertiary - Butyl Phenol
2, 6 - Ditertiary - Butyl - 4 - Methyl Phenol
2, 6 - Ditertiary - Butyl Phenol
75% min. 2,6 - Ditertiary - Butyl Phenol; 10 - 15% 2, 4, 6 - Tritertiary - Butyl Phenol; 10 - 15% Orthothertiary - Butyl Phenol
72% min. 2,4 - Dimethyl - 6 Tertiary Butyl Phenol, 28% max. Monomethyl and Dimethyl Tertiary Butyl Phenol
60% min. 2,4 - Ditertiary - Butyl Phenol, 40% max, mixed Tertiary - Butyl Phenols

l1item.para: The following Anti-corrosion, Anti-corrosion and Lubricity Improving, Thermal Stability, Metal Deactivator, Anti-icing, Anti-Static, Anti-microbial and Leak Check additives, in addition to the approved Oxidation Inhibitors preceding, are acceptable for use in engine fuel subject to the limitations stated.

These fuel additives were approved on the basis of information received from manufacturers or suppliers of the additives. Analysis of this information and results of tests on product samples have indicated no significant adverse effect on engine materials provided the concentration does not exceed the recommended maximum.

Anti-corrosion and lubricity additives in the following tables of this sub-section are described as being primarily corrosion inhibitors, and secondarily, as lubricity improvers, to meet a U.S. Military Specification. In certain cases, it is necessary to adjust concentration of such additives to obtain necessary lubricity improvement. Only products listed in Table, 'Anti-corrosion and Fuel Lubricity Improver Additives', have been tested and approved by P&WC as both corrosion inhibitors and lubricity improvers, at the concentrations specified.
Anti-corrosion additives: the corrosion inhibitors on Table, Anti-corrosion Additives' are approved for the concentrations listed.

Anti-corrosion and Fuel Lubricity Improver Additives: The following corrosion inhibitor and fuel lubricity improver additives are approved for the concentrations listed (Ref. Table, 'Anti-corrosion and Fuel Lubricity Improver Additives',):

Extensive operation on low lubricity fuel can result in accelerated engine fuel pump wear. Until a generally accepted method of measuring and defining fuel lubricity is available, rapid fuel pump wear should be considered an indication of low lubricity fuel and dictates a change in the fuel or addition of a lubricity improver.

table.title: Anti-corrosion and Fuel Lubricity Improver Additives

l1item.para: Table, 'Thermal Stability Additives - Group A', specifies a thermal stability additive, approved for use in engine fuel, at the option of refiner, to ensure adequate high temperature stability at time of use.

The following thermal stability additives (Ref. Table, 'Thermal Stability Additives - Group B') have been shown to improve jet fuel thermal stability, and in some applications, to significantly reduce fuel nozzle coking and to improve hot section cleanliness. These additives consist of an anti-oxidant, a metal deactivator and a dispersant. They are approved for use in engine fuel, as any of the following available products, which are identical to each other, except that Turboline FS100 is available in diluted form.
Table, 'Metal Deactivator Additives', specifies an approved metal deactivator.
Any anti-icing additive which is directly equivalent to those listed in Table, 'Anti-icing Additives', is approved.

entry.para: Diethylene Glycol Monomethyl Ether as defined in MIL-I-85470B or ASTM D4171 TYPE III
Ethylene Glycol Monoethyl Ether (Fluid I) as defined in GOST 8313
Mixture of 50% Ethylene Glycol Monoethyl Ether (Fluid I) and 50% Methyl Alcohol (Fluid I-M) as defined in TU 6-10-1458

l1item.para: Table specifies approved anti-static additives.
Table specifies anti-microbial organisms additives

Airline operation: The following biocide additives may be used on a limited basis. Limited basis is defined as intermittent or non-continuous use in a single application to sterilize aircraft systems suspected or found to be contaminated by microbial organisms, such as fungi, bacteria and yeasts. For those operators, where the need for biocide use is indicated (blocked LP filters), P&WC recommends, as a guide, a dosage interval of once a month. This interval can then be adjusted, either greater or lesser, as the operator's own experience dictates.
Executive aircraft operation: The additive may be used continuously in executive aircraft where utilization is less than 1200 hours per year.

taskproc.title: Leak Check Additive - Ground Fuel Systems

l1item.para: Occasional use of a leak check additive may be required by local airport and/or environmental authorities. The leak check additive listed in Table and Table 'Leak Check Additive - Ground Fuel Systems', may be used when it has been added to the fuel for the express purpose of detecting leaks in airport fuel distribution systems.

table.title: Leak Check Additive - Ground Fuel Systems
Leak Check Additive - Ground Fuel Systems

l1item.para: Fuels listed in Table, 'Approved Fuels (Unrestricted Use)', comply with P&WC specifications and are approved for unrestricted use in PW617F-E engines.
Unless otherwise specified, the latest issue of fuel specifications applies.
An acceptable fuel or any mixture of acceptable fuels may be used.

entry.para: French Ministry of the Armed Forces
National Standards of The Peoples Republic of China

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: Contains fuel system icing inhibitor FSII.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: These designations are not specifications, therefore there are no freeze point definitions.

numlitem.label: nnp
numlitem.para: Use of a fuel lubricity improver is strongly recommended.

l1item.para: P&WC does not recommend the casual mixing of different approved brands of the same oil type or mixing of different types of oil. If deliberate oil mixing is necessary, or if inadvertent oil mixing has occurred, refer to Task 72-00-00-640-801.
Refer to Table for list of approved engine oils.

Major factors affecting oil quality over time are engine mechanical condition, climatic, atmospheric and environmental conditions, dust and sand ingestion during take-off/landing modes and engine utilization.
If an operator wishes to monitor oil quality, it is recommended that a program be established in collaboration with the operator's oil supplier/manufacturer.

The Standard and High Thermal Stability (HTS) oils listed in Table, 'Approved Lubricating Oils - PWA521, Type II (5 Centistokes)' are approved to MIL-PRF-23699F and comply with specification PWA 521, Type II Oil (5 Centistokes). These oils are fully approved for use in PW600 engines.

The term `Third Generation' is one that oil companies use to describe turbine oils which are claimed to have superior thermal and oxidative stability when compared to typical Type II, 5 centistoke oils. To ensure that there is no confusion regarding the term `Third Generation', P&WC consider approved `Third Generation' lubricants as those identified in Table, 'Approved Lubricating Oils - PWA521, Type II (5 Centistokes)' as 'Type II HTS' oils.

No other oils are approved for use in PW600 Series engines. Should the use of an oil not listed on Table, 'Approved Lubricating Oils - PWA521, Type II (5 Centistokes)' be desired, the intended user should contact Pratt & Whitney Canada, PW600 Service Engineering Department for consultation (Ref. INTRODUCTION).

table.title: Approved Lubricating Oils - PWA521, Type II (5 Centistokes)

task.title: Converting the Engine from Left to Right Side Installation

l1item.para: The following engine components must be relocated to convert an engine from a left installation to a right installation:

l2item.para: The oil filler neck assembly.
The engine wiring harness.
The engine rear mounting bracket.
The engine mount pad flight closure

caution.para: THE ENGINE HAS TWO P3 FAIRINGS. THE INBOARD P3 FAIRING HAS A P3 AIR COOLER INSTALLED AND THE OUTBOARD P3 FAIRING HAS A P3 AIR PASSAGE SPACER INSTALLED. FOR BOTH RIGHT AND LEFT ENGINES, THE P3 COOLER MUST BE AT THE INBOARD LOCATION.

THE ENGINE ELECTRONIC CONTROL (EEC) ELECTRICAL POWER MUST BE OFF DURING ENGINE REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION AND/OR WHEN THE ENGINE ELECTRICAL HARNESS IS DISCONNECTED FROM THE AIRCRAFT IN ORDER TO AVOID DAMAGE TO THE EEC. THE EEC ELECTRICAL POWER MUST REMAIN OFF WHEN THE ENGINE IS REMOVED AND/OR THE ELECTRICAL HARNESS IS DISCONNECTED FROM THE AIRCRAFT.

l2item.para: The P3 cooler.

l1item.para: If the engine is in the engine shipping container:

l2item.para: Deleted
Put the engine in the build stand.

l1item.para: If the engine is on the aircraft:

l2item.para: Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Remove the engine from the aircraft.
Put the engine in the engine build stand.

taskproc.title: Relocation of the Oil Filler Neck from LH to RH Engine

caution.para: DO NOT LEAVE THE OPEN AGB PORT EXPOSED. MASK THE OPEN AGB PORT IF THE OIL FILLER NECK ASSEMBLY RELOCATION PROCEDURE IS NOT DONE IMMEDIATELY.

l1item.para: Remove the oil filler neck assembly (Ref. Task 79-30-03-000-802) and oil tank cover (Ref. Task 79-30-03-000-803) from the AGB.
Re-install the filler neck assembly (Ref. Task 79-30-03-400-804) and oil tank over (Ref. Task 79-30-03-400-805) on the opposite side of the AGB.
Remove the engine rear mounting bracket (Ref. Task 72-70-01-000-801). Install the bracket on the opposite side of the engine (Ref. Task 72-70-01-400-802).

note.para: If the engine was removed from the shipping container, remove the engine rear mounting bracket from the bypass duct rear flange.

l1item.para: Relocate the engine mount pad flight closure to the opposite side of the engine.

taskproc.title: Relocation of the P3 Cooler from LH to RH Engine

l1item.para: Remove the P3 cooler from the left engine as follows (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Loosen the bolt (4) two turns.
Remove the bolt (5).
Remove the P3 air cooler (1) from between the P3 fairing (3) and the compressor case.
Remove and discard the two gaskets (2).

l1item.para: Install the P3 cooler on the right engine as follows (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Install the two new gaskets (1) on the P3 air cooler (2).
Install the P3 air cooler (2) between the P3 fairing (5) and the compressor case.
Lubricate the threads of the bolt (3) with (PWC06-036+)lubricating compound.
Install the bolt (3).
Torque the bolt (3) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Torque the bolt (4) 62 to 72 lb.in. (7.0-8.0 Nm).
Re-torque the bolt (3) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Re-torque the bolt (4) 62 to 72 lb.in. (7.0-8.0 Nm).

l1item.para: Do a visual inspection to make sure that the P3 cooler is installed at the inboard location and the P3 air passage spacer installed at the outboard location (Ref. Fig..

taskproc.title: Relocation of the P3 Air Passage Spacer from LH to RH Engine

l1item.para: Remove the P3 air passage spacer from the left engine as follows (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Loosen the bolt (4) two turns.
Remove the bolt (3).
Remove the P3 air passage spacer (2) from between the P3 fairing (5) and the compressor case.

note.para: Insert a suitable tool into the hole in the rear of the P3 air passage spacer to help you pull it out.

l2item.para: Remove and discard the two gaskets (1).

caution.para: WHEN INSTALLING THE P3 AIR PASSAGE SPACER BETWEEN THE P3 FAIRING AND THE COMPRESSOR CASE, MAKE SURE THAT THE P3 AIR PASSAGE SPACER PROFILE MATCHES WITH THE P3 FAIRING AND THE COMPRESSOR CASE.

l1item.para: Install the P3 air passage spacer in the right engine as follows (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Install the two new gaskets (1) on the on the P3 air passage spacer (5).
Install the P3 air passage spacer (5) between the P3 fairing (2) and the compressor case.

note.para: Do a visual inspection to make sure that the P3 air passage spacer profile matches with the P3 fairing and the compressor case (Ref. Fig..

l2item.para: Lubricate the threads of the bolt (4) with (PWC06-036+)lubricating compound.
Install the bolt (4).
Torque the bolt (4) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Torque the bolt (3) 62 to 72 lb.in. (7.0-8.0 Nm).
Re-torque the bolt (4) 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.0-3.4 Nm).
Re-torque the bolt (3) 62 to 72 lb.in. (7.0-8.0 Nm).

l1item.para: Do a visual inspection to make sure that the P3 cooler is installed at the inboard location and the P3 air passage spacer installed at the outboard location (Ref. Fig..

taskproc.title: Relocation of the Engine Wiring Harness from LH to RH Engine

l1item.para: Relocate the Channel A branch of the engine wiring harness as follows (Ref. Fig.:

note.para: When the wiring harness is placed over the engine in its neutral (unconstrained) state, the Channel A branch of the harness should be pointing up, towards the 12 o'clock position.
Use the same fastening hardware for left or right hand engine.

l2item.para: Remove bolt (1), self-locking nut (2), loop clamp (3), self-locking nut (4) and bracket (5) from Location A.

note.para: Do not loosen the loop clamp at Location C. This will reduce twisting of the harness at the other connectors.

l2item.para: Loosen the loop clamp at Location B enough to allow the harness to rotate approximately 180 degrees, across the top of the fan case.
Lubricate the threads of fan case stud using ( PWC03-001)engine lubricating oil .
Install bracket (10) on fan case stud and secure with self-locking nut (9). Torque the nut to 32 to 36 lb.in. (3.6-4.1 Nm).
Lubricate the threads of bolt (6) using (PWC03-001)engine lubricating oil.
Install loop clamp (8) on the harness at Location D. Attach the loop clamp to the angle bracket with bolt (6) and self-locking nut (9). Torque the bolt to 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Torque the loop clamps at Location B to 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

l1item.para: Relocate the Channel B branch of the engine wiring harness as follows (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Remove four bolts (1), four self-locking nuts (2) and four loop clamps (3) from Location A.
Loosen the loop clamp at Location C enough to allow the Channel B branch of the harness to pass under the ignition cable.
Position the Channel B branch of the harness on the left side of the engine (RH installation).
Lubricate the threads of bolts (4), (8) and (12) using (PWC03-001) engine lubricating oil.
Install loop clamps (6) and (7) on the harness (Ref. Detail D). Secure the loop clamps with bolt (4) and self-locking nut (5). Torque the bolt to 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install loop clamps (9) and (10) on the harness (Ref. Detail E). Secure the loop clamps with bolt (8) and self-locking nut (11). Torque the bolt to 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install loop clamps (14) and (15) on the harness (Ref. Detail F). Secure the loop clamps with bolt (12) and self-locking nut (13). Torque the bolt to 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Torque the ignition cable loop clamp at Location C to 32 to 36 lb.in. (3.6-4.0 Nm).

l1item.para: Record the engine conversion activity in the engine logbook.
Install the engine on the aircraft.

note.para: If the engine was removed from the shipping container, remove all remaining shipping covers and other shipping components.
