l1item.para: This section contains the servicing procedures applicable to the engine. The procedures are sub-divided as follows: Oil System Servicing, Fuel System Servicing, Preparation for Service or Storage, Preservation/Depreservation, Removal/Installation from/in Maintenance Stand, Configuration of the Engine for RH or LH Installation and Removal/Installation of the Engine From/Onto Aircraft.
Oil system servicing includes oil level checks, replenishing, draining, flushing and refilling and engine oil sampling.
Fuel system servicing includes engine fuel system preservation and depreservation procedures.
Preparation of the engine for service or storage involves removal or installation of the engine from its shipping container.
Preservation/depreservation procedures are included for the engine and the engine oil and fuel systems.
Configuration of the engine for RH or LH installation involves moving required components from one side of the engine to the other side.
Removal/Installation of the Engine From/Onto Aircraft refers to the Aircraft Maintenance Manual procedure and has specific engine handling information.
Not applicable.
Not applicable.
Not applicable.
Not applicable.
Not applicable.

task.title: Introduction of Approved Engine Oil of a Different Brand

l1item.para: This task gives the engine oil system servicing procedures necessary for introduction of approved engine oil of a different brand.
Not applicable

caution.para: WHEN CHANGING FROM AN APPROVED STANDARD TYPE II OIL BRAND TO AN APPROVED TYPE II HIGH THERMAL STABILITY (HTS) BRAND (REF. Task 72-00-00-800-803), P&WC STRONGLY RECOMMENDS THAT SUCH A CHANGE IS MADE WHEN THE ENGINE IS NEW OR HAS BEEN NEWLY RETURNED TO SERVICE AFTER OVERHAUL.

ADDITIVES IN "THIRD GENERATION" TYPE II (HTS) OILS BEING USED TO REPLENISH AN ENGINE WITH STANDARD TYPE II OIL, CAN CAUSE SUDDEN LIBERATION OF UNDESIRABLE AMOUNTS OF CARBON FROM OIL-LUBRICATED SURFACES INTO ENGINE OIL

l1item.para: If an operator wishes to intentionally replace the original approved engine oil brand with another approved engine oil brand of the same type, the original oil does not need to be drained and the oil system does not need to be flushed. The new oil brand can be introduced gradually during oil tank replenishment (top-up). Do the following before starting to introduce new approved oil brand:

l2item.para: Collect and analyze an engine oil sample for Total Acid Number (TAN), oil viscosity and water content (Ref. Task 72-00-00-280-801). If the oil sample limits are acceptable, continue with replenishment (top-up) procedures. If engine oil sample did not meet inspection criteria:

l3item.para: Drain all oil from the engine (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-806).
Fill the engine oil system with new oil of the original oil brand (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-805).
Continue with the replenishment (top-up) procedures.

l1item.para: Remove the engine oil filter and do a visual inspection for presence of carbon (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801), other debris and general condition. Install the original filter or replace with a serviceable filter as required.

note.para: If the engine has had less than 100 hours of operation since new or since engine overhaul, the engine oil filter does not have to be inspected or replaced.

l1item.para: Replenish the oil tank with the new brand of engine oil (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-804).
Apply a suitable label on the engine oil tank that identifies the new brand of oil.
Record introduction of the new oil brand in the engine logbook.

Remove the engine oil filter within 40 to 50 hours after introduction of the new engine oil. Do a visual inspection, paying close attention for presence of carbon particles and other debris. Refer to maintenance procedures for debris/metal particle disposition if applicable.

note.para: Additives in "THIRD GENERATION" Type II (HTS) oils being used to replenish an engine with standard Type II oil, can cause sudden liberation of undesirable amounts of carbon from oil-lubricated surfaces into engine oil.

l2item.para: If acceptable, return to the engine oil filter scheduled inspection interval (Ref. SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CHECKS', Task 05-20-00-210-801).
If loose carbon deposits cover most of the oil filter surface and inside cavity of the filter housing, discard and replace the engine oil filter. Refer to the next step.

l1item.para: Inspect the oil filter again after 40 to 60 hours of operation.

l2item.para: If acceptable, return to the engine oil filter scheduled inspection interval (Ref. SCHEDULED MAINTENANCE CHECKS', Task 05-20-00-210-801).
If carbon deposits are still found in large quantity in the oil filter element, stop replenishing the engine with the new brand of engine oil and contact a P&WC representative for further action.

l1item.para: Not applicable

task.title: Use of Unapproved Engine Oil Brands

l1item.para: This task gives the procedures necessary in the event of the use of unapproved engine oil brands or other substances.
Not applicable

caution.para: DO NOT REPLENISH OR FILL THE ENGINE OIL TANK WITH NON-APPROVED OIL BRANDS OR OILS OF NON-APPROVED VISCOSITY.

l1item.para: If oils of non-approved brands or of different viscosities become intermixed (Ref. Task 05-50-00-210-815), or if other chemical substances were inadvertently put in the engine oil tank (Ref. Task 05-50-00-210-820).
In cases where oils approved by P&WC are not available and other oils have to be substituted, an operator must obtain prior approval or recommendations for use of such oil from:

unlitem.para: Att: Manager, PW600 Service Engineering Department

l1item.para: Close the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedure to check the engine oil quantity.
Open the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

warning.para: TO REDUCE THE POSSIBILITY OF OVER-SERVICING AND TO MAKE SURE THAT READINGS ARE ACCURATE FOR OIL CONSUMPTION MEASUREMENT, CHECK THE OIL LEVEL AFTER A MINIMUM INTERVAL OF 10 MINUTES BUT NOT EXCEEDING 20 MINUTES AFTER ENGINE SHUTDOWN.

note.para: If the engine oil system is empty following a draining operation or if the engine has been newly installed after an overhaul, fill the engine oil tank before checking the engine oil level (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-805).

l1item.para: Open the nacelle servicing access door to get access to the outboard side of the engine. Refer to the AMM.
If between 10 minutes and not more than 20 minutes have passed since engine shutdown, do the following:

l2item.para: Check the engine oil level in the visual oil level indicator (2) mounted on the outboard side of the AGB.
If the engine oil level is between the "MIN" and "MAX" marks, no further action is required.
If the oil level is above the "MAX" mark, drain some oil to bring it below the "MAX" mark.

If engine oil level is visible and below the "MIN" mark on the visual oil level indicator (2) and there is no evidence of excessive oil consumption (Ref. 72-00-01, FAULT ISOLATION, Task 72-00-01-810-801), replenish the engine oil tank to bring the oil level between the "MIN" and "MAX" marks on the oil level visual indicator. Refer to Task 72-00-00-640-804.
If the engine oil level is not visible in the visual oil level indicator (2), do the following:

l3item.para: Check the engine for external oil leaks and do repairs as necessary.
Replenish the engine oil tank if no evidence of an external oil leak was found. Refer to Task 72-00-00-640-804.

l1item.para: If more than 20 minutes has passed since engine shutdown, do the following:

l2item.para: Check the engine oil level in the visual oil level indicator (2) mounted on the outboard side of the AGB.
If the engine oil level is between the "MIN" and "MAX" marks, no further action is required.
If the oil level is above the "MAX" mark, drain some oil to bring it below the "MAX" mark.

If the oil level is below the "MIN" mark, carry out a ground run at stabilized GROUND IDLE for five minutes. Wait a minimum of 10 minutes but not exceeding 20 minutes and then re-check the oil level in the visual oil level indicator (2).

l1item.para: Close the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedures to top up the engine oil tank.
Open the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

caution.para: DO NOT MIX DIFFERENT TYPES OF OIL SINCE THEIR DIFFERENT CHEMICAL STRUCTURES MAY MAKE THEM INCOMPATIBLE. DO NOT MIX DIFFERENT BRANDS OF OIL OTHER THAN THE APPROVED BRANDS AND LIMITATIONS DEFINED IN Task 72-00-00-640-801.

l1item.para: Remove the oil tank filler cap (1) (Ref. Task 79-30-03-000-801.
Add (PWC03-001)engine lubricating oil to the oil tank to between the MIN and MAX marks on the visual oil level indicator (2).
Install and lock the oil filler cap (Ref. Task 79-30-03-400-801).
Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810).
Do a ground run at stabilized GROUND IDLE for five minutes.
Shut the engine down (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-811).

Check engine oil level in the visual oil level indicator (2) a minimum of 10 minutes but not exceeding 20 minutes after engine has been shut down (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-803). If the engine oil level is visible and between the MIN and MAX marks on the visual oil level indicator (2) no further action is required.

If the oil tank contents are below the MIN mark in the visual oil level indicator (2) and excessive oil consumption is seen or suspected, do the Fault Isolation procedure for High Oil Consumption (Ref. Task 72-00-01-810-829).
Close the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedures necessary to fill the engine oil system.
Open the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

caution.para: DO NOT MIX DIFFERENT TYPES OF OIL SINCE THEIR DIFFERENT CHEMICAL STRUCTURES MAY MAKE THEM INCOMPATIBLE. DO NOT MIX DIFFERENT BRANDS OF OIL OTHER THAN THE APPROVED BRANDS AND LIMITATIONS DEFINED IN Task 72-00-00-640-801.

note.para: Use this procedure if the engine oil system is empty.

l1item.para: Make sure that the chip detector assembly and the oil tank drain plug are correctly installed and secured.
Remove and replace the oil filter element if required (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801).
Remove the oil tank filler cap (1) from the oil tank filling port on the AGB (Ref. Task 79-30-03-000-801).
Add (PWC03-001) engine lubricating oil to bring engine oil level to "MAX" mark on the visual oil level indicator (2).
Install and lock the oil tank filler cap in the oil tank filling port on the AGB (Ref. Task 79-30-03-400-801).
Start the engine and do a ground run at stabilized GROUND IDLE speed for five minutes.
Shut the engine down.
Check for engine oil leaks.
Check the engine oil level a minimum of ten minutes but not exceeding 20 minutes after engine shutdown (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-803). Replenish as required (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-804).
Close the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedures necessary to drain the engine oil system.
Open the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Put suitable containers or drip pan under engine.
Remove the oil filler cap from oil tank filling port on the AGB (Ref. Task 79-30-03-000-801).
Remove the oil tank drain plug (3) from the bottom of the accessory gearbox. Remove and discard the preformed packing (4).
Remove the chip detector assembly (2) from the AGB as follows:

l2item.para: Remove the magnetic chip detector (Ref. Task 79-30-01-000-801).
Remove the chip detector valve.

l1item.para: If necessary, remove the existing oil filter element from the oil filter housing (1) and drain the residual oil (Ref. Task 79-20-01-000-801). Do the inspections for the oil filter housing cover and the oil filter.
Allow engine oil to fully drain from the engine.
Install the magnetic chip detector self-closing valve (Ref. Task 79-30-01-400-801).
Install the magnetic chip detector.
Install the oil tank drain plug (3) as follows:

l2item.para: Lubricate a new preformed packing (4) with (PWC03-001)engine oil and install it on the oil tank drain plug (3).
Lubricate the oil tank drain plug (3) threads with (PWC03-001) engine oil and install it in port in the AGB. Torque the drain plug to 40 to 50 lb.in. (4.6-5.7 Nm.).
Secure the oil tank drain plug (3) with (PWC05-344)safety cable using crimper (PWC90025) crimper.

l1item.para: Install and lock the oil filler cap in the AGB oil tank filling port (Ref. Task 79-30-03-400-801).
If the oil filter element was inspected and found to be unserviceable, install a replacement oil filter element (Ref. Task 79-20-01-400-801).

graphic.title: Locations of Engine Oil Drain Ports

l1item.para: Close the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedures necessary to flush the engine oil system.
Open the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

note.para: If an engine oil system has been contaminated by other than metallic matter, the oil system must be flushed.

l1item.para: Drain the engine oil (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-806).
Fill the oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-805).
Start the engine (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-810) and run at GROUND IDLE for five minutes.
Do the engine shutdown procedure (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-811).
Drain the engine oil (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-806).
Fill the oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-805).
Close the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
This task gives the procedures necessary to collect and analyze an engine oil sample.
Open the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM
Engine oil sampling and inspection is recommended if visual inspection shows oil is very dark and/or has an unusual odor, and/or exhibits other abnormal properties.

note.para: As oil deteriorates, the color becomes black and a strong harsh odor is given off. This is not a reason to change the oil, but the oil should be analyzed.

l1item.para: Prepare to take an engine oil sample as follows:

l2item.para: Obtain the sample within 20-30 minutes of engine shutdown.

If the engine is cold, start the engine and do ground run until engine oil temperature is 70C (158F) minimum (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-804) before obtaining an oil sample to analyze. Shut the engine down.

l1item.para: Take a sample of engine oil from the oil tank drain port (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-806). Drain and discard one cup of oil from the tank before collecting the final sample. Collect one 100 - 125 ml sample of engine oil into a clean glass container.
Have the engine oil sample analyzed for Total Acid Number (TAN) by one of the two methods following:

l2item.para: Send the sample to an approved laboratory to analyze the engine oil sample for Total Acid Number (TAN), water content and change in viscosity. Refer to Task 79-20-01-280-801 for a list of laboratories.
Use a Titra-Lube TAN Test Kit (P/N TI-TAN) to analyze the oil. The kit can be obtained from the following address or contact a local distributor for availability of the kit:

l1item.para: The limits are as follows:

unlitem.para: Viscosity: change in viscosity of the drained oil sample must not be less than -10% or more than + 25% when compared to a reference unused sample of oil of the same brand when measured at the same temperature.

note.para: The value of TAN in unused oil conforming to specification varies, depending on brand and manufacturer.

l1item.para: Close the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

task.title: Use of Blue Oil Dye in Engine Oil

l1item.para: This task gives the procedures for the use of blue oil dye in engine oil system to improve oil level visual indication and aid in the detection of oil leaks.
Not applicable

(PWC05-372)Blue oil dye may be added to any P&WC approved lubricating oil on a one-time basis when filling the system. The dye improves oil level visual indicator visibility and aids in the detection of oil leaks.
Use 0.122-0.171 milliliters per liter, or 0.462-0.647 milliliters per U.S. gallon of oil. The maximum concentration must not exceed 0.171 milliliters per liter, or 0.647 milliliters per U.S. gallon.
The dye is blue in color, however, when mixed with some oils which are yellow in color, the result may be green colored oil.
Not applicable
The following are the approved procedures necessary to store and maintain the engine in the shipping container.
Not applicable

caution.para: DO NOT USE (PWC69262)ENGINE SLING TO LIFT THE ENGINE WHILE IT IS IN THE CONTAINER
DO NOT STACK LOADS ON TOP OF THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: The shipping container consists of a fiberboard box and lid and a metal cradle on a wood base. The container is intended for domestic shipment in a closed conveyance on the North American continent or for overseas shipment by air. It is not intended for shipment by sea.

caution.para: DO NOT STACK LOADS ON TOP OF THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: The container is weather resistant only and should not be exposed to climatic conditions for more than seven days. It must not be used for outdoor storage. The shipping container offers protection against corrosion for a period of up to six months, provided that the container is correctly sealed and sheltered indoors in relatively dry area and the color of the humidity indicator is monitored every 15 days.
To maintain internal conditions within the protective envelope, at a safe humidity level for storage, eight bags of desiccant material are placed in the protective envelope.

A humidity indicator is installed within the protective envelope and is visible through a window in the shipping container. The moisture level can thus be checked without disturbing the container or its contents. At a safe humidity level (up to 40% relative humidity), the indicator color is blue. As humidity increases, the color gradually changes to pink. An all pink color indicates that an unsafe moisture condition has been reached. The desiccant must then be replaced with freshly activated bags.

taskproc.title: Reactivation of Desiccant and Humidity Indicator

l1item.para: Place the bags of desiccant and the humidity indicator in a suitable oven controlled at 250F (121C). The humidity indicator may be removed when an all blue color has been attained. The desiccant bags should remain in the oven for two hours minimum.
Allow the oven to cool to room temperature (approximately 72F (22C) and then remove the bags and the indicator as applicable.
Immediately place the desiccant bags in airtight polyethylene envelopes. Exclude all air and heat-seal the envelopes.

note.para: The desiccant bags must be removed from polyethylene bags prior to installation in the engine shipping/storage container.

l1item.para: Not applicable

task.title: Removal of the Engine from the Shipping Container

l1item.para: This task gives the procedures for removing the engine from the shipping container.
When an engine is to be removed from the shipping container, the following precautions must be taken:

l2item.para: Make sure that a hoist of sufficient lifting capacity, plus safety factor, is available to lift loads as follows:

numlitem.para: 375.5lb. (170.3 kg.) when lifting the engine and ( PWC69262)sling.
770.5 lb. (349.5 kg.) when lifting the engine in the shipping container.

l1item.para: Make sure that container or engine is positioned correctly on floor, directly beneath hoist.
Make sure that free overhead space of at least seven feet is available, exclusive of distance from top of container or engine to hook.
Suspend the (PWC69262)engine sling on a suitable hoist over the engine shipping container.

caution.para: DO NOT REMOVE THE CONE LOCKING BRACKET FROM THE FAN CASE UNTIL THE ENGINE REQUIRED FOR INSTALLATION ON THE AIRCRAFT.
IF THE ENGINE IS DROPPED IN THE CONTAINER OR OTHERWISE, REFER TO Task 05-50-00-210-807.

l1item.para: Remove the shipping container strapping ( 5, (Ref. Fig. cover (1) and sleeve (6) .
Cut the protective envelope and expose the top of the engine.
Remove the engine rear mount bracket (Ref. Task 72-70-01-000-801).
Install the (PWC69357)lifting bracket ( 6, (Ref. Fig.. Secure the bracket with eight washers (7), four bolts (5) and four nuts (8). Torque the nuts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm) .

note.para: A front lifting bracket is already installed on the engine.

l1item.para: Attach the (PWC69262)engine sling to the two engine lifting brackets.

caution.para: DO NOT LIFT THE ENGINE IF IT IS ATTACHED TO THE SHIPPING CRADLE.

l1item.para: Take the weight of the engine on the sling and make sure the engine is in the horizontal attitude.
Remove the two receiver caps ( 8, (Ref. Fig. and the four quick release pins (7) .

caution.para: DO NOT LET THE ENGINE CONTACT THE SHIPPING CRADLE DURING REMOVAL.

l1item.para: Lift the engine and move it away of the shipping container.
Remove one engine mount bracket (9) (Ref. Fig., four bolts (11) and four washers (10) from each of the two engine mount pads.
Remove one shipping bracket (4), four bolts (3), four nuts (1) and four washers (2) from the bypass duct at the 4 o'clock and at the 8 o'clock positions.
Install the engine on the (PWC56096) maintenance stand (Ref. Task 72-00-00-410-802).
Remove the eight desiccant bags from the engine.
Install the engine rear mount bracket (Ref. Task 72-70-01-400-801) for a left engine installation or for a right engine installation (Ref. Task 72-70-01-400-802).
Remove the shipping caps, covers and plugs from the electrical wiring harness (Ref. Task 72-00-00-530-801) except for the cover and tie wrap on the T1 sensor.

note.para: The cover and tie wrap on the T1 sensor will be removed when the inlet cowl is installed.

l1item.para: Remove the remaining shipping caps, covers and plugs except for the intake and exhaust covers.

note.para: The intake and exhaust covers will be removed prior to installation on the aircraft.

l1item.para: Store all the shipping caps, covers and plugs with the shipping container.
Remove the engine components from the shipping container and keep them with the engine.

graphic.title: Removal of the Strapping from the Shipping Container
Removal of the Engine Lifting and Mounting Brackets
Removal of the Engine from the Shipping Container

l1item.para: Remove envelopes containing shipping and engine documents from the shipping container.
Remove bags of desiccant and retain for reactivation and reuse.

task.title: Installation of the Engine in the Shipping Container

l1item.para: This task gives the procedures for installing the engine in the shipping container.
When an engine is to be installed in a shipping container, the following precautions must be taken:

l2item.para: Make sure that a hoist of sufficient lifting capacity, plus safety factor, is available to lift loads as follows:

numlitem.para: 375.5lb. (170.3 kg.) when lifting the engine and ( PWC69262)sling.
770.5 lb. (349.5 kg.) when lifting the engine in the shipping container.

l1item.para: Install the shipping caps, covers and plugs (Ref. Task 72-00-00-530-802).
Make sure the container is clean and dry.
Make sure the container or engine is positioned correctly on floor, directly beneath the hoist.
Make sure that free overhead space of at least seven feet is available, exclusive of distance from top of container or engine to hook.
Make sure the engine shipping container is serviceable.

caution.para: IF THE ENGINE IS DROPPED IN THE CONTAINER OR OTHERWISE, REFER TO Task 05-50-00-210-807.

l1item.para: Prepare the shipping container as follows (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Remove the cover (1) and the sleeve (2) from the cradle (3).
Remove the two pins (7) and the two engine mount brackets (6) from the cradle (3).
Remove the two pins (5) and the two duct mount brackets (4) from the cradle (3).

l1item.para: Prepare the engine for the shipping container as follows (Ref. Fig.:

l2item.para: Lubricate the eight bolts (3) threads with (PWC06-004)anti-seize compound

Install one shipping bracket (4), four bolts (3), four washers (2) and four nuts (1) on the bypass duct at the 4 o'clock and 8 o'clock positions. Torque the bolts 110 to 120 lb.in. (12.5-13.5 Nm.). Torque the bolts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Install the (PWC69357)lifting bracket (6). Secure the bracket with eight washers (7), four bolts (5) and four nuts (8). Torque the nuts 36 to 40 lb.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

note.para: A front lifting bracket is already installed on the engine.

l2item.para: Lubricate the eight bolts (11) threads with (PWC03-001)engine oil
Install one engine mount bracket (9), four washers (10) and four bolts (11) on each of the two engine mount pads. Torque the bolts 110 to 120 lb.in. (12.5-13.5 Nm.).

l1item.para: Install the engine in the container as follows (Ref. Fig..

l2item.para: Install the (PWC69262)engine sling on a suitable hoist.
Attach the (PWC69262)engine sling to the two engine lifting brackets.
If necessary, put a new protective plastic envelope in the shipping container with the gaskets aligned to mounting brackets.
Put the relevant engine documents in a waterproof envelope and put them in the shipping container.
Lift the engine and lower it into the engine shipping container aligning the holes in the mount brackets (4, Ref. Fig. and (6) with the holes in the cradle (3) brackets.
Install the four quick release pins (5) and (7) facing rearwards and install receiver caps (8) on the two quick release pins.
Remove the (PWC69262)engine sling.
Install the engine shipping closures.
Install the shipping container humidity indicator. Tighten the indicator with your hand, sandwiching the protective envelope between the rubber washers.
Attach the eight desiccant bags to the engine, evenly distributed along the length of the engine.
Position the protective envelope so that the data plates can be read through the container window.
Heat seal the protective envelope.
Cut a corner in the protective envelope big enough for a vacuum nozzle.
Remove all the air from the protective envelope with a vacuum cleaner then heat seal the open corner of the envelope.
Fold the protective envelope neatly so that the humidity indicator can be seen through the container window.
Make sure the data plates and the humidity indicator can be seen through the container window. Use adhesive tape to stop the protective envelope from moving.
Install the shipping container sleeve ( 6, Ref. Fig.) and cover (1) using strapping (5) and sixteen corners (3).
Write the engine serial number and the date on the container.

graphic.title: Installation of the Engine Lifting and Mounting Brackets
Installation of the Strapping on the Shipping Container

l1item.para: Not applicable

task.title: Removal of the Engine Shipping Caps, Covers and Plugs

l1item.para: The following are the approved procedures necessary to remove the engine shipping closures.
Not applicable.

taskproc.title: Engine Shipping Caps, Covers and Plugs

note.para: The following procedures apply to both right and left engines, unless otherwise stated.

l1item.para: Remove the cap from the fuel filter impending bypass switch connector.
Remove the cap, cover and wing nuts from the MOP/MOT sensor.
Remove the four wing nuts and the protective cover from the AGB starter-generator mount pad.
Remove the caps from each of the two ignition exciter forward (input) electrical connectors.
Remove the cap from the starter-generator seal drain port.
Remove the cap from the FMU fuel drain port.
Remove the cap from the chip detector.
Remove the cap from the combustion chamber fuel drain port.
Remove the engine inlet cover from the LP compressor case.
Remove the shipping bag from the exhaust case.
Remove the cap from the bleed valve actuator drain port.
Remove the cap from the cabin bleed ports.
Remove the cap from the FMU fuel inlet port.
Remove the cap from the FMU motive flow port.
Remove the plugs from each of the two fuel flowmeter tubes.
Remove the tie wrap securing the forward engine wiring harness aircraft connector cable to the T1 sensor.
Remove the tie wrap securing the other engine wiring harness aircraft connector cable to the adjacent tube.
Remove the tape and unwrap the plastic cushioning material from the two engine wiring harness aircraft electrical connectors and the T1 sensor.
Remove the caps from each of the two engine wiring harness aircraft electrical connectors.
Remove the cap from the T1 sensor
Not applicable

graphic.title: Engine Shipping Caps, Covers and Plugs

task.title: Installation of Engine Shipping Caps, Covers and Plugs

l1item.para: The following are the approved procedures necessary to select and install the engine shipping closures.
Install the engine on the (PWC56096) build stand (Ref. Task 72-00-00-410-802).
Refer to the PW617F-E Engine Illustrated Parts Catalog P/N 3072164, 72-00-00, Engine Shipping Container, to select correct shipping closures.
Remove the starter-generator from the engine AGB mount pad. Refer to the AMM.

taskproc.title: Engine Shipping Caps, Covers and Plugs

note.para: The following procedures apply to both right and left engines, unless otherwise stated.

l1item.para: Put a cap on the fuel filter impending bypass switch connector.
Put a cap on the MOP/MOT sensor.
Lubricate the threads of the four studs on the AGB starter-generator mount pad with (PWC03-001)engine oil .
Put the protective cap on the AGB starter-generator mount pad and secure it with four wing nuts. Tighten the nuts with your hand.
Put one cap on each of the two ignition exciter forward (input) electrical connectors.
Put a cap on the starter-generator seal drain port.
Put a cap on the FMU fuel drain port.
Put a cap on the chip detector.
Put a cap on the combustion chamber fuel drain port.

caution.para: MAKE SURE THE CONE LOCKING BRACKET IS ATTACHED TO THE FAN CASE BEFORE INSTALLING THE INLET SHIPPING COVER.

l1item.para: Put the engine inlet cover on the LP compressor case.
Put the shipping bag on the exhaust case.
Put a cap on the bleed valve actuator.
Put a cap on the cabin bleed ports.
Put a cap on the FMU fuel inlet port.
Put a cap on the FMU motive flow port.
Put a plug in each of the two fuel flowmeter tubes.
Install one cap on each of the two engine wiring harness aircraft electrical connectors.
Wrap plastic cushioning material around the two engine wiring harness aircraft electrical connectors and attach with tape.
Put a cap on the T1 sensor
Wrap plastic cushioning material around the T1 sensor and attach with tape.
Secure the forward engine wiring harness aircraft connector cable to the T1 sensor with a tie wrap.
Secure the other engine wiring harness aircraft connector cable to an adjacent tube with a tie wrap.
Not applicable

graphic.title: Engine Shipping Caps, Covers and Plugs

l1item.para: The following are the approved engine procedures necessary for shipping the engine in the shipping container.
Put the engine in the shipping container (Ref. Task 72-00-00-530-803).

The engine shipping container is intended for domestic shipment in a closed conveyance on the North American continent or for overseas shipment by air. It is not intended for shipment by sea. To prevent possible bearing damage such as brinelling, use of a shipping container/skid with shock mounts is required for all transportation.
Not applicable
The following gives the approved engine preservation schedule.
Not applicable.

The procedure to be followed for the preservation of engines in service depends on the period of inactivity and whether or not the engine may be rotated during the inactive period (engines installed in aircraft only). The expected period of inactivity should be established and reference made to the Engine Preservation Schedule. The preservation carried out should be recorded in the engine log book and on tags secured to the engine. If the engines are preserved on the aircraft, put a placard indicating the engine preservation activity in the aircraft cockpit.

0 to 7 days - Engines may be left in an inactive state, with no preservation protection, provided the engine is sheltered, humidity is not excessively high and the engine is not subjected to extreme temperature changes which would produce condensation.

8 to 28 days - Engines inactive for up to 28 days require no preservation provided all engine openings are sealed off and relative humidity in the engine is maintained at less than 40 percent. Humidity control is maintained by placing desiccant bags and humidity indicators on wooden racks in engine exhaust duct. Suitable windows must be provided in exhaust closure to facilitate observation of the humidity indicators.
29 to 90 days:

l2item.para: Preserve the engine fuel system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-620-802).
Put covers in the engine intake and exhaust openings. Refer to the AMM.
Install desiccant bags and humidity indicators.

caution.para: UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES SHOULD PRESERVATIVE OIL BE SPRAYED INTO THE COMPRESSOR OR THE TURBINE ENDS OF ENGINES. DIRT PARTICLES DEPOSITED ON BLADES AND VANES COULD ADHERE AND ALTER THE AIRFOIL SHAPE, ADVERSELY AFFECTING ENGINE EFFICIENCY.

l1item.para: 90 days and over:

l2item.para: Engines inactive over 90 days in the airframe or removed for long term storage in a container, must, in addition to 29 and 90 day procedures, have the engine oil system drained. Refer to Task 72-00-00-640-806.
Remove cover plates from unused AGB accessory drive pads and spray exposed surfaces and gearshafts with (PWC03-001)engine oil. Replace the cover plates.

l1item.para: Not applicable.

task.title: Preservation of the Engine Fuel System

l1item.para: The following are the procedures necessary to preserve the engine fuel system.

note.para: The engine fuel system must be preserved while the engine is installed on the aircraft.

l1item.para: Remove the engine cowlings as required. Refer to the AMM.
Install the (PWC69328)preservation rig on the engine outboard lower mount pad on the LPC case assembly:

note.para: Refer to the Fuel System Preservation - Without Aircraft Electrical Power procedure if electrical power is not available to the aircraft.

l2item.para: Remove the cover from the engine outboard lower mount pad.
Apply (PWC03-001)engine oil on the threads of the four double-hex bolts.
Attach the preservation rig adapter to the engine outboard lower mount pad with the four double-hex bolts and the four washers. Torque the bolts to 150 to 170 lb.in (17.0 - 19.6 Nm).
If required, attach the preservation rig to the container assembly mounting plate with the four socket-headed capscrews, washers and nuts.

taskproc.title: Fuel System Preservation - Using Aircraft Electrical Power

caution.para: EXTREME CARE MUST BE TAKEN TO PREVENT FOREIGN MATERIAL FROM BEING DRAWN INTO THE ENGINE FUEL SYSTEM. EQUIPMENT MUST BE SUPPLIED WITH SUITABLE FILTERS NO COARSER THAN 10 MICRON RATING.

numlitem.para: The following procedures apply to engines inactive for more than 28 days.
Use this procedure when aircraft electrical power can be applied to the engine.

l1item.para: Fill the (PWC69328)engine preservation rig with clean (PWC05-077)preservative oil.
Disconnect the motive flow fuel line from the connector on the engine FMU motive flow port (5). Refer to the AMM.
Install a threaded cap on the FMU motive flow port connector (5).
Disconnect and remove the primary (Ref. Task 73-10-01-000-804) and secondary fuel tubes (1) and (2) (Ref. Task 73-10-01-000-805).
Install a preformed packing on each of the two ( PWC69449)drain tubes .
Connect the (PWC69449)drain tube to the connector at the FMU PRIMARY fuel outlet (3). Refer to Task 73-10-01-400-804 for torque values.
Connect the (PWC69449)drain tube to the connector at the FMU SECONDARY fuel outlet (4). Refer to Task 73-10-01-400-805 for torque values.
Disconnect the airframe fuel supply line to the FMU fuel inlet port (6) (Refer to the AMM). Install suitable caps on the airframe fuel supply line and the FMU fuel inlet port.
Connect the (PWC69328)engine preservation rig to the FMU fuel inlet port (6). Refer to the AMM for connector torque value.

caution.para: OBSERVE THE STARTER MOTOR OPERATING LIMITS.

l1item.para: Do a 30-second wet motoring run and make sure that residual fuel and clean preservative oil flows from the primary fuel drain tube. Repeat, if necessary.

note.para: The secondary fuel drain tube may not drain any residual fuel/preservative oil.

l1item.para: Shut off the supply of preservative oil.
Disconnect the (PWC69328) engine preservation rig from the connector at the FMU fuel inlet port (6).
Remove the caps on the airframe fuel supply line and the FMU fuel inlet port and connect the aircraft fuel supply to the FMU fuel inlet port (6). Refer to the AMM.

note.para: This step is required unless the engine is to be removed from the aircraft immediately.

l1item.para: Remove the cap from the FMU motive flow outlet port (5) and connect the aircraft motive flow fuel line. Refer to the AMM.

note.para: This step is required unless the engine is to be removed from the aircraft immediately.

l1item.para: Disconnect and remove the (PWC69449) drain tubes from the FMU PRIMARY and SECONDARY fuel outlets (3) and (4).
Install the primary fuel tube (1) (Ref. Task 73-10-01-400-804) and secondary fuel tubes (2) (Ref. Task 73-10-01-400-805).
Check the engine for external leaks.

graphic.title: Preservation of the Engine Fuel System

taskproc.title: Fuel System Preservation - Without Aircraft Electrical Power

caution.para: EXTREME CARE MUST BE TAKEN TO PREVENT FOREIGN MATERIAL FROM BEING DRAWN INTO THE ENGINE FUEL SYSTEM. EQUIPMENT MUST BE SUPPLIED WITH SUITABLE FILTERS NO COARSER THAN 10 MICRON RATING.

numlitem.para: The following procedures apply to engines inactive for more than 28 days.
Use this procedure when no electrical power can be applied to the engine.

l1item.para: Prepare a source of clean (PWC05-077) preservative oil and a suitable container to collect drained fuel and preservative oil.
Remove the FMU from the engine. Refer to Task 73-20-01-000-801.
Drain as much fuel from the FMU assembly as possible.
Pour clean (PWC05-077)preservative oil filtered to 10 microns into all open FMU ports except the outboard (OBD) port.
Drain as much (PWC05-077)preservative oil from the FMU control assembly as possible.
Install the FMU on the engine. Refer to Task 73-20-01-400-801.
Check the FMU installation for leaks.
Disconnect and remove the (PWC69328) preservation rig or the (PWC60863)preservation rig if used.
Record the fuel system preservation in the engine logbook and put a placard in the aircraft cockpit indicating the engine preservation activity.
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

task.title: Preservation of the Engine Oil System

l1item.para: The following are the approved procedures necessary to preserve the engine oil system.
Not applicable.
Drain the engine oil system, including the oil filter housing (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-806).
Record the oil system preservation in the engine logbook. If the engines are preserved on the aircraft, put a placard in the aircraft cockpit indicating the engine preservation activity.
Not applicable.
The following gives the approved engine depreservation schedule.
Not applicable.
0 to 7 days - No depreservation required.
8 to 28 days:

l2item.para: Remove desiccant and moisture barriers.
Ensure that all previously sealed engine openings are reopened and are unobstructed.

l1item.para: 29 to 90 days:

l2item.para: Remove the engine intake and exhaust covers.
Remove the desiccant and humidity indicators.
Depreserve the engine fuel system.

l1item.para: 91 days and over:

l2item.para: The engine must be completely depreserved.
The lubrication system must be serviced.

l1item.para: Not applicable.

task.title: Depreservation of the Engine Fuel System

l1item.para: The following gives the approved engine fuel system depreservation procedure.
Install the engine on the aircraft. Refer to the AMM.
0 to 7 days - No depreservation required.
8 to 28 days - Desiccant and moisture barriers must be removed. Ensure that all previously sealed engine openings are reopened and are unobstructed.
29 to 90 days - Remove the engine intake and exhaust covers together with the desiccant and humidity indicators. Depreserve the engine fuel system.
91 days and over - The engine must be completely depreserved and the lubrication system serviced.

graphic.title: Depreservation of the Engine Fuel System

l1item.para: Prepare a suitable container to collect residual preservative oil and fuel.
Remove the FMU PRIMARY fuel tubes (1) (Ref. Task 73-10-01-000-804) and SECONDARY fuel tubes (2) (Ref. Task 73-10-01-000-805).
Install a preformed packing on each of the two ( PWC69449)drain tubes.
Connect one (PWC69449)drain tube to the connector at the FMU PRIMARY fuel outlet (3). Refer to Task 73-10-01-400-804 for torque values.
Connect one (PWC69449)drain tube to the connector at the FMU SECONDARY fuel outlet (4). Refer to Task 73-10-01-400-805 for torque values.
Connect the aircraft fuel supply to the FMU fuel inlet port (6).

note.para: Do not connect the aircraft motive flow line to the FMU motive flow port (5) until after the depreservation procedure.

l1item.para: Make sure that the FMU motive flow port (5) is capped.

caution.para: OBSERVE THE STARTER MOTOR OPERATING LIMITS.

l1item.para: Do a 30-second wet motoring run and observe that fuel is flowing from the primary fuel drain tube. Repeat, if necessary.

note.para: The secondary fuel drain tube may not produce any preservative oil/fuel.

l1item.para: Remove the blanking cap from the FMU motive flow port (5).
Install the aircraft motive flow line on the FMU motive flow port connector (5). Refer to the AMM.
Remove the two (PWC69449) drain tubes from the FMU PRIMARY and the SECONDARY fuel outlets (3) and (4).
Install the primary fuel tube (1) (Ref. Task 73-10-01-400-804) and secondary fuel tube (2) (Ref. Task 73-10-01-400-805).
Check the engine for external leaks.
Record the fuel system depreservation activity in the engine logbook and remove the placard from the aircraft cockpit indicating the engine preservation activity.
Not applicable.

task.title: Depreservation of the Engine Oil System

l1item.para: The following gives the approved engine oil system depreservation procedure.
Not applicable
Fill the engine oil tank with approved (PWC03-001)engine lubricating oil (Ref. Task 72-00-00-640-805).

note.para: The engine lubricating oil system does not require any further depreservation procedures.

l1item.para: Record depreservation activity in the engine logbook and remove the placard from the aircraft cockpit indicating the engine preservation activity.

task.title: Installation of the Engine on the Build Stand

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for installing the engine on the build stand.
Make sure a clear overhead space of at least eight feet (2.44 meters) is available, not including distance from top of engine to hoist hook.
Make sure the (PWC56096)build stand is directly below the hoist and the engine handling sling.
Lock the transport wheels and the gearbox hand wheel on the (PWC56096)build stand .
Install the engine rear lifting bracket (Ref. Task 72-00-00-540-801).

graphic.title: Installation of Engine on Build Stand

caution.para: DO NOT ALLOW ENGINE TO CONTACT ANY PART OF ENGINE BUILD STAND AS IT IS LOWERED INTO POSITION.

note.para: Engines received from P&WC approved overhaul facilities following scheduled overhaul are shipped as left (port side) engines.

l1item.para: Remove the two upper and lower (PWC69045) engine mounts (5) and (12) from the ( PWC68607)yoke (8) on the (PWC56096) build stand.
Install the upper (PWC69045) engine mount (12) on the LP compressor case upper front mount pad (11) as follows:

l2item.para: Lubricate the threads of the four bolts (2) with (PWC03-001) engine oil.
Install the upper (PWC69045) engine mount with the four washers (3) and the four bolts (2). Torque the bolts 125 to 170 lb.in. (14.2-19.2 Nm.).

l1item.para: Install the lower (PWC69045) engine mount (5) on the LP compressor case lower front mount pad as follows:

l2item.para: Lubricate the threads of the four bolts (6) with (PWC03-001) engine oil.
Install the lower (PWC69045) engine mount (5) with the four washers (3) and the four bolts (6). Torque the bolts 125 to 170 lb.in. (14.2-19.2 Nm.).

caution.para: MAKE SURE THAT THE MAINTENANCE STAND WHEELS ARE LOCKED.
MAKE SURE THE (PWC68626) ADAPTER (4) AND THE (PWC68607)YOKE (8) ARE IN THE POSITION SHOWN IN RELATION TO THE COMPRESSOR CASE (REF. DETAIL A).

l1item.para: Lower the engine and align the holes in the two upper and lower ( PWC69045)engine mounts (5) and (12) with the (PWC68607)yoke (8).
Install the two pins (9) and (10) to secure the engine on the (PWC56096)build stand .
Remove the engine handling (PWC69262) sling and it's attaching hardware from the engine.
To prepare the engine for shipment to an approved overhaul or service facility:

note.para: It is not required to convert right engines to left engines for installation in the shipping container.

l2item.para: Check the engine logbook and make sure that the engine fuel and oil systems have been preserved.
Install the shipping caps, covers and plugs.
Remove the engine from the (PWC56096) build stand.
Install the engine in the engine shipping container along with all unattached engine components and required documentation.

l1item.para: To prepare the engine for installation on the aircraft:

l2item.para: If required, do the procedures to convert the engine for installation on the opposite side of the aircraft (Ref. Task 72-00-00-870-801).
Do the procedures to install the engine on the aircraft (Ref. Task 72-00-00-410-802).

task.title: Removal of the Engine from the Build Stand

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for removing the engine from the build stand.
Make sure the engine and the (PWC56096) build stand are directly beneath the hoist.
Make sure a clear overhead space of at least eight feet (2.44 meters) is available, not including distance from top of engine to hoist hook.
Lock the transport wheels and the gearbox hand wheel on (PWC56096)build stand .
Install the engine rear lifting bracket (Ref. Task 72-00-00-540-801).

caution.para: WHEN AN ENGINE IS TO BE REMOVED FROM A MAINTENANCE STAND, MAKE SURE THAT A HOIST OF SUFFICIENT LIFTING CAPACITY AND SAFETY FACTOR IS AVAILABLE. REFER TO Task 72-00-00-540-801, ENGINE AND SHIPPING CONTAINER LIFTING PRECAUTIONS.

l1item.para: If the engine is to be installed on the aircraft, refer to the Aircraft Maintenance Manual for approved ground handling equipment and procedures.
Install the engine (PWC69262) lifting sling on the engine.
Take the weight of the engine on the (PWC69262)lifting sling and make sure that the sling is in the horizontal attitude.
Remove the two pins (9) and (10) that attach the compressor case to the (PWC68607)yoke.
Make sure that the engine is suspended in the horizontal attitude.
Move the (PWC56096)build stand way from the engine.
Remove the four bolts (2) and the four washers (3) that attach the upper (PWC69045)engine mount (12) to the compressor case. Remove the upper (PWC69045)engine mount.
Remove the four bolts (6) and the four washers (7) that attach the lower (PWC69045)engine mount (5) to the compressor case. Remove the (PWC69045)engine mount.
Put the parts in (PWC05-053) polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

caution.para: DO NOT ALLOW THE ENGINE TO REMAIN SUSPENDED FROM THE HOIST LONGER THAN NECESSARY.

l1item.para: Hoist the engine carefully.
Install the two engine upper and lower (PWC69045)engine mounts on the ( PWC56096)build stand with the two ball lock pins (9) and (10).

graphic.title: Removal of the Engine from the Build Stand

task.title: Removing the Engine from the Aircraft

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for removing the engine from the aircraft.
Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Preserve the engine fuel system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-620-802).
Preserve the engine oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-620-803).
Make the build stand ready to receive the engine (Ref. Task 72-00-00-410-802).

caution.para: THE ENGINE ELECTRONIC CONTROL (EEC) ELECTRICAL POWER MUST BE OFF DURING ENGINE REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION AND/OR WHEN THE ENGINE ELECTRICAL HARNESS IS DISCONNECTED FROM THE AIRCRAFT IN ORDER TO AVOID DAMAGE TO THE EEC. THE EEC ELECTRICAL POWER MUST REMAIN OFF WHEN THE ENGINE IS REMOVED AND/OR THE ELECTRICAL HARNESS IS DISCONNECTED FROM THE AIRCRAFT.

l1item.para: Remove the engine from the aircraft. Refer to the AMM.

note.para: The engine lifting sling is identified in the AMM.

l1item.para: If the engine is being removed to be installed in a shipping container, install the nose cone locking bracket assembly PK4636 (part of the shipping container assembly PK4663), on the engine as follows ((Ref. Fig. :

caution.para: MAKE SURE THE GROMMET ON THE CONE LOCKING BRACKET IS ATTACHED AND SECURE.
DO NOT USE ANY LUBRICATING OIL ON THE THREADS OF THE SCREWS.

l2item.para: Attach the cone locking bracket (4) on the fan case forward flange with the four screws (3), the four washers (2) and the four nuts (1).
Torque the screws (3) to 27 to 30 lb.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).

caution.para: DO NOT REMOVE THE CONE LOCKING BRACKET UNLESS ACCESS TO THE COMPRESSOR AREA IS REQUIRED. THE BRACKET MUST BE INSTALLED WHILE THE ENGINE IS BEING TRANSPORTED.

l1item.para: Put the engine in the (PWC56096)build stand (Refer to Task 72-00-00-410-802).

caution.para: THE AIRFRAME-MOUNTED ENGINE EEC MUST BE REMOVED FROM THE AIRCRAFT AND RETAINED WITH THE ENGINE ONLY WHEN THE REASON FOR THE ENGINE REMOVAL IS A SCHEDULED ENGINE OVERHAUL.

l1item.para: Remove the engine EEC from the aircraft. Refer to the AMM. Keep the engine EEC with the engine.

graphic.title: Installation of the Cone Locking Bracket

l1item.para: Close the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

task.title: Installing the Engine on the Aircraft

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for installing the engine on the aircraft.
Open the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Do the procedures necessary to convert the engine for installation on the opposite side of the aircraft, if required (Ref. Task 72-00-00-870-801).
Remove the engine from the build stand (Ref. Task 72-00-00-010-801).
If the engine was removed from a shipping container, remove the nose cone locking bracket assembly PK4636 (part of the shipping container assembly PK4663) from the fan case as follows (Ref. Fig. :

l2item.para: Remove the four screws (3), the four nuts (1), the four washers (2) and the cone locking bracket (4) from the fan case forward flange.
Put the cone locking bracket and attaching hardware in the engine shipping container.

l1item.para: For best electrical connection, the engine wiring harness-to-firewall electrical connectors must be clean and have electrical contact enhancer applied to pins. Refer to Task 70-00-00-110-802 for connector cleaning procedure and optional contact enhancer procedure.

caution.para: MAKE SURE AN EEC IS INSTALLED IN THE AIRCRAFT (REFER TO THE AMM).

l1item.para: Install the engine on the aircraft. Refer to the AMM.

note.para: The engine lifting sling is identified in the AMM.

l1item.para: Install the flight closures on the engine outboard upper and lower mount pads.

graphic.title: Removal of the Cone Locking Bracket

l1item.para: Close the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Do the procedures necessary to depreserve the engine oil system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-630-803).
Do the procedures necessary to depreserve the engine fuel system (Ref. Task 72-00-00-630-802).
Do the necessary engine ground checks (Ref. Task 71-00-00-760-804).

l1item.para: Hot Section Inspection intervals and Engine Operating Time between Overhauls are summarized in Task 05-20-00-210-801. Periodic Inspections are summarized in Task 05-20-00-210-802. Detailed inspection procedures are provided, where applicable, in the relevant INSPECTION/CHECK sections of subject chapters in this manual.

taskproc.title: Engines with Damage Outside Specified Limits

l1item.para: Engines with damage outside specified limits (e.g. damaged impellers) may be returned to service providing the prior approval and substantiation data is obtained from the P&WC Design Approval Appointee (DAA). (Copies of the substantiation documentation will be supplied to Transport Canada.) The local airworthiness authority must be informed of the P&WC recommendation.
Operators must supply all relevant details of the damage to:

High temperature alloy corrosion may be identified as metal loss or pitting, but more usually appears as local swelling or buildup due to greater volume occupied by nickel oxides. These corrosion products vary in color from black to green and in the advanced state there will be cracking and flaking, referred to as exfoliation. Care should be taken to distinguish between corrosion buildup and possible light brown or rust-colored deposits which are essentially harmless combustion by-products. The latter are usually more widespread over hot section components and, while possibly affecting performance, will not directly affect compressor mechanical integrity.

note.para: This task is contained in the pw617fe Maintenance Manual Part No. 3072162
This task is contained in the pw617fe Maintenance Manual Part No. 3072162

unlitem.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

caution.para: THE BORESCOPE IS A DELICATE DEVICE; IT IS CONSIDERED AT RISK TO SEVERE SHOCKS, TWISTING AND PINCHING. CARE AND ATTENTION MUST BE EXERCISED WHEN HANDLING IT.
HEAT CAN SEVERELY DAMAGE THE BORESCOPE. BORESCOPE INSPECTION MUST ONLY BE DONE AFTER THE ENGINE HAS COOLED TO AN ACCEPTABLE LEVEL.
DO NOT USE A BORESCOPE WITH AN OUTER DIAMETER LARGER THAN 4.0 MM.

l1item.para: The borescope is an optical device that enables an operator to visually inspect the hot section and compressor areas of the engine while the engine remains installed in the aircraft or at a ground handling installation.
The (PWC38711)borescope kit includes a camera adapter, for use with an optional camera, so that a photographic record can be made of the borescope inspection.
Damage may be difficult to estimate through a borescope. It is therefore important that borescope inspection be performed by experienced personnel only.
Rotation of the HP compressor and HP turbines for borescope inspection can be accomplished by removing the starter motor and installing the (PWC34941)gearshaft wrench .
Borescope access to engine components:
Insert the borescope between the fan blades until the fan exit vanes and grommets can be viewed.
Inspect the grommets for cracks, tears and thermal distress.
Inspect the vanes in accordance with Table.
Reposition the borescope and repeat the inspection until all the vanes and grommets have been inspected.
Remove the borescope.

entry.para: Max. 4 per vane if: dim. a is less than 0.150 inch (3.8 mm) and dim. b is less than 0.125 inch (3.2 mm), and separated by a minimum of 0.300 inch (7.6 mm).
More than four per vane and/or if dim. a is more than 0.150 inch (3.8 mm), and/or dim. b is more than 0.125 inch (3.2 mm), and/or less than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) apart.
Max. 4 per vane if dim. c and dim. d are less than 0.050 inch (1.3 mm) each, and separated by a minimum of 0.300 inch (7.6 mm).
If either dim c and/or d are more than 0.050 inch (1.3 mm) and/or less than 0.300 inch (7.6 mm) apart.
Max. one per pressure or suction surface 0.020 inch (0.5 mm) deep if not directly opposite each other.
Nicks deeper than 0.020 inch (0.5 mm), or one on each surface directly opposite each other.
One bend per vane if dim. a is less than 0.250 inch (6.3 mm) and deflection is 0.030 inch (0.8 mm) max.
More than one bent area per vane, and/or deflection more than 0.030 inch (0.8 mm) .

l1item.para: Remove the starter motor. Refer to the AMM.
Install the (PWC34941)gearshaft wrench in the AGB starter drive gearshaft.
Insert the borescope probe through the fan and fan exit vanes until the leading edges of the HP compressor blades are visible.
Inspect the compressor blades.

caution.para: MAKE SURE THE TIP OF THE BORESCOPE IS NOT BETWEEN COMPRESSOR BLADES BEFORE ROTATING THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: Rotate the HP compressor rotor slowly, using the (PWC34941)gearshaft wrench in the AGB starter drive gearshaft, and repeat the inspection until all 16 blades have been inspected.
Remove the borescope.
Remove the (PWC34941)gearshaft wrench.

entry.para: No more than two per blade permitted provided damage is not on adjacent blades and Dim. a is less than 0.090 inch (2.3 mm), Dim. b is less than 0.030 inch (0.7 mm), nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.0 mm) and do not occur within 0.200 inch ( 5.0 mm) of blade root or 0.400 inch (10.0 mm) of blade tip.

No more than two per blade permitted to a maximum of four blades provided damage is not on adjacent blades and Dim. a is less than 0.090 inch (2.3 mm), Dim. b is less than 0.030 inch (0.7 mm), nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.0 mm) and do not occur within 0.200 inch (5.0 mm) of blade root or 0.400 inch (10.0 mm) of blade tip.

More than two nicks per blade or more than four blades damaged, Dim. a in excess of 0.190 inch (4.8 mm), Dim. b in excess of 0.090 inch (2.3 mm) or nicks occur within 0.200 inch (5.0 mm) of blade root or 0.400 inch (10.0 mm) of blade tip.

No more than two per blade permitted provided Dim. c is less than 0.040 inch (1.0 mm), Dim. d is less than 0.010 inch (0.25 mm), nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.120 inch (3.0 mm) and do not occur within 0.200 inch ( mm) of blade root or 0.400 inch (10.0 mm) of blade tip.

No more than two per blade permitted to a maximum of four blades provided Dim. c is less than 0.080 inch (1.2 mm), Dim. d is less than 0.030 inch (0.7 mm), nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.120 inch (3.0 mm) and do not occur within 0.200 inch ( mm) of blade root or 0.400 inch (10.0 mm) of blade tip.

More than two nicks per blade or more than four blades damaged, Dim. c in excess of 0.080 inch (1.2 mm), Dim. d in excess of 0.030 inch (0.7 mm) or nicks occur within 0.200 inch ( mm) of blade root or 0.400 inch (10.0 mm) of blade tip.
Surface Damage: Nicks or Dents (Area k)
Acceptable to a maximum depth of 0.003 inch (0.7 mm) provided damage does not appear to be directly opposite on pressure and suction sides of blade.
Acceptable to a maximum depth of 0.007 inch (0.17 mm) provided damage does not appear to be directly opposite on pressure and suction sides of blade.
Damage in excess of 0.007 inch (0.17 mm) deep or occurring directly opposite on pressure and suction sides of blade.
Blade Tip Corner Loss: Leading edge, Dim. e and f.
Blade Tip Corner Loss: Trailing edge
Acceptable provided Dim. g or Dim. h is less than 0.020 inch (0.5 mm).
Acceptable provided Dim. g or Dim. h is less than 0.040 inch (1.0 mm).
Dim. g or Dim. h in excess of 0.040 inch (1.0 mm).
Acceptable provided Dim. j is not in excess of 0.005 inch (0.13 mm).
Acceptable provided Dim. j is not in excess of 0.010 inch (0.25 mm).
Dim. j, in excess of 0.010 inch (0.25 mm).

caution.para: DO NOT ROTATE THE ENGINE WHILE THE BORESCOPE IS BETWEEN THE COMPRESSOR BLADES.

l1item.para: Insert the borescope probe between the fan blades, the fan exit vanes, and the HP compressor rotor and stator vanes until the HP compressor impeller is visible.
Inspect the impeller.
Reposition the borescope and inspect as necessary and inspect all the impeller blades.
Remove the borescope.

entry.para: No more than two per vane permitted provided Dim. a is less than 0.050 inch (1.2 mm), Dim. b is less than 0.030 inch (0.07 mm), nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) and do not occur within 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) of vane root or 0.100 inch (2.5 mm) of vane tip.

No more than two per vane permitted to a maximum of four per vane provided Dim. a is less than 0.090 inch (2.2 mm), Dim. b is less than 0.050 inch (1.2 mm), nicks are separated by a minimum of 0.200 inch (5.1 mm) and do not occur within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of vane root or 0.125 inch (3.2 mm) of vane tip.

More than two nicks per vane or more than four vanes damaged, Dim. a, in excess of 0.090 inch (2.2 mm), Dim. b, in excess of 0.050 inch (1.2 mm) or nicks occur within 0.250 inch (6.4 mm) of vane root or 0.125 inch (3.2 mm) of vane tip.
Surface damage: Nicks and/or dents: (Area g)
Acceptable to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch (0.13 mm) provided damage does not appear to be directly opposite on pressure and suction sides of vane.
Acceptable to a maximum depth of 0.010 inch (0.25 mm) provided damage does not appear to be directly opposite on pressure and suction sides of vane.
Damage in excess of 0.010 inch (0.25 mm) deep or occurring directly opposite on pressure and suction sides of vane.
Vane tip corner loss: Leading edge.
Acceptable provided Dim. e is not in excess of 0.050 inch (1.2 mm) and f is not in excess of 0.040 inch (1.0 mm).
Acceptable provided Dim. e and f are not in excess of 0.070 inch (1.7 mm).
Dim. e and f in excess of 0.070 inch (1.7 mm).
Acceptable provided Dim. d is not in excess of 0.008 inch (0.20 mm).

note.para: The combustion chamber liner, HP turbine vane ring, HP turbine blades and HP turbine shroud segments can be inspected at this time.

l1item.para: Remove the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.

warning.para: THE VOLTAGE OUTPUT OF THE IGNITION EXCITER IS SUFFICIENT TO CAUSE A LETHAL ELECTRICAL SHOCK. THE RESIDUAL VOLTAGE IN THE IGNITION EXCITER MAY BE DANGEROUSLY HIGH. MAKE SURE THE IGNITION IS SWITCHED OFF. DISCONNECT THE INPUT CONNECTOR FIRST (REFER TO THE AIRFRAME MAINTENANCE MANUAL) AND WAIT AT LEAST 10 MINUTES BEFORE FURTHER WORK IS ATTEMPTED. DISCONNECT THE IGNITER CABLES AT THE EXCITER BEFORE DISCONNECTING AT THE IGNITERS. ALWAYS USE INSULATED TOOLS TO REMOVE THE CABLE COUPLING NUTS. DO NOT TOUCH THE OUTPUT CONNECTORS OR THE COUPLING NUTS WITH BARE HANDS.

caution.para: DO NOT ALLOW THE IGNITION CABLE BRAIDING OR THE FERRULES TO ROTATE WHEN TURNING THE COUPLING NUTS.

l1item.para: Disconnect the ignition exciter input connector. Refer to the AMM.
Disconnect the ignition cable assembly from the outboard igniter (Ref. Task 74-20-01-000-801).
Remove the igniter (Ref. Task 74-20-02-000-801) and examine for damage.
Insert the borescope into the combustion chamber liner.
Inspect as many fuel nozzles as possible.
Inspect the fuel nozzle for evidence of:

l2item.para: Carbon build-up affecting fuel nozzle operation. This will be seen as a carbon lump at the edge of the tip orifice.
Large deposits of soot on the nozzle tip face.

note.para: The start fuel nozzles may form some soot on the nozzle tip faces during start and sub-idle condition. At high power the swirler air should wash the nozzle tip face.

l2item.para: Thermal distress and oxidation on the nozzle tip face.
Any crack indication on the nozzle swirler.

l1item.para: If any of these conditions are evident, inspect the combustion chamber large exit duct, small exit duct and HP turbine vane ring for thermal distress.
Remove the borescope.
Install the igniter (Ref. Task 74-20-02-400-801).
Connect the ignition cable assembly to the outboard igniter (Ref. Task 74-20-01-400-801).
Install the engine cowlings as necessary. Refer to the AMM.
Follow the instructions for gaining access to the fuel nozzles. Refer to Task 72-00-00-290-808.
Inspect the combustion chamber liner.
Follow the instructions for closing up the engine after inspecting the fuel nozzles. Refer to Task 72-00-00-290-808.

entry.para: Cracks: Areas A, B and C

Up to 1.000 inch (25.4 mm) long, connecting adjacent holes and opened less than 0.040 inch (1.00 mm) wide are acceptable, provided cracks are not converging in such a way that material loss will occur.
Axial cracks starting from the dilution hole edge, not exceeding 0.300 inch (0.70 mm) and 0.040 inch (1.00 mm) wide.

Multiple cracks, not exceeding five, between 1.000 inch (25.4 mm) and 2.000 inches (50.8 mm) long, connecting adjacent holes and opened less than 0.060 inch (1.52 mm) wide and at least 3.00 inches (76.20 mm) apart are acceptable, provided cracks are not converging in such a way that material loss will occur. - Inspect twice as frequently.
Cracks more than 2.000 inches (50.8 mm) long and opened more than 0.080 inch (2.00 mm) and/or converging in such a way that material loss will occur.
Radial cracks around the fuel manifold floating collar bracket weldment (Ref View E)

Radial cracks not exceeding 0.30 inch long and 0.030 inch wide are acceptable for further service, provided cracks are not converging such that a piece of metal can be liberated in the gas path. Eight cracks are acceptable provided they are at least 0.15 inch apart from each other and are not converging.
Radial cracks once discovered, must be monitored by regular borescope inspection at 50 flight hour intervals.
Circumferential cracks around the fuel manifold floating collar bracket weldment (Ref View E).

Two circumferential cracks not exceeding 60 degrees angle and 0.030 inch wide each in and around the floating collar bracket weldment are acceptable provided they are 60 degrees apart circumferentially from each other, or one circumferential crack not exceeding 180 degrees is acceptable. Circumferential cracks intersecting with radial crack are acceptable provided they are not converging in such a way that a piece of metal can be liberated.
Circumferential cracks once discovered, must be monitored by regular borescope inspection at 50 flight hour intervals.
Local burning at the edge of dilution holes. Bulges due to local burning with mulitple cracks less than 0.300 inch (7.62 mm) long and 0.020 inch (0.50 mm) wide
No holes permitted except for those associated with cracks defined above.

Local burning at the edge of dilution holes. Bulges due to local burning with mulitple cracks less than 0.300 inch (7.62 mm) long and 0.040 inch (1.00 mm) wide. Circumferential burning and or bulging at the large exit duct and small exit duct lips not exceeding 0.050 inch (1.27 mm) long.
Cracks starting from the dilution hole edge and converging to adjacent dilution holes 0.040 inch (1.00 mm) wide with edges curled and burned. - Inspect twice as frequently.
Cracks starting from the dilution hole edge and converging to adjacent dilution holes 0.080 inch (2.0 mm) wide with edges curled and burned.

Local burning at the edge of dilution holes or bulges due to local burning with mulitple cracks less than 0.300 inch (7.62 mm) long and 0.040 inch (1.00 mm) wide. Burning and or bulging at the large exit duct and small exit duct lips not exceeding 0.050 inch (1.27 mm) long in a circumferential direction
Thermal barrier coating spalling: Area C
Coating loss not exceeding 2.00 inch (50.8 mm) by 2.00 inch (50.8 mm)
Burning and or bulging at the coating spalled areas. Inspect twice as frequently.
Thermal barrier coating spalling: Area D
Coating loss not exceeding 1.00 inch (25.4 mm) by 1.00 inch (25.4 mm).

l1item.para: Insert the borescope (PWC68833)guide tube in the ignitor port. The guide tube is correctly installed when the notch of the guide tube is facing up as shown (Ref. Fig..
Insert the borescope inside the (PWC68833) guide tube until you can see the HP blades.

Loss of coating evident or parent material visible.
Acceptable, provided performance check is acceptable.

l1item.para: Insert the borescope (PWC68833)guide tube in the fuel nozzle port. The guide tube is correctly installed when the notch of the guide tube is facing up as shown (Ref. Fig..

Bends on airfoil trailing edges (area g).
One bend with a maximum deflection of 0.015 inch (0.38 mm) and a maximum length of 25% of trailing edge length is acceptable.

caution.para: DO NOT ROTATE THE LP TURBINE.

Inspect the LP turbine vane ring.
